story:
Short Summary

My name is Gunnar Engblom. I am a Swedish biologist who arranges birdwatching tours in Peru since 1998 with my company Kolibri Expeditions. I have been involved in numerous projects involving threatened birds, and even though I run a bird tour company I have always looked for ways in which birding tourism can empower conservation. Getting myself involved with my company to raise funds for the local bird guide Cesar Zevallos to collect breeding data of the Junin Grebe is a fantastic way of both empowering local people as well as channeling the concerns of birdwatchers and conservationists worldwide.

Critically Endangered Junin Grebe may go extinct. Without continuous monitoring of the breeding success, it may happen faster than we can detect it. 

The Junin Grebe has an extremely small range and population. It is the most threatened bird in Peru. Yet there is no regular monitoring that can give reliable data of changes of the population.  By introducing simple monitoring of the breeding success over a couple of months to a year, we shall show that this methodology gives far more reliable data to monitor any change in the population than the yearly/bi-yearly total counts of birds in the lake which are carried out using small rocky boats.  

The total population counts have many sources of discrepancies that makes it impossible to compare data from one year to another, such as:

  • difficulty of separating Junin and Silvery Grebe in the field, 
  • observer experience, 
  • birds being wary not allowing getting close enough for certain identification, 
  • birds diving creating double counts, 
  • birds staying within the massive reed areas not allowing to be counted, 
  • birds moving from one survey quadrant to another creating double counts or omit to be counted.  
As things are now, rapid changes in the population numbers could go undetected, and may be discovered when it is too late. 

Long Summary

There were 23 species of grebes known in the world, but three of these have gone extinct very recently - Colombian Grebe 1977, Atitlán Grebe in Guatemala 1989, and Alaotra Grebe of Madagascar 2010. All were very restricted in range and both Atitlán and Alaotra Grebes were flightless. The same is true for the Junin Grebe in Central Peru and with its very small population of only 200-350 birds it is the most threatened bird in Peru. 
It only lives on the Junin Lake and due to the isolation in Pleistocene glacial times it evolved losing the ability of flight. Conditions of the lake stayed more or less the same until mining started 1955 and the regulation of the water level for a hydroelectric power plant below on the Mantaro river. 

Morrison visited the lake in January-May in 1938, before any alterations, and found the Junin Grebe extremely abundant. Still in 1961 Frank Gill saw several hundreds of birds in the southern end of the lake, suggesting that well over 1000 birds inhabited the lake at this time. 

?The recent changes of its habitat with pollution from mining, served waters from nearby communities, agriculture and livestock, as well as abrupt changes in water levels are probably the main reasons for the reduction in numbers. Possibly these factors have changed the composition of food items available. A recent threat include presence of large trout in the lake.

??Practically all recent census since 1977 have come up with similar numbers of 200-350 birds in the whole lake. However, the methodology used, the skills and experience of the observers to separate Junin Grebe from the similar shorter-billed Silvery Grebe, the birds tendency to frequently dive when a boat is approaching, the possibility that a part of the population is within the inaccessible reed area and the limited range of hand-held binoculars, make numbers from year to year extremely difficult to compare.  

The most recent census counted 236 birds (Rolando Tito, SERNANP, pers com). A previous count one year earlier had 315 birds (Alan Chamorro, ECOAN, pers com). So either, there is a worrying 25% decrease of the population in one year, or the methodology for counting the whole population is not very exact.

Regardless, drastic real changes in the numbers are not going to be detected until it is too late. A complimentary census is needed to look at changes in the population dynamics and the breeding success. This is what we aim to do with this project.

Methodology.

Cesar Zevallos - a well known local bird guide from Ondores, Junin, has taken part in numerous census studies in the past and knows the Junin Grebe very well. The idea is that Cesar gets out to the reed edge on a daily basis. First to locate the nests. Last year Cesar found around 30 nests and a good number to get some sort of tendency if they were to monitored over an extended period. Notes will be taken on GPS location of each nest, how many young are reared and if any of the nests are abandoned.

Cesar's monthly salary when working with other projects in the region has been US$260/month. I asked Cesar whether he would be interested in collecting the data for the project if I could raise the $300 per month and he was more than pleased to confirm. It makes me wonder why no one has already commenced to collect the necessary data this way. 

It is not easy field work and this could be a reason. Cesar uses a aluminum one person homemade kayak to get to the reed edge. Over some stretches he will have to carry it over the floating vegetation. There are sink holes here and there, so he will in most circumstances get wet. The rainy season has started which also makes the work hard, wet and cold. And the altitude is 4100 meters above sea level.  Yet, $300/month is an important addition to the family household of Cesar's family with wife and two kids at 6 and 9.  Only 10 US$ from 30 people assures one month of expense to run the project.

What We Need & What You Get

We need minimum of 3 months of data, thus about $1000 for the first phase, plus telescope, tripod and digital camera. Thus, $3000 is set as our minimum goal.  But both to find out more in detail about the threats to grebes and to get the overview picture we should try to expand the project over a year to include.  

  • Point counts from the reed edge on daily basis to monitor population dynamics and population changes. These point count studies can be reproduced with accuracy in future years. 
  • Toxicology and stomach content studies of dead birds found. 
  • Sampling of food availability different times of year with a 

    homemade Minnow trap made from a soda bottle will give some immediate answers. 

Here is a cost breakdown for the whole year.

$3600 - salary to Cesar. 
$1000 - telescope
$400 - tripod
$500 - point and shoot camera.

So all in all the funds needed for a full year is $5500. But we shall start with only $3000 in funds regardless of how much can be raised. 

If we raise more money the funds will be carried into 2017 and continue the project. 

Perks

We believe that the pledge for the Junin Grebe is so powerful, that anyone would want to donate at least 1 US$ and spread the word to their friends.  If you are a birdwatcher and interested in birding in Peru, you should definitely have a look at the perks in the $100-1000 range. All these will give you birdwatching perks in Peru with a value which actually surpasses the total of the amount donated. It is a WIN-WIN-WIN-WIN situation.

  • You can't lose.  You save money,
  • Kolibri Expeditions gets a client,
  • Cesar Zevallos gets a monthly salary
  • JUNIN GREBE GETS A SURVEY METHODOLOGY THAT WILL SHOW TRUE FLUCTUATIONS IN THE POPULATION BEFORE IT IS TOO LATE.
Everyone is a winner!

Even if we do not reach our goals with this campaign, it shall not stop us to collect data for at least a couple of months.  

The Impact of the Junin Grebe project.

By showing that reliable population data can be collected by doing a survey of breeding success and point counts from fixed points, it will highlight the importance of creating better access to the lake reed edge. As for now, any birder wanting to see the Grebe needs to hire a motor boat and spend minimum of over three hours on the lake. For the current surveys that includes counting all the birds on the open water it is extremely manpower demanding. BUT WHAT IF?

What if there was a boardwalk to the reed edge? About 2 km of boardwalk would be needed. Check this boardwalk of similar length from Point Pelee, in Canada. 

This would not be inexpensive and is out of the scope of what our modest efforts of fundraising can achieve. But if it is 100% clear that the best data can be collected from fixed points, then I am sure that enough money could be raised by larger funding bodies such as the Wildfowl and Wetland Trust in the UK, Nature Conservancy of the US or Birdlife International perhaps through the British Birdfair. At the end of the board walk at the reed edge one could build a floating observation tower similar to this construction I saw in the Brazilian Pantanal.

Such a tower can be towed or moved with an engine to different fixed points in the lake, where we already know there are big concentrations of grebes in the non-breeding season. Over a couple of days at various points, one could get a replicable methodology for counting birds in the open water. Such data could be collected several times per year for a small cost in both funds as well as manpower. 

The boardwalk would also dynamize ecotourism in a unprecedented way in Junin. The Junin lake is incredibly impressive with massive number of birds, but the access is limited. The lack of infrastructure and the extreme altitude makes most ecotourists stay away.  The boardwalk would highlight the importance of ecotourism to the lake. It would be managed by SERNANP and the voluntary park guards of the local community which would get an income from the use of the boardwalk. For birders it would make less impact than the current motorized boats and it would promote local ecotourism among Peruvians. Afterall, Junin lake is only 4 hours from Lima. Lima has 9 million inhabitants and ecotourism, especially bird photography, is getting very popular.

Risks & Challenges

Whenever an expat gringo tries to do something positive in Peru (and I presume elsewhere in South America the situation is much the same), we may get reactions that question our sincerity and our motives. When announcing this project I got immediately got such reactions, from very few, but still loud opponents.  Especially local conservation organizations will question your motives and also indirectly hint that conservation funds does not go to true conservation.  It is true however, that we will use the goodwill of doing conservation and perhaps sell a few more birding trips, just as a conservation organizations would get into building lodges in conservation areas to capture funds from birders.  Is there really any difference?

So let's go through the type of critique that is possible. 

  1. The project will deviate important conservation funds.  Not true. There are no conservation funds involved in this project. The money, apart from the small amount donation categories, stem from a part of the price that birdwatchers would spend for a birding tour. 
  2. Commercial companies should not try to do conservation. We are just collecting data which will be shared openly with other institutions such as SERNANP (the Peruvian State Conservation Body) and Birdlife International.  We also have plans to get a student to use analyze the data for a thesis. 
  3. Commercial companies are only interested in making money and have no true interest in conservation. This is just a commercial sales gimmick. While I certainly hope that our interest in saving the Junin Grebe would also be commercially viable giving us more clients in the long run, I still believe the main thing is that we are actually doing SOMETHING. Just stating that someone ought to be doing something, when one can do something oneself is not very satisfactory. We have a unique position with big following on Social Media to be able to raise the money for that SOMETHING that needs to be done. It is our commitment with Cesar Zevallos and his family, and with the Junin Grebe.  
  4. By starting this project you are criticizing the previous work done by other conservation organizations.  We don't see it like that. This data will be supplemental to previous data. Previous conservation work in the Junin area has been very successful in making the local population more aware and have also monitored the water-levels and the pollution, as well as been in constant negotiation about the maximum/minimum water-levels and the amount of pollution. In the future in such negotiations, it shall be vital to know to what extent pollution or water level fluctuations are the problem. 
We shall remain very open about the project and look forward to work with the local conservation NGO:s for a synergistic maximum effect to save the Junin Grebe from extinction. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot support with even ONE DOLLAR, you can still support the project by making it better known among your friends. Use the sharing tools on Indiegogo. Also consider supporting Cesar directly by using his services as a guide in the Junin area. You may also help spreading the word about Kolibri Expeditions as a bird tour operator with social and environmental conscience. 

Furthermore, if you are Peruvian, you may join our Junin outings at a special price that cover our costs, to experience the Junin Grebe first hand. We hope you then help to spread the project to your friends abroad and encourage them to donate.

story:
Who we are

Finca Katanga (Katanga farm) is a family project, our main goal is to provide agricultural land and livestock production using an agosilvopastpralism-based system. Located at 650 mamsl in the municipality of San Luis, Tolima, Colombia; the farm is categorised as a tropical dry forest.

Our principles aim to encourage sustainability in agricultural and livestock activities, outlining methods that reduce negative impacts on the social and natural environments, while promoting the positive results of of a sustainable farming system.

2015 was one of the warmest year on record and this has caused negative repercussions throughout the region.The farm and its inhabitants have suffered the consequences of El Niño : drought, forest fires, mosquito -related diseases (zika , chikungunya , dengue). We realized the need to act quickly to preserve not only our investment and family project but the future of our land; and as a result of this we develop the Iwana project in honour of one of the tenants (Iwana is the Taino name for Iguana).

We identified three main areas of the farm presenting a certain degree of vulnerability to soil erosion, and one area where establishing a connection between the 20-ha secondary forest and a small legume-tree wood would help some animal species (birds, iguanas, and many more) by enlarging their habitat.  We decided that planting native trees would be the best solution.

Trees wouldn’t only reduce and prevent soil erosion or connect woody areas of the farm, they would also bring many other ecosystem services such as carbon sequestration, temperature reduction of the soil surface, housing supply for many birds and other animals, and many more!

The project

We identify 4 zones to plant trees; it represents a total of 11’598 m2.

We plan to plant a total of 590 trees from different species (Algarrobo, Balso, Yarumo, Guadua, Iguá, Caracolí)

We need :

-  1708 m of electric wire for electric fences

-  170.8 studs

-  345 kg of compost

-  Workforce (planting + fence construction + maintenance)

Exchange rate COP/USD - 04.04.2016

It is considered a loss of 10 % of trees by disease, pests or other external factor the first year. Fertilizing twice a year and weeding 8 times in a year.

7% of the total amount for incidentals.

The detailed budget is available upon request.

Impact

Dry forest is an ecosystem found in the very warm lowlands of the tropical and subtropical regions, where summer rain brings 500-1500 mm annually, and the dry season spans 5-8 months. To cope with this strong seasonality, the predominantly deciduous trees shed their leaves during the dry season, creating singular landscapes. Although dry forests have less biodiversity than rain forests, a remarkable diversity of plants and animals calls this habitat home. For some of them, this is their only home. Dry forests account for nearly half of the world’s tropical and subtropical forests, covering large areas of Africa, Latin America and the Asia Pacific.

In Colombia, this ecosystem originally covered around 7% of the territory. Currently, only 1.5-2% of the original cover remains; it is one of the most threatened ecosystems in the country. The Colombian National Park System covers around 10 million of ha. Only 0.4% of them include areas partially covering dry forest ecosystems, and all of them are in the Caribbean region. Due to the precarious conditions of the Tropical Dry Forest in Colombia, it is important to consider regeneration areas as the only opportunity to conserve this fragile ecosystem.

Since the vast majority of the current dry forest coverage is located in productive farms and private properties, it is urgent urgent to make a collective effort to link together and motivate different sectors to ensure the preservation of what remains of this forest.

We know Iwana Project is a small-scale, but we know that its impact will be very positive in the medium and long term and not only for the farm, but for the region. Taking part in this project means supporting an initiative oriented towards mitigation and adaptation to the well-known challenges of Global Warming and Climate Change.

Do you want to participate?

With only $ 5.00 we can buy 25 trees

With only $ 10 we can buy 1500 m of electric wire (protect trees in the early years is essential)

With $ 20 we can produce enough compost for a year!

With $ 50 we can pay the wage for planting 590 trees!

You can also visit our website www.fincakatanga.co or follow us on Facebook or Google+ and the most important : help us to spread our message about Iwana project. Remember: small contributions from a local scale can be the seed for more action on a larger scale!

And... If you are in Colombia, or plan a trip there, you can come and visit Finca Katanga, we’ll be very pleased to show you our activities and other projects!

Gracias!

other ecosystem services such as carbon sequestration, temperature reduction of
the soil surface, housing supply for many birds and other animals, and many
more!The project
We identify 4 zones to plant trees; it
represents a total of 11’598 m2.
We plan to plant a total of 590 trees from different species (Algarrobo, Balso, Yarumo, Guadua, Iguá, Caracolí) 
We need :
-

fences

maintenance)

It
is considered a loss of 10 % of trees by disease, pests or other external
factor the first year. Fertilizing twice a year and
weeding 8 times in a year. 

7% of the total amount for incidentals.The detailed budget is available upon request.
Impact
Dry forest is an
ecosystem found in the very warm lowlands of the tropical and subtropical
regions, where summer rain brings 500-1500 mm annually, and the dry season
spans 5-8 months. To cope with this strong seasonality, the predominantly
deciduous trees shed their leaves during the dry season, creating singular
landscapes. Although dry forests have less biodiversity than rain forests, a
remarkable diversity of plants and animals calls this habitat home. For some of
them, this is their only home. Dry forests account for nearly half of the
world’s tropical and subtropical forests, covering large areas of Africa, Latin
America and the Asia Pacific.In Colombia, this
ecosystem originally covered around 7% of the territory. Currently, only 1.5-2%
of the original cover remains; it is one
of the most threatened ecosystems in the country. The Colombian National
Park System covers around 10 million of ha. Only
0.4% of them include areas partially covering dry forest ecosystems, and all of
them are in the Caribbean region. Due to the precarious conditions of the Tropical Dry Forest in
Colombia, it is important to consider regeneration areas as the only
opportunity to conserve this fragile ecosystem. 

Since the vast
majority of the current dry forest coverage is located in productive farms and
private properties, it is urgent urgent
to make a collective effort to link together and motivate different sectors to
ensure the preservation of what remains of this forest. 
We
know Iwana Project is a small-scale, but we know that its impact will be very
positive in the medium and long term and not only for the farm, but for the
region. Taking part in this project means supporting an initiative oriented
towards mitigation and adaptation to the well-known challenges of Global
Warming and Climate Change. 
Do you want to participate? 
With only $ 5.00 we can buy 25 trees
With only $ 10 we can buy 1500 m of electric
wire (protect trees in the early years is essential)
With $ 20 we can produce enough compost for a
year!
With $ 50 we can pay the wage for planting 590
trees!
You can also visit our website www.fincakatanga.co or follow us on Facebook or Google+ and the most important : help us to spread our message about Iwana project. Remember:
small contributions from a local scale can be the seed for more action on a
larger scale!And... If
you are in Colombia, or plan a trip there, you can come and visit Finca
Katanga, we’ll be very pleased to show you our activities and other projects!Gracias!

story:
The Beginning of Saving Trees, Helping People

The founders of Aalaniel Crating Systems, Inc. are Craig L Aaland and Roger B Nielsen, both of Scandinavian heritage, and each have over 40 years experience in our respective fields; Craig in the Moving Industry and Roger in Plastics Manufacturing. The name Aalaniel Crating comes from combining the first letters of our two names...clever, huh?

                                  


                 

Why do these products make sense for you?

If you are a member of...
...The General Public - This new crating system can be used by novices and professionals, alike. Kits will be available for rental at most self-serve household moving companies (a.k.a. U-Haul, Ryder, etc.). You will be able to protect your mirrors, valuable artwork in the same way professional movers do.
...Moving Company Owners - This new system will create better cash retention in your company. Ballooning costs for ordering multiple third-party crates for customer moves can be scaled way back. Fragile and marginally fragile items can be crated, using reusable crating, thereby reducing liability claims without increasing these third-party cash drains. Your company keeps control of schedules (see driver's advantages).
...Packing Professionals - This new system allows you to control your own workflow. No need to rely on the schedules of third-party crating companies. If your contract calls for you to pay for crating (to third-parties), reusable crating keeps that revenue in your pocket. Reusable crating is also assembled around a mirror carton-packed item in about 20 minutes, as opposed to the 40-50 minute average time of a custom wood crate.
...Independent Drivers - This new system keeps you on the go. How many times during the loading process do items appear from under beds or behind heavy furniture that should be crated? Scheduling a third-party crater to return to the jobsite keeps you sitting at the curb. Or, assuming the liability of accepting an uncrated item is financially dangerous. Having kits on your truck gives you the freedom to crate on-the-fly - and keep you on the road.
...Shippers of High-Grade Artwork - This new system gives you a secure, easy-to-use method of protecting valuable art pieces during transport and storage. It is great value for artists who create and sell their own work to pass this up-scale crate on to their customers. It is convenient value for private or corporate art owners who move their collection in regular intervals.
...Consumers of Professional Moving Services - This new system assures you that your moving professionals will be free to crate more of your precious items in an extremely more cost-effective way. Contractual limits are placed on cost outlays, in many cases, forcing the surveyor and contractors to make critical choices on the crates they order for your move. More of your personal items will receive the protection and care they (and you) deserve.
...Manufacturers of Custom Sub-Assemblies - This new system can give you an alternative to one-time-use crating systems that cost money to build, money to disassembly, and are unlikely to be reused because of size, shape, or damage. If you regularly ship sub-assemblies to assembly destination plants, this system can save you time, money, and dreadful waste.

Introducing the Aalaniel Products

http://www.aalaniel.com

The basic Aalaniel Crating model is called the Evergreen; you can see it assembled in this CAD rendering. The Blue Spruce model contains longer extension pieces that replace the parts of the frame between the center member (the part with our logo on it) and the corner unit. Each wall of the frame can be extended out to 84" with the Blue Spruce extensions. The Yellow Pine model contains more cross member assemblies to brace larger frame sizes (if needed).

The Aalaniel Crating system is designed as a 2-D crating system, specifically any X/Y dimension between 28" and 84" while always being 4" thick. These sizes fit the majority of custom built wood frames for household moving (and the majority for high-end artwork shipping requirements.

To accommodate crating needs that exceed the 4" standard width, the Aalaniel system will have available, in the near future, connector elements that will join 2 or more Aalaniel crates together - side-by-side. This gives consumers and professionals alike the ability to crate items with a re-usable, sustainable crating system. SAVES TREES, HELPS PEOPLE!


This is the Evergreen model in a portable carrying case:


This is the Blue Spruce model in a portable carrying case:


This is the Yellow Pine model in a portable carrying case:


Future Frame to Frame Link Section:

What We Need to Roll This Ball

Here's how our early costs break down for our backers in more detail:

  1. MADE IN THE USA! We have 24 separate parts that we will build tooling to mold and manufacture the crating system and their traveling cases. All the molding and assembly will take place right here in the USA - specifically in Nampa, Idaho.
  2. QUALITY QUOTING. Injection molds are expensive and we have worked with our vendor(s) getting this system quoted 6 ways to Tuesday (old Minnesota saying). We are confident of the quality we expect to receive. 
  3. WHO GETS ONE? The finished kits will be expensive in terms of retailing them to the general public, but they will eventually be available to anyone and everyone. We expect that our base model kit will retail for around $300 and almost $400 with a fitted case. We would like all our backers to get an Aalaniel Crating kit, but we have to be careful not to recreate supply errors of the recent past - crowd funded projects that could not afford to produce enough to get the company off the ground and fulfill promises to their backers.
  4. OUR BACKER'S MONEY AND SUCCESS. We are dedicated to get the company off the ground, through the starting gate, and running down the track of growing success. We encourage our backers to share and refer others to this campaign to avoid delays in accomplishing all of these things. Indiegogo asks us to describe where the funds will go if we do not make our goal...well honestly, right back here again. We will start another crowd funding campaign (with marketing adjustments and focus pivots) and combine all funds raised until we do make our tooling goal.

                                   

Risks & Challenges

See Website

Ways You Can Save Trees, Help People

   *********** BE A BACKER; BE A REFERRAL CHAMPION ************

                                                        

 Some people just can't contribute, but everybody can still help:
  1. CASH BACKER Obviously, the best way to help is to become a backer of this campaign. We pledge to do everything in our power to fulfill everything we say and to keep our friends and backers as up-to-date and informed as possible.
  2. ACTION BACKER Whether or not you can make a contribution, could you please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign? In the near future (and during this campaign), we will setup a referral contest program for all those who help our campaign by successfully getting the word out to the whole world. Refer others and: You will be eligible for the same PERK benefits that 4 of your friends earn with their donations, as well as potentially other prizes tbd! (use the share Indiegogo share tools!)
  3. BACKER TRACKS Make sure that you always use the Indiegogo share tools! We can automatically track all your referrals and your referrals' pledge activity - giving you full benefit credit to receive perks, additional perks, and ownership of some of the first Aalaniel products to be produced!

Coupons in the Perks:

See website and backer's emails.


And that's all there is to it.

Your turn to take ACTION - Pick a Perk,

DONATE NOW!

Let's rock this thing!

story:
Starting with the soil

In Massachusetts, we currently EXPORT a lot of our garbage. What a waste! Close to capacity, our landfills are set to close by 2021.

In Franklin County, we also have a high recidivism rate, which means that nearly half the people who come out of jail end up back there—often because of a lack of access to meaningful, engaging work and other forms of social supports that can be invisible to those who already have them.

At the Compost Co-operative, we want to live in a world where food scraps—and humans—are considered precious, not disposable.

We believe in compost as a powerful agent of social change.

The Compost Co-op is a collective effort to interrupt the process of repeated incarceration, with all its damage to individuals, families, and communities. We offer commercial and residential food scraps pickup services in Greenfield, MA, partnering with local restaurants, cooperative businesses, and western Massachusetts' largest composting facility, Martin's Farm. 

Help us build a just and sustainable business for people coming out of jail, with your generous gift of any amount you can afford. Together we can redefine public safety and replenish the soil.

This worker-owned business rises out of conversations over a number of years between incarcerated people, educators, and local cooperatives and composting experts about what we could do at a local level to deal with the problems we face.

Now our dream is becoming a reality, with our first commercial customers. We will be starting residential food scraps pickups by bicycle in Greenfield later this year. Our goal is to have five part-time worker owners by 2020. To provide service for our commercial customers and generate a sustainable revenue stream, we need a reliable, used truck. We've been borrowing one, and now we're ready to take the plunge and purchase our own.

Help us divert up to 100 tons per year of compostable waste from the landfill as we expand our business.

Why does our project deserve your support?

Having paid our debt to society, people coming out of jail and prison often have nothing. Employers hesitate to hire people with felony convictions. It's hard to find work, especially that pays a living wage. This often pushes people back to old ways of surviving and increases the likelihood of getting caught in the system. We decided to do something about that destructive cycle—by building our own business!

We began with a simple observation: our town doesn't divert residential compostable waste. And we thought, maybe there is a place for us. So we took an economic model for stability in hard times—the worker-owned cooperative—and mixed in our passion for justice, community spirit, and the relationships we have built over years. That's how the Compost Co-operative, an innovative project to create jobs and replenish the soil, came to be. We've started with commercial customers, and plan to begin residential curbside pickups later this year in Greenfield—by bicycle.

At the Compost Co-op we provide a much-needed service, help regenerate topsoil, and create living-wage employment for people who face legalized discrimination and social stigma. We understand the urgent need for all municipalities to divert compostable waste from landfills—and believe that everyone has the potential to rebuild their life through connecting with others.

Until now, we've been hauling with a borrowed truck. After much planning and budgeting, we're ready to purchase our own used vehicle! We also need a lift gate, buckets, safety equipment, and insurance. With a reliable truck, we will be able to take on more customers and expand our business to include two more worker owners this year.

Launching without a large debt hanging over our worker owners will make all the difference to the success of our business. We know this is possible. Our existing customers are valued investors in the community. Our supporters agree that we all deserve a second, third, and even fourth chance—to have access to stability, education, housing, healthcare, and opportunity to address and repair the harms we have caused and to heal from those we have experienced.

By supporting the Compost Co-op, you are participating in a unique effort to address a large social problem in a local and sustainable way. You can feel proud about being part of this project to bring about social change, one bucketful of food scraps at a time.

If we are not able to reach our goal of $10,000 in this campaign, all the funds we raise will go towards the purchase of our truck.

The impact of your gift

It costs more than $50,000 per year to incarcerate someone in Massachusetts. The financial and emotional costs—including for loved ones, especially children of incarcerated parents—extend down the generations. We believe it is unsound fiscal policy to spend that kind of money on incarceration rather than education, economic development, housing, and healthcare.

Each person coming out of jail or prison faces different challenges, from reuniting with family and friends to adjusting to the requirements of probation or parole to lack of access to affordable housing and nourishing food. All of our worker owners will be paid to go through our apprenticeship program, which will prepare them for full ownership and democratic control of the business. Leadership, public speaking, business skills, wellness: these are all skills we cultivate as we replenish the soil.

The Compost Co-op represents a grassroots effort to interrupt the revolving door of incarceration by creating living-wage jobs that people own.

Will owning a business keep someone out of jail? Maybe. Is $10,000 better spent on building a business than incarcerating someone? We think so—and hope you will, too.

The Compost Co-op benefits from the expertise of its developers in many areas: composting, cooperative business development, post-incarceration/reentry, legislation at the state level, media, and storytelling. We have raised awareness in our community about our country's over-reliance on punishment. We believe that the concept of public safety has to include everyone. We have gained the support and trust of local cooperatives and other businesses and institutions in Greenfield and look forward to sharing our progress with others. You can read more about us on our website, www.thecompostcooperative.com

Risks & challenges

Like the tortoise, we move slowly and steadily. It is difficult to capitalize a business with little or no money. It is difficult to rebuild your life after being incarcerated. We are realists and dreamers. Our advisors, many of whom have experienced incarceration, include educators, poets, composting experts, cooperative business owners, and bicycle-powered waste haulers (Pedal People in Northampton, MA, another worker-owned cooperative). Our first worker owner helped develop the business plan while incarcerated.

After 3 years of planning and development, we are finally rolling. We are humbled by the tremendous support we have received from people and institutions in our community, and from cooperatives all over. Yes, there are challenges. Your support gives us the energy to continue despite the odds.

Thank you for taking the time to read about the Compost Co-op!

Many ways to help

We hope you will support us with a donation in any amount you can afford towards the purchase of our truck. You can join our effort to build economic infrastructure with people coming out of jail and prison in many other ways, too, such as:

* donate your used, clean food-grade 5-gallon buckets to the Compost Co-op

* get in touch, share your ideas, and sign up for our newsletter at www.thecompostcooperative.com

* residents of Greenfield: this fall, sign up for our residential curbside pickups

* tell your friends about us

* learn more about composting, incarceration, and cooperative businesses near you!

We are realists and dreamers. Our advisors, many of whom have experienced incarceration, include educators, poets, composting experts, cooperative business owners, and bicycle-powered waste haulers (Pedal People in Northampton, MA, another worker-owned cooperative). Our first worker owner helped develop the business plan while incarcerated.
After 3 years of planning and development, we are finally rolling. We are humbled by the tremendous support we have received from people and institutions in our community, and from cooperatives all over. Yes, there are challenges. Your support gives us the energy to continue despite the odds.
Thank you for taking the time to read about the Compost Co-op!

Many ways to help
We hope you will support us with a donation in any amount you can afford towards the purchase of our truck. You can join our effort to build economic infrastructure with people coming out of jail and prison in many other ways, too, such as:
* donate your used, clean food-grade 5-gallon buckets to the Compost Co-op
* get in touch, share your ideas, and sign up for our newsletter at www.thecompostcooperative.com
* residents of Greenfield: this fall, sign up for our residential curbside pickups
* tell your friends about us
* learn more about composting, incarceration, and cooperative businesses near you!

story:
Forest Founders meets one necessary and universal goal: to help the current state of our planet. Admittedly, “saving the planet” is a pretty overwhelming goal. So, we looked to the best information source available for guidance, planet earth! Trees are the ultimate carbon solution, turning tons of co2 into the oxygen that we need. Every day that consumers, well, consume, the planet suffers tremendously.

 

As a result, we realized that a program to help the planet required individuals coming together to address the current consumption situation head on. So we created a subscription based, carbon accountability plan that plants trees on our subscribers’ behalf. Through Forest Founders, individuals will be able to plant enough trees to negate the average American’s carbon footprint.



 

This campaign is raising funds to bring the Carbon Accountability Plan to life through the creation of a mobile app that, like YouTube, will use marketing to provide a free service to our members. The Forest Founders app will give businesses the opportunity to plant trees on their consumers’ behalf through an environmentally conscientious marketing program. Anyone who downloads the free Forest Founders app will be able to find participating businesses, track the trees they redeem, collect points, and understand how their consumer behavior can change the planet.

 

Take Matters into Your Own Hands

 

It’s true, what Bill Nye said. The planet is on f***ing fire! Forests are burning to the ground, global temperatures are rising, and natural disasters claim endless habitats and homes. We all stand to lose if we do not address our carbon crisis. By subscribing to our Carbon Accountability Plan, you are able to take matters into your own hands and finally become a part of the solution.

 

 

 

We are inspired and humbled by:

 

  • Leonardo Dicaprio and Matt Damon who use their popularity to champion our cause.
  • Scott Harrison who leads by example and shows us the difference one person can make. 
  • Elon Musk who stands up against incredible odds and was willing to sacrifice everything to allow us a better future (and our founder’s personal hero, Jim Chanos need not subscribe...)
  • Bill Nye and Captain Planet for inspiring the generation that will take charge in this fight.
  • Greta Thunberg who proves that even the smallest voices can be incredibly powerful.
  • Our children and future generations that bring the reality of our current situation into shockingly clear focus. Without focused change now there might not be a future for them.
  • Our Mother Earth whose natural beauty and generosity we take for granted daily.
  • And every single person who takes the time to read and understand what we are trying to accomplish and becomes a member or subscriber.

 

Signing up brings Forest Founders closer to our goals. As our membership grows it will be impossible to ignore us. Even if you don’t subscribe with us and pay monthly to negate your carbon footprint, take the first step of becoming a member so we can update you on our progress. Share us with your friends and family to allow us to build our network so when our app is ready we have a large pool of members to force businesses to take us seriously. The more support we have the quicker it will be to convince businesses to rally to our cause. 

 

Without a user base businesses might not feel compelled to do the right thing and plant trees with us. We need to show them that our consumer power is strong and we demand they take the carbon footprint they generate to create profits seriously. This will enable us to reward the businesses that do, and hopefully convince the ones that don’t to change their minds over time. Do you see our vision? Become a member today and sign up with us at forestfounders.org. Channel your inner Gandhi and “Be the change that you wish to see in the world.”

 

How it Works

 

 

 

The Carbon Accountability Plan is a subscription based model that plants trees and rewards points to Forest Founders members. Using the Forest Founders member dashboard, subscribers can:

 

  • Use points for Forest Founders merchandise
  • Spend points on planting extra trees
  • Track their tree planting progress
  • Get Forest Founders resources and news

 

Our members are encouraged to share our program! Any referral will result in bonus points and extra trees planted. Your personal profile page will keep track of the trees you plant, manage your rewards points, and create an easy way to invite friends and share our program online.

 

 "The best time to plant a tree was twenty years ago, the second best time is now!"

- Chinese Proverb

 

Forest Founders for Businesses

 

With the development of the Forest Founders App, we will be able to develop more solutions for users to help the planet using the devices in their pockets. In order for this to work we need to engage businesses to lead the charge. Climate change isn’t a result of just one person’s commute to work. It’s more than that, and if we can get businesses on board to join our mission, we can maximize our efforts to the fullest. 

 

Businesses that join us can manage promotions in a way that both help the planet and also brings in new, unique customers who share their values. Through the Forest Founders app, businesses will be able to get in front of the sustainably conscientious audience they’ve been looking for. Most importantly, consumers know they’re purchasing products or services from a business that cares about our planet, and takes action to be carbon accountable. The app will interact with our website’s member profile page and points and progress will be tracked.

 

 

Here are some examples of business promotions that can be run through the app:

 

  • Restaurants can promote a “Green Meal of The Day” that plants trees when purchased.
  • Fitness gyms can promote a “Go Green and Get Fit” campaign that plants a tree for  members on a monthly basis.
  • Retail stores can plant trees for members who pick up in-store to reduce shipping needs while also advertising in store promotions. “Sustainable Saturday, 10% off and plant one tree for all in-store purchases”.

 

The Forest Founders app will use geo-location, QR codes, and direct email tree invites to provide customer satisfaction and security. Elegant and simple, the back-end of the app allows for businesses to have ultimate control over the campaigns they create, managing margins and giving  Forest Founders the flexibility to work with almost every type of business.

 

The app will be developed with React Native so both iOS and Android users can contribute to the cause. We will connect Forest Founders Web App existing database so our members can earn points and rewards through their online profile while collecting trees at participating businesses.

 

Forest Founders Partners

The National Forest Foundation & Trees For The Future

 

​

 

 

 

 

Each month we will use your contributions to plant trees on your behalf through our partner, the National Forest Foundation, the nonprofit arm of the US Forest Service. Our native trees are planted exclusively in US National Forests across the country. Trees are planted only in optimal planting conditions to allow for best growth practices by experienced tree planting specialists. We also plant trees through Trees For The Future in agro-forestry projects across Africa.

 

INDIEGOGO Perks

 

Every perk we offer to our backers will help fund the development of our mobile app. We also offer a unique package that can be purchased to enhance your subscription tier. The tier 4 perk will allow you to subscribe at a higher reward point multiplier to earn points more quickly. Points can be spent either on our exclusive merchandise or to plant more trees.

 

Part of the proceeds from this fundraising will also be used to subsidize our rewards program and offer exciting, exclusive rewards you can only get by selecting the Founding Member perk. We will also create a section on our website to acknowledge our Founding Members and thank them for their generosity. Become a Founding Member of Forest Founders and help us, help you, help the planet. 

 

The Carbon Accountability Plan is a way to inspire people to take stock in the health of our planet. A little difference can go a long way when a massive community of people join forces for one cause. We want to hear your ideas and let donors give their active input to grow Forest Founders to its true potential. Supporting this campaign will allow us to build stronger programs and subsidize our rewards program to better reward our members' environmentalism.

 

Join Us!

 

Help us heal our planet. Subscribe to our Carbon Accountability Plan on forestfounders.org to donate $20 on a monthly basis and use our app to connect with businesses that will plant extra trees.

 

  • The money we spend daily builds our carbon footprint.
  • Every dollar we spend can somehow be linked to carbon emissions. 
  • Every product we buy has an environmental cost. 
  • Globalisation has created a carbon problem the likes of which have never been seen.
  • Even organic produce needs to be transported on trucks. 
  • Becoming a vegetarian will only result in a 40% reduction of your carbon footprint.
  • Changing to LED light bulbs and taking shorter showers barely reduce one’s carbon footprint.

 

We have a solution, and it only costs $20 a month, less than the cost of a tank of gas (a little more than netflix…). We need to become the change we want to see. Become a member and subscribe today. Go to forestfounders.org to start your journey and begin planting your forest. Our future depends on it.

 

TL;DR - Forest Founders is a non-profit organization with the mission of carbon accountability. Tree planting is one of the single best ways available to help negate our carbon footprint on this earth. We plant trees, we want to build an app, and we need your help.

story:
I am deeply grateful to the experiences that led to this project, they opened me to the world as a whole and offered me prodigious sense of belonging to humanity rather than one geographical region. I found myself useful to serve humankind and the earth in such ways that I could find meaning and inspiration. Therefore, I feel a profound need to give back whilst discovering the ancient indigenous knowledge with therapeutic potential of shamanic diets and master healers.  I am offering my skill, experience, outreach and most importantly myself as a research subject. The research will start in the November of 2019 and will potentially continue for 18 months. 

With the community permissions am going to develop a thorough on-line presence of my project through daily live updates from the community life on Instagram, as well as keep a detailed diary blog, both of these will become the main resource for my research and are currently under construction. Yet the most exciting product is series of short documentaries, that I am planning to work on the go. I will be able to talk about community benefit more when I find hosts and have a change to understand what they need from their perspective as well.

The budget for the trip is around $8,000 USD see the cost breakdown below (not including Indiegogo fees), the trip will be built depending on the raised amount. ANY FUNDS RAISED ON TOP OF THIS, WILL BE DONATED DIRECTLY BACK TO THE COMMUNITY NEEDS.

Read more about the struggles of indiginous people in Amazon.

***

Hi all! Thank you for giving your time to this crowdfunding campaign! 

My name is Hamida, 27 and I am a practicing Peace & Conflict worker from Baku, Azerbaijan with a thorough training in holistic approaches to peace and considerable experience in human rights advocacy. Majority of my career I have been occupied with understanding the importance of self-regulating intentional communities across the globe and the potential it has for the societies of the modern world, as well as designing spaces for multi-format dialogues within and between societies. Great deal of my training and practice originates from the context of Nagorno-Karabakh Conflict and UNESCO Chair for Peace Studies MA  Program at the University of Innsbruck, Austria. Currently, I work with Imagine Center for Conflict Transformation where I lead the initiatives in Azerbaijan as well as offer services of independent facilitator, trainer and consultant. Imagine is very special for me in particular because I believe that, structures forming communities has potential for healthy and inclusive coexistence.

I am from a small Post-Soviet country situated on a shore of Caspian Sea at the feet of Great Caucasus mountains. For about 30 years now the region I am from have been involved into violent conflicts due to various political and not reasons. Since I am 18 I have been invested into peaceful transformation of the societies living in this authentically beautiful and diverse area, which included not only reconciliation of conflict-torn societies, yet also profound activism in the areas of human rights, social healing, environment,  and gender. However beyond all of these strong words I find it crucial to dig deeper into reasons why chose peacebuilding. 

 In order to understand my motivation of learning from Amazon communities, it would be a huge overlook not to mention all the personal incentives of why I have been following these themes for so long and how I see this journey as indispensable for my healing. As much as I look happy on all of the pictures, I have been struggling with heavy depression connected to several PTSDs followed by continuous physical and emotional abuse, discrimination, assault, harassment, suicide and rape attempt for most of my life. In some of the cases my family members have been the reason for these painful experiences, in some, the society transitioning from authoritative communism to a new form of  statehood followed by a wave of nationalism and traumas of war. 

Peacebuilding have not been just a career for me, over these years it became my life, my therapy, which extended beyond my own ego, into the community I wanted to belong without forcing myself to adjust. Thanks to everything I experienced through my work, by the age of 27 I have learned to prevent the traumatic events and survival patterns from manipulating my life, now I own the experience not vice versa. Yet above all, I am grateful for it opened me to the world as a whole and offered me prodigious sense of  belonging to humanity rather than one geographical region, where I found myself useful to serve humankind and the earth in such ways that I could find meaning and inspiration. A great example of this phenomena is my volunteering experience during Syrian refugee crisis where I used to provide humanitarian aid at a small camp in Austria.

For my transformational journey I own a big deal of gratitude to MA Program in Peace Studies at the University of Innsbruck where I was introduced to the concept of holistic peace, that integrates the knowledge of many ancient philosophies and traditions across the world. I have started learning through many different experiences of healing via altered state of consciousness, for instance Holotropic Breathwork, 5Rhythms Dance, Quantum Light Breath, Shamanic journeys etc., which in its turn have bestowed mental, emotional, and spiritual development for myself. After my masters I have had a chance to spend 8 months on several organic vegetable farms in Virginia and Maryland, USA. Before this experience I have never thought on a serious basis how significant and most importantly how physically hard and unappreciated farming is, I have spent probably one of the most challenging 8 months of my life on this soil in a team of wonderful people, so dedicated to and in love with nature and environment.

Picking potatoes at Potomac Vegetable Farms 2016. 

While I was living in a small forest tree house,  listening to cicadas mating at nights, and breaking down my body over caring after the fruits the fertile soil was ceaselessly producing during the day, an obscure bond with the earth was germinating inside of me. I found out later during an intensely healing Ayahuasca retreat from an intentional community Amoraleza in Spain, that it was the connection to the great mother of all with its unconditional divine love. It is exactly when I knew I have to go to the Amazon forest and serve it for it has given me the greatest gifts of all, self-love. It has given me the healing, which years of drugs and therapy would not. I see an exceptional purpose in the call that I have and I wish the community that I am reaching out to support me in my purpose and maybe, just maybe I will find more healing for myself and more people in this challenged world we have today. 

Hopefully with the help of the universe, I am planning to visit several communities across the Amazon, where I can live and work along with the indigenous people, that are taking care of the forest and follow the traditions of Shamanism. I am trained in Basic Universal Shamanism, Indigenous survival techniques, and Universal spiritual Practices, so in a sense I feel like I have the basics for the journey. I want to learn the ancient knowledge that will result in a research, as well as unfold my true self more than ever. I don’t have any money to fulfill this dream therefore I am looking for support from all over the world. I am planning to start my journey already this November, but I will continuously crowdfund so I can build the trip on the go. Please see the budget for the trip below if you are wondering how I am planning to spend the gathered sources. 

Plan of the trip 

Since my nationality offers me certain limitations on my journey, I am building my plan according to the travel and visa regulations of the Amazon states. In case I will find a way to legally stay longer I will certainly take the opportunity to engage with community life on continuous basis.

Brazil 3-6 Months (travel visa 3 months, renewable); Bolivia 3 Months (maximum); Ecuador 3 Months (maximum); Colombia 3-6 Months (travel visa 3 months, renewable) .

Be aware that any funds raised on the top of the goal will be donated to the community needs. I frankly do not know what future holds for me, I am preparing myself for anything. For example if I will manage to crowdfund only for one trip I will visit one community and stay there as much as possible, and the remaining funds will be donated. I promise to update the donating community on a constant basis, sharing the life in Amazon as much as possible through variety of social media platforms, which also means raising the awareness and advocacy about the local issues.

Skills I am offering

Here is brief overview of most relevant skills and training I have gathered throughout these years, which I am offering to the communities upon their need including some reference: 

Networking, Campaigning, Advocacy, Conflict Resolution and Conflict Transformation, Non formal Education, Confidence and Capacity building; Monitoring Assemblies  (OSCE/ODIHR), Human Rights (Council of Europe), Video and Photo Journalism, Film Directing  (Internews Azerbaijan), Political Analysis and Risk Assessment (Peace Brigades International), Sustainable Development and Permaculture (Potomac Vegetable Farms), Conflict specific First Aid and Immediate life-saving measures (Austrian Red Cross); Peace Support Operations, Security Awareness, Negotiation Techniques, Coordination and Organization of small field units, Stress management, Public and Press Relations, Humanitarian Aid Delivery (Austrian Armed Forces Military Command of the Tyrol), Water Rescue (Tyrolean Water Rescue Team).

Current Stage and Needs

Currently I am establishing contacts at my first destination in Brazil and slowly learning Portuguese. Before I leave for such a tough journey, I am also planning to take several months of Aikido course in order to straighten my self defense skills. I am in a big need for promotion support and PR strategy for finding potential investors as well as building the audience for the project.

 I really hope I will be able to make this journey happen and invest my soul into the people of our planet’s only functional lungs. Please feel free to contact me over my campaign e-mail florestasagrada2019@gmail.com if you have any more questions, or concerns, or suggestions on destinations and communities to visit, seriously any help is very much appreciated. 

Thank you for everything no matter who you are. 

Here is a short multimedia story where you can read more about me and work the Imagine Center does in English on Chai-Khana.  

And an article in Azerbaijani on Meydan TV

Before this experience I have never thought on a serious basis how significant and most importantly how physically hard and unappreciated farming is, I have spent probably one of the most challenging 8 months of my life on this soil in a team of wonderful people, so dedicated to and in love with nature and environment.Picking potatoes at Potomac Vegetable Farms 2016. While I was living in a small forest tree house,  listening to cicadas mating at nights, and breaking down my body over caring after the fruits the fertile soil was ceaselessly producing during the day, an obscure bond with the earth was germinating inside of me. I found out later during an intensely healing Ayahuasca retreat from an intentional community Amoraleza in Spain, that it was the connection to the great mother of all with its unconditional divine love. It is exactly when I knew I have to go to the Amazon forest and serve it for it has given me the greatest gifts of all, self-love. It has given me the healing, which years of drugs and therapy would not. I see an exceptional purpose in the call that I have and I wish the community that I am reaching out to support me in my purpose and maybe, just maybe I will find more healing for myself and more people in this challenged world we have today. Hopefully with the help of the universe, I am planning to visit several communities across the Amazon, where I can live and work along with the indigenous people, that are taking care of the forest and follow the traditions of Shamanism. I am trained in Basic Universal Shamanism, Indigenous survival techniques, and Universal spiritual Practices, so in a sense I feel like I have the basics for the journey. I want to learn the ancient knowledge that will result in a research, as well as unfold my true self more than ever. I don’t have any money to fulfill this dream therefore I am looking for support from all over the world. I am planning to start my journey already this November, but I will continuously crowdfund so I can build the trip on the go. Please see the budget for the trip below if you are wondering how I am planning to spend the gathered sources. Plan of the trip Since my nationality offers me certain limitations on my journey, I am building my plan according to the travel and visa regulations of the Amazon states. In case I will find a way to legally stay longer I will certainly take the opportunity to engage with community life on continuous basis.Brazil 3-6 Months (travel visa 3 months, renewable); Bolivia 3 Months (maximum); Ecuador 3 Months (maximum); Colombia 3-6 Months (travel visa 3 months, renewable) .Be aware that any funds raised on the top of the goal will be donated to the community needs. I frankly do not know what future holds for me, I am preparing myself for anything. For example if I will manage to crowdfund only for one trip I will visit one community and stay there as much as possible, and the remaining funds will be donated. I promise to update the donating community on a constant basis, sharing the life in Amazon as much as possible through variety of social media platforms, which also means raising the awareness and advocacy about the local issues.Skills I am offeringHere is brief overview of most relevant skills and training I have gathered throughout these years, which I am offering to the communities upon their need including some reference: Networking, Campaigning, Advocacy, Conflict Resolution and Conflict Transformation, Non formal Education, Confidence and Capacity building; Monitoring Assemblies  (OSCE/ODIHR), Human Rights (Council of Europe), Video and Photo Journalism, Film Directing  (Internews Azerbaijan), Political Analysis and Risk Assessment (Peace Brigades International), Sustainable Development and Permaculture (Potomac Vegetable Farms), Conflict specific First Aid and Immediate life-saving measures (Austrian Red Cross); Peace Support Operations, Security Awareness, Negotiation Techniques, Coordination and Organization of small field units, Stress management, Public and Press Relations, Humanitarian Aid Delivery (Austrian Armed Forces Military Command of the Tyrol), Water Rescue (Tyrolean Water Rescue Team).Current Stage and NeedsCurrently I am establishing contacts at my first destination in Brazil and slowly learning Portuguese. Before I leave for such a tough journey, I am also planning to take several months of Aikido course in order to straighten my self defense skills. I am in a big need for promotion support and PR strategy for finding potential investors as well as building the audience for the project. I really hope I will be able to make this journey happen and invest my soul into the people of our planet’s only functional lungs. Please feel free to contact me over my campaign e-mail florestasagrada2019@gmail.com if you have any more questions, or concerns, or suggestions on destinations and communities to visit, seriously any help is very much appreciated. Thank you for everything no matter who you are. Here is a short multimedia story where you can read more about me and work the Imagine Center does in English on Chai-Khana.  And an article in Azerbaijani on Meydan TV

story:
My name is Myra and I would like to warmly welcome you to my Cycle 2 Recycle crowdfunding campaign! Cycle 2 Recycle is a project I have set up out of pure optimism, idealism, and out of the need and willingness to take action and make a difference for our beloved planet.

I was born and raised in the Netherlands but I have been living in Italy since 2012. In the past few years I have embarked on two solo bike tours through Europe, during which I was simply appalled by the huge amount of plastic waste that I found basically everywhere around me: plastic bottles and wraps just left there by previous visitors who cared more for their perfect selfie instead of the environment that hosted them, and equally disturbing amounts of plastic thrown away onto the roadside by car drivers and road cyclists.

Ideally I wanted to pick up this plastic and leave it at recycling or waste collecting stations, but my fully-packed bike simply didn't allow me to. This summer of 2019 however the game changes! I have decided to combine my passion for cycling with my passion for the environment, and that's how Cycle 2 Recycle was born.

On the 29th of June I will depart from Turin in Italy with a very pink & very big and heavy cargo bike, crossing the Swiss Alps and then into Germany towards the Moselle Valley. I will be collecting as much plastic waste as possible from the roadside, and bring it to recycling and waste collecting stations along the itinerary. After a break in the Moselle Valley I will then cycle all the way back again towards Turin, but along a different route.

With this initiative I hope to raise more awareness about the plastic problem, inspire people to stop using disposable plastics and to show that if we really want to, we can all contribute in our very own way. And with your help, I plan to continue fighting plastic pollution one bike trip at a time!

 

How Can You Help & What You Get In Return

My main goal is and always remains to create more awareness about the plastic problem and to inspire people to stop using disposable plastics. So one of the best ways you can help me is to share my project with your friends, family, colleagues, and everybody else who you think is receptive to the initiative.

However, if this summer's Cycle 2 Recycle adventure goes well, I would like to expand the project into a bigger network and start new initiatives, involving local communities as well. And in order to make this happen, and to make Cycle 2 Recycle grow into a proper non-profit project, I need your help and your donations!
By donating to my campaign you will make it possible for me to collect plastic waste this summer and more importantly, you will help me in continuing to do so in the future!
On my website www.cycle2recycle.org you will be able to track my progress and see how many kilos of plastic I have already collected and how many kilometers I have already cycled.

What do you get?

I have teamed up with some really cool suppliers to provide my backers with fun, useful, and eco-friendly perks.

Backers will be able to obtain the official Cycle 2 Recycle t-shirt, a Cycle 2 Recycle canvas tote bag available in five different colors, and for the real adventurers it will be even possible to become the proud owner of a cargo bike similar to the one I will be using this summer to collect all the plastic!

Companies with donations of €1000 or over will have their logo featured as official sponsor on the Cycle 2 Recycle website.

 

The Impact

Cycle 2 Recycle is an initiative that shows that everybody can make a difference to try to make the world a better place. Initiatives like these don't necessarily have to start on a huge, global scale; making changes in smaller local communities is equally important.

By contributing to Cycle 2 Recycle you will support a small-sized, yet very passionate initiative aimed at making people more aware about the huge plastic problem and inspiring them to stop using disposable plastics.
The fact that I will be cycling all the way from Italy to Germany, passing over the Swiss Alps with a pretty heavy cargo bike while collecting plastic waste left there by others, hopefully helps others to see and understand the lengths (literally!) I am prepared to go through to get this important message across.

 

Risks & Challenges

To be completely honest, I don't foresee any major challenges or obstacles during the big adventure. The worst that could happen is a flat tire, worn down brake pads, a major downpour on my way up the Alps, or I could get sick along the way. However, having embarked on other bike trips in the past I can assure you that these things are all surmountable and I see no reason whatsoever why they would put my bike trip in danger. As I mentioned before, optimism and idealism are in my blood so I will persevere with my head held high!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I said this before but I will say it again: my main goal is to raise awareness about the plastic problem and to inspire people to stop using single-use plastics. With the right information, education, and tools I am convinced this is something we can achieve by working together. So if you don't have the means to contribute with a donation, please help me spread the word about Cycle 2 Recycle!

You can use the sharing tools here on Indiegogo, go to my website www.cycle2recycle.org, or start following me on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter.

You can also contact me at info@cycle2recycle.org

story:
Short Summary

Hello, Davy Rothbart and James Molenda here! We're the editors of FOUND Magazine, and each summer – with the generous help of friends like you – we put together a camping trip for kids from the city called Washington to Washington. Thank you so much for checking out the short video above, and contributing what you can to help this summer's trip come to life!

Washington to Washington is an annual outdoors adventure bringing kids from Washington, D.C., Southeast Michigan (Detroit area), and New Orleans on a week-long camping and hiking trip to explore some of the country's most incredible wilderness areas. Along the way, these kids will hike up a mountain, walk through beautiful forests, see animals they didn't know existed, swim, canoe, and fish in pristine lakes and rivers, eat new foods, ride horses, watch the Perseid meteor shower, make S’mores and tell ghost stories around a campfire, learn camping and wilderness skills, and explore the Great Outdoors!

In recent years, our campers have had a blast in places like the Grayson Highlands in SW Virginia, where we hiked amongst wild ponies, heifers and bulls on breathtaking Mount Rogers (one of the highest peaks in the Eastern U.S.) and, last year, we swam in Lake Moomaw in Virginia's George Washington National Forest, in the heart of the Appalachian Mountains. This year, we'll be heading to Sleeping Bear Dunes in northern Michigan and hiking the stunning Empire Dunes!

The trip was inspired by our friendship with D.C. native Emmanuel Durant, Jr. After his tragic death on New Year's Eve, 2009, we teamed up with Emmanuel's family to create these annual trips as a way to introduce city kids to the magic of nature, broaden perspectives, and pay tribute to Emmanuel.

What We Need & What You Get

We have 54 wonderful, deserving kids who are excited to go camping and hiking this summer, but we would love to raise $50,000 by July 30th in order to make the trip happen. Our trips are run entirely by volunteers, so please know that 100% of your donation goes toward covering the hard costs of bringing these kids on the trip — food, gas, transportation, camping gear, etc.

Honestly, the biggest reward you'll receive from contributing is the knowledge that you've helped some awesome kids get out into nature — many for the first time in their lives — and have some new, life-enriching experiences. That said, we'll also be sending out photos of the trip, handmade Thank You cards, and all kinds of other special prizes to those who offer support. Check out the full range of Perks listed to the right.  Have a special Perks request that we didn't include?  Don't hesitate to email us and ask!

The Impact

Our trips have no specific agenda — we seek only to introduce kids who have rarely left D.C., Detroit and New Orleans (or even their own neighborhoods) to the joys of nature and wilderness hiking and give them a chance to experience something brand-new and have an exciting adventure.  On past Washington to Washington hikes, we trip leaders have seen that look of accomplishment and inspiration that fills the kids' faces when we've reached the top of a mountain.  It's amazing! You can check out photo galleries of our 2011 - 2018 trips to get a sense for just how special our Washington to Washington trips seem to be to these kids. And, here's a short, lovely video featuring camper David on his first trip in 2014 (he's a camper who has returned every year since).

Other Ways You Can Help

Besides contributing financially, there are other ways that you can help us make our 10th Annual Washington to Washington trip a reality:

- Email links to this IndieGoGo fundraising page and our Washington to Washington website to your family and friends. The URLs are below.

- Help us spread the word! Post links to this fundraising page and our Washington to Washington site on Facebook and Twitter. This makes an absolutely HUGE difference! The more people who learn about the trip, the better chance we have of raising the funds we need.

- Donate gear! We are always in need of tents, sleeping bags, flashlights, and other camping and hiking supplies. To arrange a contribution of this kind, email us at WashingtonToWashington@gmail.com.

So, please help us distribute these URLs and get the word out!

W2W IndieGoGo Fundraising Page short-link: https://igg.me/at/w2w19/x#/

W2W Official Site: http://www.washingtontowashington.org/ 

Thank you so much for your support — it is hugely appreciated!

Much love & respect,

Davy, James, Margaret, Pat, Joshua, Nina, Barry, Ryan, Brandon, Avery, Nat, Hillary, Sam, Laura, Ethan, Lopez, Jason, Shawn, Hakim, Paul, Tom, Angela, Tim, Crystal, Zach, Callie, Maggie, Emily, Hannah, Ellyn, Denice, Smurf, Anna, Talisha, Biju, Sierra, Mark, Katie, and the entire Washington to Washington crew.

Questions? Email us at WashingtonToWashington@gmail.com

All photos courtesy of the fantastic Callie Giovanna
