story:
Short Summary

Trying to go waste-free in 2018 London is still a daily challenge but we are convinced it doesn’t have to be. With Zéro, we want to make it easy for everyone to embark on the Zero Waste journey. Our shop will offer a simple alternative to excessive single-use packaging consumption with a wide range of ready-to-go bulk items. We want people to consider our shop as an alternative to supermarkets where they can source local, organic and FairTrade products without the unnecessary packaging.

With our passion for environmental issues and our combined experience in sales and retail (Josh) and business operations and finance (Alicia), we are convinced we have the knowledge and skills necessary to make Zéro a successful venture. 

By funding this project, you will make it possible for Zéro to become Londoners’ new favourite grocery shop and give us the first push to make this happen. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to raise at least £20,000 to cover the initial investment, including shop set-up and initial inventory. To keep the business stocked up for the first 3 months we will need around £11,200 and extra £8,800 will be used to refurbish the shop and acquire the food dispensers (gravity dispensers, jars, scoops etc.). 

We have some amazing perks available! Discounts, Zero Waste shopping kits, special mentions on our shop ‘thank you’ mural, VIP launch invites… you name it! All Zero Waste, of course. 

If we don't reach the entire goal, the funds will go in priority towards the initial inventory as having great quality products is of paramount importance to us. The rest will be invested in the premises and equipment (possibly with a bank loan). 

The Impact

Zero Waste shops offer a sustainable shopping option to mindful customers who are not satisfied with the current standards of the food retail industry. They are the answer to the increasing demand for more sustainable practices in supermarkets and local food stores and present a satisfying alternative for grocery shopping. 

For many products, zero packaging represents a perfectly viable and more sustainable packaging solution than plastic. Many fresh foods are naturally wrapped in their own skin and, under the right conditions, can be safely transported and consumed without single-use plastic packaging. Traditional farmers’ markets are common across Europe and in particular across the UK, many of which operate with low levels of packaging, selling fruits and vegetables loose, and meat and dairy products in paper. As well as traditional markets, a growing number of European food retailers are now renouncing packaging. Just like traditional grocery shops, package-free, or ‘Zero Waste’ shops sell loose produce and promote the use of reusable containers.

Beyond the obvious environmental benefits of cutting down the use of unwanted packaging, Zero Waste shops are also a great way to reduce food waste and to save on household expenses. By enabling their customers to purchase the exact quantity of goods they require, Zero Waste shopping makes it easier to tailor consumption to people’s real needs and to manage expenses. 

In a nutshell, Zero Waste shops bring the perfect solution to both the packaging and food waste issues that plague the food industry in Western countries. Over the last few years, such shops have been flourishing across Europe and the USA and consumers have welcomed very favourably these new shopping facilities which offer a sustainable alternative to slow-moving big retail chains. 

Example of other successful Zero Waste Shops: 

  • Earth.Food.Love - Zero Waste Shop in Totnes, Devon
  • Hetu - Zero Waste Shop in Battersea, London
  • Negozio Leggero - network of Zero Waste shops in Italy
  •  …

Risks & Challenges

Some of the risks and obstacles we may face on the way to achieving our goal and how we plan to overcome them: 

  • Need to build a strong consumers basis: as a new independent shop, we will have to make ourselves known to the public, which might be challenging at the start. This will require a strong marketing strategy with a mix of impactful media content, and promotional events. 
  • Need to educate the consumer: As the concept of Zero Waste shops is still new, there will be an important educational effort to make to explain the idea and the way the shop works to the public. According to a study from Euromonitor, “the main barriers to buying green products are availability and knowledge” (2013). We have started to write a blog (available on our website) to write about the zero waste lifestyle and the shop. We also plan to organise workshops on a regular basis to help our customers find new ways to achieve zero waste in their lives. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute, but enjoyed reading about our project and believe in our Zero Waste ideal:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools! Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, email, telephone, WhatsApp. 

Thank you for your support!

Alicia and Josh

We have started to write a blog (available on our website) to write about the zero waste lifestyle and the shop. We also plan to organise workshops on a regular basis to help our customers find new ways to achieve zero waste in their lives. 


Other Ways You Can Help
If you just can't contribute, but enjoyed reading about our project and believe in our Zero Waste ideal:

Help us get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools! Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, email, telephone, WhatsApp. 

Thank you for your support!
Alicia and Josh

story:
The symposium will allow students and professionals to publicize their work and the most important thing is that we can have updated information about the species in different parts of the country. In the last four years there have been several deaths of Andean bears, which greatly affect the populations that are delimited in small fractions of Colombian territory.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Zhz9_naVTU

In this academic event, we will be able to socialize all the updated information on the species and allow the environmental authorities of the country to update and define the protection and conservation measures of an important species for all Colombians and reduce between the communities and the Andean bear.

The funds that we raise through this campaign will allow us to obtain the speakers we want to present at the symposium and in this way interact with them, know their work and see how to articulate actions that allow us to improve our implementation of actions. or activities for the conservation of the Andean bear in Colombia and this way little by little we will achieve that our phrase: "Bear land, land of people, land of all" can be a real fact in which rural and urban communities learn to live. Harmony with wildlife.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CQX13jEzVZE

The funds raised will be used to pay the expenses of the exhibitors and the members of the monitoring groups (who are farmers who, on their own initiative, monitor biodiversity, especially threatened species such as the Andean bear and the tapir).

 

For us it will be very important your support and, above all, for the survival of the Andean bear in Colombia.

story:
What's the big deal?

Plastic is pollution from the moment it is made. It has been documented from the depths of the ocean floor, to the height of Mt. Everest, and in lakes, streams, rivers, storm drains, wetlands, arctic sea ice, beaches, oceans, tap water, bottled water, in the air we breathe, in the intestines of all ocean life (from plankton to whales), sea birds, the fish on people's plates, and in the salt used to season it.

There is no recycling our way out of this: It's time to stop making, and buying disposable products, made out of materials that last forever.

Our focus on school supplies is precisely because of the prescriptive nature of Back-to-School shopping.  Students are issued long lists of forever-garbage supplies to purchase, with no place to turn for waste-free options. 

Until now.

We need your help.

Over the past few years, we've done the research, partnered with schools, worked with students, conducted end-of-year "locker-clean-outs," developed zero-waste programs, curated a comprehensive zero-waste school supply assortment, designed our own products, set up a warehouse, received endorsements from Surfrider, 5 Gyres, and Plastic Pollution Coalition, joined 1% For the Planet, submitted for final round B-Corp Certification, and launched a website with custom built functionality to help teachers and parents draw down waste in meaningful ways in their schools.  

We've bootstrapped Wisdom Supply Co. to date, and before we reach out to investors for help to scale our efforts and expand our reach, we're asking for a boost from friends, friends-yet-to-be, family, peers, and people sick of plastic pollution.  Your generous support will allow us to responsibly grow this company to the next level.

We're looking to raise $75,000 to:

Onboard 2 New Team Members  We have an increasing number of moving parts these days, and we want those parts to operate smoothly so we can keep at the work of preventing waste.  We also need help forecasting our multi-channel product flow in order to continue delivering where and when we say we will. We'd also like to officially market our products and services to include businesses and offices (requests are frequent).

Complete the next phase of product development of our 100% Plastic-Free Recyclable Glue Stick.  This is extremely exciting, because for decades now, thousands of tons of plastic glue sticks + bottles have been/are being sent to landfill every year.  This is madness, and we've come up with an authentically recyclable solution we're eager to bring to market.

Our adhesive uses only 100% Natural + Organic ingredients, and will be submitted for Made Safe Certification, because we strongly believe those profiting from the sale of their product, should not be the ones to tell you their product is safe.

We're sweating the details down to the aluminum cap:

 

 

Given what we know about small pieces of plastic, and how easily they are ingested by wildlife,

we knew we couldn't cap our adhesive with plastic.  So "Keep the Cap" was born: a 4-Function aluminum cap:

  1. Puncture - The bottom of the cap has a puncture point for opening the aluminum seal.
  2. Seal - Twist it on the opened product like a regular cap.
  3. Stand - The cap also functions as a stand, so the product can be stored upright.
  4. Re-use - Why recycle something that is just as easily kept and reused? (especially since keeping + reusing the cap keeps costs down for cap-less refills)  

 

When you buy a glue stick, the bulk of what you're getting is plastic packaging that will exist on the planet forever.

When you buy Wisdom Supply Co. Zero-Waste Paste, nothing goes to waste, with 100% recyclable aluminum packaging, and 100% all natural and organic ingredients to boot.

Packaging our product in an airtight, aluminum tube, minimizes the need for all-natural preservatives, since very little of the product is exposed to air before use.

 

 

Place Orders for 2020 Zero-Waste Weekly Planners

We worked with our local municipal waste haulers to design a 100% Recyclable (cover-to-cover) weekly planner, because everything else on the market was destined for landfill.

What Wisdom Supply Co. planners do NOT have, are components that turn them into landfill:

  • Spiral Binding (plastic or metal)
  • Plastic Tabs
  • Lamination
  • Elastic Bands / Ribbons
  • Book-Style Covers
  • Synthetic Material Covers

Landfill, landfill + landfill:

 

*Our 2019 Zero-Waste Weekly Planners have been extremely well received, both online + retail.

Due to the number of requests, we're working on a new version designed specifically for teachers.

 

Our Impact

Every time you choose Wisdom Supply Co. school supplies, you're preventing everlasting plastic and vinyl from becoming pollution. It's a vote for true sustainability, and for companies built from the ground up to do well (+ good) in the world. 

It is our belief that it's irresponsible to continue to tell our children they should care about the planet, while repeatedly filling their backpacks and desks with disposable products, year after year.

With your help, Wisdom Supply Co. can scale the reduction of waste, expand our reach, and increase our impact; together preventing tons of plastic and vinyl from entering the waste stream.

 

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge is staffing in order to be nimble enough to respond to sudden shifts in demand.

Ours is a unique model, in that every time we onboard on a new customer (school or a teacher), there's a consulting component, followed by potentially hundreds of orders at one time. This requires us to establish efficient fulfillment systems, and to coordinate response strategies well in advance.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Forwarding this campaign to friends and groups concerned about plastic pollution, and conservation in general will be a HUGE help.

THANK YOU FOR SHARING

 

SPECIAL NOTE ABOUT REWARDS FOR SCHOOLS:

*If you are gifting a reward to a teacher or school, we are happy to send them a message now, informing them that they will be receiving their new zero-waste classroom supplies in August.

If you want them to receive the supplies NOW, send us an email and we'll work it out!

Thank you!

Heather + Nikki
story_txt:
What's the big deal?
Plastic is pollution from the moment it is made. It has been documented from the depths of the ocean floor, to the height of Mt. Everest, and in lakes, streams, rivers, storm drains, wetlands, arctic sea ice, beaches, oceans, tap water, bottled water, in the air we breathe, in the intestines of all ocean life (from plankton to whales), sea birds, the fish on people's plates, and in the salt used to season it.

There is no recycling our way out of this: It's time to stop making, and buying disposable products, made out of materials that last forever.
Our focus on school supplies is precisely because of the prescriptive nature of Back-to-School shopping.  Students are issued long lists of forever-garbage supplies to purchase, with no place to turn for waste-free options. 
Until now.

We need your help.
Over the past few years, we've done the research, partnered with schools, worked with students, conducted end-of-year "locker-clean-outs," developed zero-waste programs, curated a comprehensive zero-waste school supply assortment, designed our own products, set up a warehouse, received endorsements from Surfrider, 5 Gyres, and Plastic Pollution Coalition, joined 1% For the Planet, submitted for final round B-Corp Certification, and launched a website with custom built functionality to help teachers and parents draw down waste in meaningful ways in their schools.  

We've bootstrapped Wisdom Supply Co. to date, and before we reach out to investors for help to scale our efforts and expand our reach, we're asking for a boost from friends, friends-yet-to-be, family, peers, and people sick of plastic pollution.  Your generous support will allow us to responsibly grow this company to the next level.
We're looking to raise $75,000 to:
Onboard 2 New Team Members  We have an increasing number of moving parts these days, and we want those parts to operate smoothly so we can keep at the work of preventing waste.  We also need help forecasting our multi-channel product flow in order to continue delivering where and when we say we will. We'd also like to officially market our products and services to include businesses and offices (requests are frequent).
Complete the next phase of product development of our 100% Plastic-Free Recyclable Glue Stick.  This is extremely exciting, because for decades now, thousands of tons of plastic glue sticks + bottles have been/are being sent to landfill every year.  This is madness, and we've come up with an authentically recyclable solution we're eager to bring to market.
Our adhesive uses only 100% Natural + Organic ingredients, and will be submitted for Made Safe Certification, because we strongly believe those profiting from the sale of their product, should not be the ones to tell you their product is safe.
We're sweating the details down to the aluminum cap:

 
 
Given what we know about small pieces of plastic, and how easily they are ingested by wildlife,

we knew we couldn't cap our adhesive with plastic.  So "Keep the Cap" was born: a 4-Function aluminum cap:


Puncture - The bottom of the cap has a puncture point for opening the aluminum seal.

Seal - Twist it on the opened product like a regular cap.

Stand - The cap also functions as a stand, so the product can be stored upright.

Re-use - Why recycle something that is just as easily kept and reused? (especially since keeping + reusing the cap keeps costs down for cap-less refills)  


 
When you buy a glue stick, the bulk of what you're getting is plastic packaging that will exist on the planet forever.
When you buy Wisdom Supply Co. Zero-Waste Paste, nothing goes to waste, with 100% recyclable aluminum packaging, and 100% all natural and organic ingredients to boot.
Packaging our product in an airtight, aluminum tube, minimizes the need for all-natural preservatives, since very little of the product is exposed to air before use.

 
 
Place Orders for 2020 Zero-Waste Weekly Planners
We worked with our local municipal waste haulers to design a 100% Recyclable (cover-to-cover) weekly planner, because everything else on the market was destined for landfill.
What Wisdom Supply Co. planners do NOT have, are components that turn them into landfill:

Spiral Binding (plastic or metal)
Plastic Tabs
Lamination
Elastic Bands / Ribbons
Book-Style Covers
Synthetic Material Covers

Landfill, landfill + landfill:

 
*Our 2019 Zero-Waste Weekly Planners have been extremely well received, both online + retail.

Due to the number of requests, we're working on a new version designed specifically for teachers.
 

Our Impact
Every time you choose Wisdom Supply Co. school supplies, you're preventing everlasting plastic and vinyl from becoming pollution. It's a vote for true sustainability, and for companies built from the ground up to do well (+ good) in the world. 
It is our belief that it's irresponsible to continue to tell our children they should care about the planet, while repeatedly filling their backpacks and desks with disposable products, year after year.
With your help, Wisdom Supply Co. can scale the reduction of waste, expand our reach, and increase our impact; together preventing tons of plastic and vinyl from entering the waste stream.

 
Risks & Challenges
Our biggest challenge is staffing in order to be nimble enough to respond to sudden shifts in demand.
Ours is a unique model, in that every time we onboard on a new customer (school or a teacher), there's a consulting component, followed by potentially hundreds of orders at one time. This requires us to establish efficient fulfillment systems, and to coordinate response strategies well in advance.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
Forwarding this campaign to friends and groups concerned about plastic pollution, and conservation in general will be a HUGE help.
THANK YOU FOR SHARING
 
SPECIAL NOTE ABOUT REWARDS FOR SCHOOLS:
*If you are gifting a reward to a teacher or school, we are happy to send them a message now, informing them that they will be receiving their new zero-waste classroom supplies in August.
If you want them to receive the supplies NOW, send us an email and we'll work it out!
Thank you!
Heather + Nikki

story:
No Petrol? No Problem!

In Nepal we currently face the second terrible crisis of this year: There is no petrol coming into the country. With the biggest national festival of Dasain on our doorstep, many of us Nepali who are living and working in Kathmandu want to travel home to our families during the holidays, which starts next week. Unfortunately, without petrol, public transport is barely pending between the cities of Kathmandu and Pokhara, the city where me and a lot of people in Kathmandu have their families. 
No Problem! On 17th of October, we will take the bicycle; Clean for the environment, healthy for us and a good promotion for more bicycle use in our country. We will be going to our home either way but this time we thought of utilizing our PEDAL POWER for a cause: Building Cycle stands in Pokhara! As the trip is roughly 200 km, with up and downhills, it will take us about two to three days (maximum) to reach to Pokhara. We believe in clean energy and advocates for clean, green and sustainable future.  This is high time we keep on pressuring our government to move towards sustainable mode of transportation and less dependency on dirty energy source; FOSSIL FUEL. 
Our cycling caravan is for raising awareness among Nepalese on clean energy importance for our sustainable future. This is where you come in! Support a good cause, donate a few dollars and get us on these bikes! Your support will help us promote cycling culture in our cities. We intend to construct bicycle stands in Pokhara and Kathmandu. This is where your support is needed!
 We did East-West Cycling with a motto "CYCLING FOR CHANGE". We work at Clean Energy Nepal, an NGO working on climate change, Clean Energy transport and closely associated with  networks; Cycle City Network Nepal, Kathmandu Cycle City 2020 which are also working on similar issues. They will hold responsibility for the way the money is being channeled. Help us to become less dependent on fossil fuel and promote the use of bicycles. In the mean time celebrate Dasain with our families!

What We Need!

  • For every person,  we have estimated that we will need 2000 NRs similar to 20 USD to account for his or her costs for food, drinks and accommodation, First Aid & bicycle maintenance along the way. Here you can support us by donating an estimated travel cost to Pokhara for individual i.e NRS 2000 (USD 20) and this amount will be directed towards building cycle stands in Pokhara similar to one recently implemented in Kathmandu: https://pbs.twimg.com/media/BmhuCvfCMAAQ_qB.png 
  • If you can join us, please join, if not you can support by donating a cost for individual to reach to Pokhara (2000 NRS  similar to 20 USD) 
  • A total of 5000 NRs. similar to 50 USD will be spent on  'spreading the message', by making a shirt with the slogan for each biker and other promotional tools.
  • For logistical arrangement, we will use NRS 10000 similar to USD 100 to make this campaign happen. 
  • Our goal is reached if we mobilize even one person coming along with us. 

The Impact

As Nepal is hit by the earthquake six months ago, it was already in a fragile state. Now with the man-made petrol crisis rolling through the country, the situation does not get any better. However, we think we are a pretty resilient folk... and by this way we can show that we are! Less petrol dependency, in a peaceful, environmental friendly way. Your contribution to that is essential! The money will be mainly spent in hotels and tea-houses along the way- stimulating the local economy, to promotional tools for message-spreading and to the implementation of a bicycle stand in Pokhara. Next to that, we will stop in numerous places along the way, and share our story to the local people.  

Risks & Challenges

Even though Clean Energy Nepal has experience with campaigning, rallies and mobilizing people, crowdfunding by Indiegogo is a new way of campaigning for us. I sadly can not offer you a signed t-shirt with your picture, a hand-made drawing of Mt. Everest or an all-inclusive trip to Nepal with guided tour (unless you're already in Nepal -then we might come to some sort of understanding), but we will put every name of every donor onto our web pages news feed after the tour, ánd CEN does have some buttons available with I (BIKE) KTM. They are limited though, so if you donate 10 USD or up, you will get one.

A challenge for us could be that only a couple of people can be mobilized because some simply do not own a bicycle. Through our network with Cycle City Network Nepal, Kathmandu Cycle City 2020, Clean Air Network Nepal and Pokhara Cycle City, we will campaign as hard as possible in both Kathmandu and Pokhara, possibly getting the attention of the news! On the other hand, if too much people are mobilized for too little funding, we will make clear that only the first ones to sign up will be receiving food, beverages and accommodation, while others are encouraged to come along on their own costs.

In order to make it easier for you to donate, we have activated a PayPal account on the credit card of one of Clean Energy Nepals' international interns, Bart Bakker. He helped me in setting up this campaign on Indiegogo, and with his bicycling experience from the Netherlands, he is dedicated to promote the use of bicycles in Nepal! The money will be channeled from his PayPal account to the bank account of Clean Energy Nepal.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have difficulties donating online, as many Nepalese do not have credit cards, it is possible to donate personally to me, Basanta Paudel, and I can be reached on 977-9841121980, or by email on abi.basanta@gmail.com. I will keep track of all personal donations and will ascertain it is being spent as we said.  

Sometimes you simply cannot afford to miss some money, we understand. You can help nonetheless by:

  • Sharing this message if you see it!
  • As an international: Coming to Nepal for Holiday! Especially now, the weather is amazing.
  • Taking the bicycle more often. Not really helping us though, but still.

A big thank you all, from me and my team at Clean Energy Nepal, and from the networks we are involved in!

story:
Short Summary

I am writing the book that I wanted to read as a child, a book that would tell me where I am, and by extension who I am and what is my place in the community of life. There are plenty of books that tell the tale of local mineral development, how Syracuse flourished because of the salt trade and the Erie Canal. But what about the biological wealth, the plants and animals who lived here and whose stories have never been told? My Indiegogo project aims to tell that story by recounting the historical ecology of Onondaga Lake, one of the most polluted lakes in the nation.

 What was Onondaga Lake like before becoming a toxic morass, and how did the indigenous people live equitably here with the land and water? Onondaga Lake once teemed with life—salmon, eel, waterfowl, rattlesnakes, orchids, passenger pigeons. The Lake today is a Superfund site with 10 subsites; see http://www.onondagalake.org/ for details. This contrast between Onondaga Lakes present (severely degraded landscape) and past (epicenter of life) inspired me to delve deeper into the past and piece together the Lake’s story.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Donations will help pay my living expenses while I work on the book and bring it to a close, about 8 months
  • Perks include original drawings of Lake flora and fauna by illustrator Stephanie Holmes and native plants from Nannyberry Nursery

The Impact

  • This book will fill a major gap in our understanding of place
  • Although details are specific to Onondaga Lake, the same story has occurred  wherever Superfund sites occur, and similar themes apply
  • I have already developed a website that has material similar to what will appear in the book -- see http://onondagalakehistoricalecology.weebly.com/the-cultural-landscape-of-onondaga-lake.html

Risks & Challenges

One challenge in a project such as this is finding the sources to answer my questions. Early settlers and visitors generally did not keep records on flora and fauna or the landscapes around them, for example. Also, the intensity of lake shore development has obliterated much biological or archaeological evidence over the years.

  • Despite these limits, I've learned to piece together a picture of the landscape from a number of different sources-- journals, archaeological records, county histories, florae for the area, etc-- combined with knowledge of species life history
Another challenge is overwhelm-- so many sub-stories to tell here, so little time!  
  • To keep the project manageable, I focus my research on the plant communities, which are the foundation for the rest of life 
  • Also, I stop at 1825, the year the Erie Canal opened across NYS and "all hell broke loose" as far as settlement and industrial growth in the Syracuse area

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but would like to help, your energy would be most welcome!

  • Please help get the word out about this campaign
  • Remember you can use the Indiegogo share tools
  • Moral support is always welcome!

story:
Greetings fellow tiny house enthusiasts, friends, family members and random explorers of the internet.

Our names are Nicole and Justin and we have big dreams to influence the world with our tiny house.


We are building a 200 square foot home on wheels.

  • Constructed from reused, upcycled, and sustainably harvested materials.

  • Built by hand with elbow grease and the help of people like you in the community.

  • Implementing alternative energy systems & conservation techniques. (including solar panels, wind power, rain-barrel water collection and energy efficient technologies)


Why Build Small?

There are many resources on the web that explain the benefits of living small. This infograph (click link below) explains some of the reasons people are living large in tiny houses.

http://tinyhousebuild.com/tiny-houses-infographic/



Beyond Building a Tiny House:

We are here to promote & educate about environmentally conscious living. Our non-profit, The Tiny Things in Life, is here to provide an educational platform to share information about tiny houses and environmentally-friendly lifestyles.

Find out more below in the section titled: Our Future Impact (with your help)

By donating to our campaign you can help us build our Tiny House which will be used to educate and advocate for the benefits of tiny house living & so much more!


Our Current Impact on the Community:

Over the last 6 months we have been working to bring the Tiny House Movement to Cleveland. It hasn't always been easy but it has been a rewarding experience to have an impact on others and the Greater Cleveland community. We have started...

  • The Greater Cleveland Tiny House Enthusiasts. A group that now has 80+ members. It was formed to help connect others passionate about tiny houses, sustainable design and alternative living. Currently we are working together to help change zoning laws to make Tiny Houses a legal & viable option in the Cleveland area. 

    http://www.meetup.com/Greater-Cleveland-Tiny-House-Enthusiasts/

  • The Non-Profit:The Tiny Things in Life. Working to make tiny houses a viable living option and expand the acceptance of affordable sustainable living.  http://www.thetinythingsinlife.org/

  • It is very important that we support and promote local businesses. Cleveland is a blossoming center for talented & inspirational companies. We've worked carefully to create our home and non-profit around the people and businesses that make this city thrive.

    Special thanks to our sponsors who are helping us make a positive change

     

     

     

      

  • (if you would like to be a sponsor, contact us at tinythingsinlife@gmail.com)


Our Future Impact (with your help):

Below are our short term goals for this project. With you're help we can grow to have a major impact on sustainability in North East Ohio. 

The Tiny Things in Life (non-profit organization):  

  • Educational How-To videos: Teach others to build their own energy efficient tiny home step-by-step. Expert advise and easy to understand information.
  • Informational Articles: Follow what is happening in the tiny house movement, Cleveland improvement projects, reducing your carbon footprint and much more.
  • Supportive Network: A Cleveland based group for those interested in tiny houses and sustainable living.
  • Work with Communities: Use Tiny House ideals to progress community goals for greener urban living.
  • Documentary / Interviews: In depth coverage of the Cleveland Tiny House Movement as it evolves. Covering the movement’s social and environmental impact and the people who make it possible.

Ways You Can Help:

Now we have the passion, enthusiasm, and planning but we need YOUR help. Supporting us as easy as a click of a button.

• Donate (& take home beautiful one of a kind art): 

Intricate Hand Made Book Mark:

One of a Kind Art Piece:

14 X 17 Custom Art Piece:

     ○   See more examples of art at https://www.facebook.com/FlowFarmcy

     ○  Simply click the CONTRIBUTE NOW button on the top right of this page to choose your size donation.


• Help Hands On! 

Do you have a tradeskill, want experience for building your own tiny house or  can just be an extra set of hands? You can pledge your time here:

http://www.volunteerspot.com/login/entry/977670384046


Can't donate money or time?

You can still help us inspire positive social and environmental change!

Like & Share us using the Indiegogo share tools! Change starts with small actions from those with a drive to make a difference. The more people we reach, the more we can . . . 

Reduce Waste, Optimize Space, and Leave the World a Better Place.

Currently we are working together to help change zoning laws to make Tiny Houses a legal & viable option in the Cleveland area.

The Non-Profit:The Tiny Things in Life. Working to make tiny houses a viable living option and expand the acceptance of affordable sustainable living.  http://www.thetinythingsinlife.org/

It is very important that we support and promote local businesses. Cleveland is a blossoming center for talented & inspirational companies. We've worked carefully to create our home and non-profit around the people and businesses that make this city thrive.
Special thanks to our sponsors who are helping us make a positive change



 
 


 








  





(if you would like to be a sponsor, contact us at tinythingsinlife@gmail.com)



Our Future Impact (with your help):
Below are our short term goals for this project. With you're help we can grow to have a major impact on sustainability in North East Ohio. 
The Tiny Things in Life (non-profit organization):  



Educational How-To videos: Teach others to build their own energy efficient tiny home step-by-step. Expert advise and easy to understand information.


Informational Articles: Follow what is happening in the tiny house movement, Cleveland improvement projects, reducing your carbon footprint and much more.


Supportive Network: A Cleveland based group for those interested in tiny houses and sustainable living.


Work with Communities: Use Tiny House ideals to progress community goals for greener urban living.


Documentary / Interviews: In depth coverage of the Cleveland Tiny House Movement as it evolves. Covering the movement’s social and environmental impact and the people who make it possible.





Ways You Can Help:
Now we have the passion, enthusiasm, and planning but we need YOUR help. Supporting us as easy as a click of a button. 

• Donate (& take home beautiful one of a kind art): Intricate Hand Made Book Mark:One of a Kind Art Piece:14 X 17 Custom Art Piece:     ○   See more examples of art at https://www.facebook.com/FlowFarmcy     ○  Simply click the CONTRIBUTE NOW button on the top right of this page to choose your size donation.
• Help Hands On! Do you have a tradeskill, want experience for building your own tiny house or  can just be an extra set of hands? You can pledge your time here:
http://www.volunteerspot.com/login/entry/977670384046

Can't donate money or time?
You can still help us inspire positive social and environmental change!
Like & Share us using the Indiegogo share tools! Change starts with small actions from those with a drive to make a difference. The more people we reach, the more we can . . . Reduce Waste, Optimize Space, and Leave the World a Better Place.

story:
The building industry is the largest contributor to carbon emissions and hence Global Warming. Only we can reverse what we have triggered and hope to restore Nature’s delicate balance. It is thus crucial to realize the responsibility architects hold in saving our planet.

We are Manasaram Architects from Bangalore, India -- an architectural firm committed to fight back climate change by promoting the use of naturally abundant, easily renewable and local materials for construction that leave lesser carbon footprint on our planet. The wonder-material Bamboo has especially inspired us to a great extent. We have 17 years of experience in prototyping a variety of building typologies, ranging from something as small as a low-cost bamboo toilet, to an urban proposal for a Bangalore Metro Station, responding to the whole spectrum of population of India. 

We have been invited for the third time to participate at the esteemed Venice Biennale in recognition of our works. In2012 and 2014, we couldn’t participate owing to high costs involved. However, this year we decided not to miss out on this huge opportunity as we believe we have some solutions to offer to the world. 

Our goal

Manasaram Architects and CGBMT (Center for Green Building Materials and Technology), a Trust and our sister organization, want to promote 'BAMBOO as a future building material of National and International Importance’ through this exhibition at the Venice Biennale by sharing on an international platform our major Bamboo based projects. 

The Center for Green Building Material Technology, Bangalore conducts various types of courses and training programs for Architects, Engineers, students, policy makers, and rural artisans. We train them in Bamboo Applications and Technologies, bamboo crafts, furniture design, energy generation, to encourage the use and realize the potential of Bamboo as a promising material. 

We conduct workshops to train and interact with designers and Artisans as part of our human resource generation through skill development, so we can come together to tackle issues and come up with solutions for minimal environmental impact.



Housing in India

India will have a higher population than China by 2022! A growing population creates demand for low cost social and responsive housing schemes, rapidly growing infrastructure facilities, amongst many other urban and rural amenities. Considering the scale of this requirement, the demand must be dealt with responsibly, taking into account the economies of scale, our environmental concerns, and HDI. HDI or Human Development Index is used to measure the quality of life in countries across the world, and is able to deeply reflect on the reality in particular countries. India at 0.609 has a long way to go to reach the minimum standards.

The Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana launched by the Prime Minister Narendra Modi in 2015 is a vision of Housing for All by the year 2022. The scheme comes with an aim of constructing more than 20 million houses across the length and breadth of the nation within a span of the next seven years. The implementation would be carried out in three sustainable phases till 2022.

OUR PM AT COP21 : Prime Minister Narendra Modi delivered a speech on making COP21 a success by promising to make India a champion in the fight against climate change. All eyes are on India as recent statements from the French and the US government suggests that the country is being pushed towards a corner to commit more at the Paris climate conference.

Ref: http://indianexpress.com/article/blogs/modi-at-cop21-india-will-negotiate-hard-to-keep-its-carbon-space/

Our concern is in regard to the enormous resource and energy consumption of the construction industry. The sector emits about 22 per cent of India’s total annual CO2 emissions. Using a minimum of 60% of bamboo as a construction material reduces emission by almost 10%! If there is a way to bring down the carbon emission, and reduce costs of construction, while at the same time making a successful attempt to raise India’s HDI, why not give this mission a fair chance to prove itself? Yes, we’re talking about tackling issues using Bamboo and other natural materials as alternatives in the construction industry. 

Bamboo Resource Position in India

India is the second largest producer of Bamboo in the world. According to FAO, total area under bamboo cultivation is 11,361 hectares as on 2005 of which 1,754 hectares in under private ownership and the rest is under state ownership. 

  • It is estimated that India taps only one-tenth of it’s bamboo potential, and it’s share in the global market is only about 4% 
  • Average productivity of bamboo from forest is around 2 tonnes per hectare per annum. 

www.bamboohouseindia.org www.greenlivelihoods.org Hyderabad India

Table 1 below shows a clear relation between bamboo growing areas and population, housing shortage, disaster and traditional bamboo technologies. Bamboo can be a major vehicle of integrated sustainable development for Bamboo rich areas.

Table 1

India has the best bamboo artisans in the world. Skill development is a basic need for any industry to grow. 

A diagram showing skill development model where the size of the box is indicative of the volume of skilled workforce required by the Industry:



Why should you care? 

Global Warming is a problem that is affecting our Earth in an exponential manner.

 We can stand by and watch it happen, or we can stand up together and pay attention to Climate Change, our low HDI, and look at the resource equity of providing housing on a large scale to our growing population. We hope it is a solution you would want to be a part of!



Join us! Help take this mission, to the most important architectural exhibition in the world, the Biennale in Venice! Lend a helping hand in taking our efforts, and the efforts of our trained artisans to share on a global stage, our work of almost two decades in Bamboo construction. Encourage the opportunity we have to solicit research, trade ideas and possibilities to further enrich our knowledge and others at the Biennale. What we do at Manasaram Architects and CGBMT how we work with our Bamboo is unique and special. Our construction methods have evolved over the years into a complex and individualistic style.

Impact

Bamboo grows in temperate and tropical countries around the world, especially in China and other countries in Southeast Asia, including in India. There is huge untapped potential here waiting to be harnessed!

Bamboo has the epithet of a ‘poor man’s timber’, and is found in abundance. Its strength, straightness and lightness combined with extraordinary hardness, range in sizes, abundance.It reaches it maturity in a short period before it is harvested for various purposes. The diversity of this incredible tall grass has to be conserved, for the revitalization of traditional sciences and technologies, and financial purposes. Moreover, planting of Bamboo would be the biggest service to environment because a bamboo produces 35% more oxygen than any other tree.

We hope that through our exhibit at this international forum, Bamboo will come out of this stigma. We intend to rebrand bamboo as a desirable material – a wise man’s timber. Through your help and our participation, we hope to expand our network and reach out to people around the world, to solicit collaborations with designers, institutions, universities, governments, and organizations for further research and skill development.

Donations to this organization will have income tax benefits.

As Halford E. Luccock  stated, 'It takes a whole orchestra to play a symphony' 

We urge you to be our orchestra.

The money received will be allocated to

  • Pay for our stall space
  • Travel expenses of our volunteers
  • Presentation of our works
  • Videos made to communicate our ideas.
  • Documentation of all the events and ideas during the exhibition as an e-book and video for further action.

story:
RESUMEN/SUMMARY

Fundación Humedales es una ONG fundada en 2000 en la ciudad de Bogotá. Trabajamos por la conservación de los humedales colombianos con un enfoque participativo. Nuestro objetivo es mejorar la calidad de vida de las comunidades locales de manera que se garantice el bienestar de las generaciones futuras.

Fundación Humedales is a Colombian NGO, funded in 2000 in the city of Bogotá. We work towards the conservation of Colombian wetlands with a participatory approach. Our goal is to improve life conditions for the local communities that guarantee the wellbeing of future generations.

Fundación Humedales Website

La Laguna de Fúquene es uno de los cuerpos de agua de alta montaña más importantes de los Andes del Norte. Se encuentra en Colombia, en la cuenca del río Ubaté. Cinco décadas de transformación, han convertido a la laguna en un distrito de riego lleno de problemas ambientales.  La cuenca de la laguna ha sufrido un intenso proceso de deforestación, dejando solo pequeños fragmentos de bosque nativo.

Lake Fúquene is one of the most important freshwater bodies of the high altitude ecosystems in the Northern Andes, located in Colombia in the Ubaté River Basin. Five centuries of transformations have changed the natural conditions of the lake and associated wetlands, into a problematic human regulated irrigation district. The catchment area of Lake Fúquene has suffered an intensive process of deforestation, leaving only small fragments of native forest.

             

                    Imágenes de la laguna de Fúquene y sus alrededores/ Images of the Lake and its surroundings

Los humedales de alta montaña son especialmente vulnerables al cambio climático y también esenciales para la adaptación de las personas a este fenómeno. Por esta razón, Fundación Humedales busca su colaboración para contribuir en la restauración de 3 ha de bosque nativo en Fúquene.
Con su ayuda, podremos mejorar el suelo y crear nuevos hábitats para las especies de animales. Estos factores van a transformar  el área, previniendo la erosión y disminuyendo el riesgo de  incendios forestales en futuros años Niño.

Colombia’s high Andean wetlands are particularly vulnerable to climate change and also essential for the adaptation of many human communities to that phenomenon. Following this rationale, Fundación Humedales decided to seek your cooperation, to contribute to the restoration of 3 ha of native forest, in Fúquene.

With your help we will be able to improve the soil and provide habitat for animal species visiting the new forest. The combination of this factors, will transform the land,preventing further erosion and decreasing the chances of forest fires in future drought periods.

QUÉ NECESITAMOS Y QUÉ OBTIENES TÚ

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

Necesitamos recolectar 10.000 USD (ca. 30 mill COP) para:
  1. Plantar semillas de especies nativas en un vivero
  2. Capacitar a la comunidad local en técnicas de reforestación
  3. Plantar más de 3000 árboles!!
  4. Mejorar la calidad de vida de la gente de Fúquene!
We need to reach 10.000 USD in order to:
  1. Plant the seedlings in a nursery
  2. Train the local community in reforestation techniques
  3. Plant 3000 trees!!
  4. Improve the quality of life of the people in Fúquene!

       

Además de contribuir a un planeta más verde para cada uno de nosotros, te damos la oportunidad de dedicarle un árbol a un ser querido cuando contribuyes con 50 USD. La dedicatoria será puesta en el árbol en una placa de metal y te enviaremos un bonito certificado de regalo con una foto del árbol además de updates de como va creciendo.
Besides contributing to achieve a better planet for all of us, you will get the oportunity to dedicate a tree to a beloved one, when contributing 50 USD or more. The dedication will be put on the tree on a plate and you will get a beautiful certificate with a picture of the tree mailed to you. We will also send you updates about your tree.

THE FULL STORY... 

Lake Fúquene is one of the most important freshwater bodies of the high altitude ecosystems in the Northern Andes, located in Colombia in the Ubaté River Basin in a high altitude tropical region. Five centuries of transformations have changed the natural conditions (i.e. climate, hydrological pulses) of the lake and associated wetlands, into a problematic human regulated irrigation district. The catchment area of Lake Fúquene has suffered an intensive process of deforestation, leaving only small fragments of native forest. Previous reforestation efforts were made in the area during the 1980s, but the species chosen were exotic and very damaging to the soil, increasing erosion.

Colombia’s high Andean wetlands are particularly vulnerable to climate change and also essential for the adaptation of many human communities to that phenomenon. Analysing Lake Fúquene´s vulnerability to climate change, Franco et al. (2011) recommended to restore a forest cover of at least 36% of the basin area in the next 20 years, to ensure the resilience of the territory.

Following this rationale, Fundación Humedales decided to seek your cooperation, to contribute to the restoration of 3 ha of native forest, in Fúquene.

The proposed site for the restoration project, lies 600 meters away from the lake´s shore, near the road that connects the small city of Ubaté and the town of Susa. The land is covered in shrubs and patches of exotic species.  The soil is highly degraded and eroded in most of the land, caused by the effects of the exotic species in the soil.

In previous years, Fundación Humedales installed a nursery, where community members learned to grow and care for native species that were later used for reforestation initiatives. We propose a project that consists of a planning phase, a nursery development phase, a planting phase and an evaluation phase. Every one of these, includes a training workshop aimed at instructing interested members of the community in the skills necessary for engaging in forest restoration. We expect to reforest 3 ha with native species, using the technique of vegetation cores. We anticipate an improvement in the soil following the planting of the seedlings in terms of water retention, amount of organic matter and depth of the soil. Also, we hope for an increase in the amount and diversity of animal species visiting the new forest and better availability of water. The combination of this factors, will transform the land, preventing further erosion and decreasing the chances of forest fires in future drought periods.

    Among the posible risks we face are:

    • A low attendance of community members to the training workshops.
    • Delays caused by the climate (Planting during drought is not an option!) 

    YOU CAN ALSO HELP US BY....

    • Sharing our campaign with your friends and family!
    • Volunteer with us to plant trees (If you are in Colombia)
    • Planting a tree near yor home
      •  

    THANK YOU!!

story:
The Cutty Sark 2Sail project is making news! Read the news about us:


 

Welcome on board!
Let’s work together to design, build and sail a magnificent replica of this most beautiful 19th century clipper ship - the Cutty Sark.

We would like to invite you to join our project to design, to build and (!)– to sail a replica of one of the most famous sailing ships the world has known - the tea clipper “Cutty Sark”

The CuttySark2Sail is about more than just building a ship; we intend to rediscover and save traditional skills and knowledge for future generations; to promote sail training and tall ships as environmentally friendly transport on the seas; to generate International friendship and trade.

THE CHALLENGE:

TO BUILD A HUGE WOODEN SAILING SHIP - working together with friends, with your own hands: isn't that a challenge to the modern world of computers and gadgets? We believe people should not forget about the good old ways of doing things. We are going for really hard work, in real world. We will bring back the Great Age of Sail. We'll make it real.

THE TASK:

We’ll start with one ship at first: an authentic sailing cargo vessel, a new Cutty Sark. Our dedicated and committed team are currently raising funds, to produce the ship's plans, and for the construction of this amazing ship. You are welcome to join the team.

YOUR HELP:

At this very first stage, we will employ the most skilful naval architects: we have to integrate a safety equipment into the historically accurate shape of the original ship. In modern world, it’s critically important to have professionally made drawings, calculations and receive approvals before moving further with the construction.
To produce this we are asking for your financial support, and your involvement

Let’s shape the future together:
Experience the power of the wind and show the world how to use it to its maximum effect!
Revive the awesome skills of past generations and ensure a future for the most ecological form of transportation known to mankind.

Tea-clipper Cutty Sark - design, history, future.

Become part of this Dream, part of the Team and a vital Crew Member. Come share with us an unforgettable experience!

Accept the challenge - make the change!

Content: About | Our first steps | You involvement | Why should you join? | Our expertise | Timeline | Budget | Environment | Rewards | History | Foundation | Objectives | Charity Trustees | The Team | Win a Prize | Technical details | FAQ


Now we'll build a new ship – the very first full-scale replica of the legendary record-breaking 19th century tea and wool Clipper Ship, the Cutty Sark.  Back in those days, the Clipper sailed around the globe, carrying precious cargo. On her journeys, all she needed was the wind to sail, and the stars to steer her by.  She was sleek and refined, the pinnacle of the Great Age of Sail. Her builders spared no expense, she was speed personified - she was perfection.

The new Cutty Sark will sail the historic routes to China, Australia, North & South America - carrying traditional cargoes (tea, coffee, wool) across the Globe. Anyone wishing for an amazing and life-changing experience will be able to join the crew as a trainee.

Just imagine, you're standing on the warm wooden deck of the most beautiful and elegant sailing ship ever built. You see the curious crowd assembled to get a glimpse  of the Cutty Sark 2 departing on her maiden voyage.
This is like standing in the middle of a major movie set. You feel the mild breeze and the sunshine gently warming your skin. Your chest swells with pride because you know it was your efforts that helped to make sure it all happened.
The sails begin to catch the wind, shaking the very fibres of your soul as you begin YOUR epic journey.

This is where the true adventure starts – this is where you belong.
Welcome back to the future!



 Please make you contribution to help move things forward.

Tell everyone about this wonderful Dream in your social media pages.

Give your friends, colleagues and relatives the chance to take part in this adventure – just tell everyone what you know about this idea to bringing back the Great Age of Sail. Share this page on Facebook. 

Please show your support by adding #reborn2sail to your profile picture!

Click here to add #Reborn2Sail to your profile picture.

Step out of your routine, and become an active member of the team. Take part in or even lead a section of the project – management, promotion, design, construction, sailing, guiding people around the shipyard or even trading for future cargo transportation.

This is your privilege, and it is our honour 
to have you in The Cutty Sark Family.


The experience:

You will have a lot of fun - meet new friends, experience team spirit, learn new skills.  And this could be your secret escape route from the fast pace of modern living.

The challenge:

You can challenge yourself by doing what you've never done before:  go to a rainforest to get some timber for the ship; help lay the keel or fit a plank; prepare a meal for 30+ hungry volunteer shipbuilders; dance on the deck of the ship before she is launched; stitch a sail and set it up to a yard...

The reward:

Satisfaction - you've supported the Cutty Sark 2Sail Project today, and you will always have the satisfaction of knowing that you’ve helped to bring back the glorious Great Age of Sail.


Now it’s time for us to thank you, please take a look at our ideas for rewards: 


Some years ago, we've got together as a team, and built a replica of the 1703 frigate Shtandart, the first ship of the Peter the Great's Russian Navy.

It was an absolutely life-changing experience – working together as a professional team, being together as a family. Learning new skills, and showing others what can be achieved. The result is an amazing ship, and the freedom to sail wherever we want. A new life which we made ourselves! 

Replica frigate Shtandart being built in St.-Petersburg Russia 1994-1999

Frigate Shtandart under full sails


Design:

This is where we shall start.  It will take three months to produce the drawings. Three months to get approvals. Then six months to secure funding. One year altogether. We shall start the design work no later than February the 1st, 2016

Construction:

The original Cutty Sark was built in 11 months. Our ancestors have set us a challenge - can we do it as fast as they did? Realistically, it might take two or even three times longer. To complete the ship in time, we plan to start construction no later than February 1st, 2017.

Launch date:

The original Cutty Sark was launched on 22nd November 1869. It would be remarkable if the launching of the new Cutty Sark could happen on the 150th Anniversary of the original launch: 22nd November 2019.


For the first stage to succeed – making the detailed design – the Cutty Sark2sail Foundation is challenged to collect 105,000 Euro (around 120,000 USD).

The total cost: We will know the exact total budget of the whole project after all the calculations and drawings are made. It might come to anything between 12 to 24M Euro. Sounds like a lot of money, eh?

There are two pieces of good news:
1. We don't need all that money at once.  "Nothing is particularly hard if you divide it into small jobs."  ~Henry Ford. 

2. By experience we know that if we do the job properly, money will come when we need it: "When one serves for the sake of service--for the satisfaction of doing that which one believes to be right – then money abundantly takes care of itself. Money comes naturally as the result of service." ~Henry Ford




Clean. Green. A wonder to be seen!  

The new ship will be as ecologically clean as possible. A stunningly magnificent vessel carrying out her work in a good, clean, traditional way, powered only by wind and sails.

Nowadays, the exhaust from cargo ships contributes enormously to the pollution of our Oceans. We want to stop the ongoing destruction of our Planet. Together we can make a difference!

Cutty Sark 2 will serve as an ambassador for the ecologically sound future which we envisage.

Sailing around the globe, transporting cargo, she will attract great attention and will serve as a reminder that we should consider sustainable energy alternatives for travel, trade and transportation.

She will serve as a shining example to all that sail power is a viable means of sea transport. With your help, we will make her a success! We will make a difference!


Does the original ship still exist?

Yes. The original ship has been preserved.  She is now used as a museum, docked in Greenwich, London.  She is motionless now, although she seems to float upon air and glass ... she can no longer sail the seven seas.  That is why we want to build an exact copy - of the same size, of the same materials and, almost, with the same technology.

The Cutty Sark 2 will once again carry her spirit around the world. 

 

       



To mark your support, we want to express our gratitude and give you some special souvenirs we have created:

PRINTED FIRST SUPPORTER CERTIFICATE + 5 POSTCARDS

A maximum of 200 pennants will be produced.

Maximum of 100 brass plates will be made.

The original Cutty Sark was built in Dumbarton, in 1869 for the China tea trade.

Cutty Sark‍’s well known race against Thermopylae took place in 1872, the two ships leaving Shanghai together on 18th June. Two weeks later Cutty Sark had built up a lead of some 400 nautical miles, when she lost her rudder in a severe gale. The ship's carpenter took six days to construct a new rudder, working in gales and heavy seas. This happened twice during the same voyage. The ship arrived in London on 18th October a week after Thermopylae, and was awarded the prize for first ship home, in spite of being a week behind Thermopylae.

In 1885, the ship’s owner, Jock Willis (white hat Willis), hired an excellent and eccentric captain named Richard Woodget to sail the ship in the Australian wool trade.

In this arena the Cutty Sark once again excelled, setting speed records between London and  Australia. For a decade she established herself  through record breaking voyages, but in 1895 Willis sold her to the Portuguese. Renamed Ferreira, she served under the Portuguese Flag until 1923 when she was purchased by Wilfred Dowman, for use as a sail training ship.

The old ship has now been restored and looks beautiful, but will never go to sea again. She rests in her own dry dock in Greenwich, London.

It’s now time to build a replica to sail the seven seas once more, as an ambassador to The Great Age of Sail and as a working memorial to the men who sailed in these fantastic ships.

CUTTY SARK 2SAIL FOUNDATION is a charity and it has been entered onto the UK Register of Charities with the Registered Charity Number 1163446.


To recreate the clipper ship 'Cutty Sark' as a seagoing vessel which will be sailed in a traditional way, as a living memorial to the Great Age of Sailing Ships;

To encourage self-development and provide innovative training in seamanship and life skills for young people of all nations;

To promote sail-powered shipping as an environmentally friendly alternative.


David T Morgan, Esq, MBE, TD video

CUTTY SARK 2SAIL Foundation Chairman

David is Chairman of the Maritime Heritage Trust and previously of Heritage Afloat, and Vice Chairman of the Cutty Sark Trust. He is Deputy President of the Transport Trust and a Committee Member of Europa Nostra Industrial and Engineering Heritage Committee. 

David is also Founder President of the European Federation of Museum and Tourist Railways and the World Association of Tourist Trams and Trains.  He served as Chairman of Heritage Railway Association  until 1st June 2014, and is also Chairman of Great Central Railway Plc and Vice President of the West Somerset Railway and President of the North Norfolk Railway. His initial involvement with preserved railways was as legal advisor, since he is a solicitor. 

David retired from practice at the end of Ferbuary 2013.  He served for 32 years in the Territorial Army, ending up with the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel. He was decorated with the MBE by the Queen in 2003 for his services "to transport preservation in the UK and Europe".


Mr John Robinson video

His 24-year career as a maritime curator was combined with extensive practical seafaring experience, including 32 years service with the Royal Naval Reserve and many thousands of miles under sail (He holds the RYA Yachtmaster Offshore qualification and an MCA Boatmaster's Licence). 

Since retiring as Senior Curator of Water Transport at the Science Museum, he worked voluntarily for the European Maritime Heritage Organisation and serves as a Trustee of the Maritime Heritage Trust. His clients for consultancy studies have included the Heritage Lottery Fund, Trinity House Lighthouse Service and various maritime museums.

A former member of the National Historic Ships Committee, he has a detailed knowledge of the UK's heritage of historic ships and boats, and of ship preservation in European counties. John Robinson is an expert on all aspects of historic ship preservation and operation.


Captain Chris Blake OBE video

Captain Blake joined the Merchant Navy in 1962 and 13 years later moved to sail training. He has been captain of the Sir Winston Churchill and Malcolm Miller (Great Britain), STS Ji Fung (Hong Kong), STS Leeuwin (Western Australia), STS Kaisei (Japan) and delivery master of STS Young Endeavour, Britain's bicentennial gift to Australia.

In 1993 Captain Blake took command of the replica vessel Endeavour and sailed her around the world twice, rounding both Cape Horn and the Cape of Good Hope during her travels to Europe and the Americas from Australia.

He holds the International Master Class I certificates with a square rig endorsement.

Captain Blake has been awarded the Freeman of the City of London, and Freeman of the City of Newark, USA. In 1996 he was awarded the Cutty Sark Medal for outstanding seamanship and leadership, and in 2001 received the OBE for services to Sail Training and Youth Development.


Mr Thomas Hoppe

Thomas Hoppe is Vice-chairman of Gemeinsame Kommission für Historische Wasserfahrzeuge (GSHW). 

Thomas is a qualified lawyer and runs his own Legal Consultancy Firm. He is also a keen sailor.



Vladimir Martus, RU/DE
Sports record holder, and the master of minds, Vladimir is used to making his dreams become reality. He is the project's leader and inspiration. It was Vladimir’s idea to build a new Cutty Sark and if anybody can make this happen – Vladimir can.

Born and raised in a naval officers family, Vladimir started his sailing career when he was just 14 and has now been sailing the seas for more than 35 years. He graduated from the St Petersburg University of shipbuilding as a naval architect and has worked as an officer on large sailing ships and replicas from 1989.
In 1991 Vladimir built his first sailing schooner called St Peter (she can be seen in “Pirates of the Carribean” as the Black Pearl). From 1994-1999 he built and launched a 100ft sailing frigate, an exact replica of Tsar Peter the Great’s 28-gun warship, Shtandart. 
Vladimir has directed several city festivals and maritime events in St Petersburg. He is President of the non-profit and charitable organisation ‘Shtandart Project’, through which, over the past 17 years,more than 3000 youngsters have received practical training in seamanship, personal skills and leadership abilities.

Roman Abykhatov, UK/RU

Being an IT engineer at Microsoft UK, Roman is responsible for establishing the IT infrastructure to help coordinate the team work and volunteer activities online for the Cutty Sark 2Sail Project. 
Whenever there is an emergency or something needs doing quickly you can rely on Roman.

Kseniya Aksenovskikh, RU
In love with color and line, Kseniya delivers visual sensation. Her beautiful images and drawings help pull the project together. 

She is working incredibly hard to create and maintain a corporate identity which is giving the project a beautiful profile across the media.


Istvan Bordacs, HU

An IT engineer and entrepreneur dedicated to both the Cutty Sark and the Cutty Sark 2Sail Project. Istvan makes our technological ideas come true. 
He is fascinated with tall ships and other related subjects and his knowledge and expertise makes him an invaluable member of the team.


Bo Forsström, FI video

Liaison officer for the Tall Ship Races and former business development manager, Bo gets great satisfaction from how sail training challenges young people and makes them grow. 
He likes to go with them and gets inspiration from them.

Dmitry Ryabchikov video

Started to sail on board of Shtandart at the age of 12. Then he became a professional seafarer and spent 14 years on sailing ships of all types and sizes. He now works on Shtandart as a sail trainer and first officer.
He is looking for ways to integrate classic sailing ships with modern reality. He holds the RYA Yachtmaster Offshore qualification.

PM von Kaenel (Michele Stephens), UK video

Michele von Kaenel is a veteran broadcaster and media consultant who helps our team stay active and move forward.
Tall ships have always been a fascination of hers, so when this project surfaced she immediately applied to join the Team.


Maria Savelieva, RU

Attracted by the project’s challenge, Maria adds a corporate element to the team and tries to make sure we work efficiently. 
Drive, competency and high targets are the cards she plays. She is enthralled by the beauty of tall ships.


Pete Sedgwick, UK video

A designer and boat builder with marketing experience, Pete offers us his wisdom and broad knowledge in marketing and strategy. For the last 15 years he has been building replica traditional wooden boats. Now he is moving on to ships! 
He is up to his neck in this BIG dream – helping to create the next famous British tea clipper.

Alina Radova, RU

A natural sales executive, Lina is happy to help with searching for construction sites and generating creative crowdfunding ideas. 
She is the engine that keeps us going and she never stops thinking out of the box. She speaks fluent Spanish, Portuguese, and links the project with many countries.  

   

A brass plaques with the winners' names will be installed on the deck of the Cutty Sark 2.  And, if you wish, we will publish an interview with you on all Cutty Sark 2Sail resources.

At this first stage, we need to find the best way to build the sailing clipper – preserving all the historic details, and satisfying modern safety and ecological requirements. It is not an easy task – most sailing ships experience difficulties nowadays, dealing with more and more complicated regulations, invented for large steel motor vessels.  We will employ the most experienced naval architects to produce top quality, detailed calculations and to prove that classical sailing ships have rights to exist today – without compromising safety.

It is also important to note that this work is necessary and will be extremely useful for all working sailing ships, developing the level of understanding between sail training ships and international maritime authorities.


If the new ship is a replica, why do we need to produce a new design?

The world has changed. Safety standards are different. What was normal sailing practice 150 years ago is not acceptable today.

To achieve the latest safety standards, it will be necessary to rearrange some internal details in the ship. For example: some machinery space is required for generators to provide power – for safety equipment that we are obliged to include, and things like a fridge and a freezer; domestic fresh, grey and black water purification systems will also be required; lifesaving equipment, including life rafts and specially designed small tug-boats which regulations demand be carried on board … and don’t forget the requisite launching equipment or the advanced anchor system - with extra anchors at the stern – which must all be designed and placed in a “concealed” fashion so they don't detract from the aesthetic integrity of a 19th century vessel.

The main hull, masts, spars, rigging and all operating aspects will be unchanged from those of the original ship. The new Cutty Sark will have modern equipment on board, everything to provide her with the highest levels of safety. And she has to be built as a pure sailing ship which is environmentally friendly and sound. 

These modern additions will be carefully placed so that they will not disrupt the historical integrity of the original clipper.

Where does the money go if this crowdfunding campaign is not successful?

The Cutty Sark2Sail Foundation retains the collected funds.
Even if we do not succeed in collecting sufficient money for the completion of the first project stage through this crowdfunding campaign, the donated money will still be used to start the project.

The Cutty Sark2Sail Foundation retains this funding and will continue raising funds from other sources until enough money has been raised to complete the first stage (design) and go on the following stages (construction, launching and putting out to sea). 

Where does the estimated figure come from?
Is it a draft figure or an exact calculation?

The cost for the design work is 105,000 Euros (110,500$). That is the definite figure received as a firm quotation from a company of professional naval architects.  

What is total cost of building such ship and how is it made up?

The total cost of the project of 19-26M Euros is an estimate, based on analysis of similar projects in Europe and other countries throughout the world. A full detailed budget will be available after the detailed design of the ship is complete.

The estimate consists of the following:

120K €: Ship design and approvals
4M €: Site preparation and building viewing/accommodation facilities
880K €: Timber: Teak (130m3) + Rock Elm  (200m3) etc.
13M €: Labour
4M €: Equipment and tooling
4M €: Overheads and contingency
Total: 26M €

How will you raise this money?

After completion of the design we will be able to detail schedules and budgets. We will go to large companies (like tea importing companies, wool producers, etc.) with proposals for cooperation in the field of marketing their products using ecologically clean transportation.

We will also approach large TV companies, with proposals to create video productions of constructing and sailing Cutty Sark 2.  Additionally, we will be approaching potential sponsors and donors, with a request to help in supporting the preservation of maritime heritage and traditional skills.
What will happen if we don't collect the required amount? 
 We will simply try and try again, until we succeed. 

To what extent will the ship be modified, modernized?
Will it still be historically accurate after the modification?

The plan will preserve ALL visible parts of the ship in their true historical appearance. The way the ship is to be used will adhere to traditional methods as much as possible. However, in the hold we will hide a modern power unit to produce electricity for state of the art navigation systems, and communication. All water & sewage purification systems, as well as up to date safety systems will also be included on board. We will make these modifications in such a way that people’s impression of Cutty Sark 2 as the original vessel will not be compromised. We have successful achieved this previously when designing the frigate Shtandart.

Are there professionals in the Cutty Sark 2Sail Team who have relevant knowledge/experience?

We have people with considerable experience in building and sailing traditional sailing ships. We also have team members with marketing and project management expertise. We will enlist other professionals for the areas where the team experience is lacking. Just to give you a glimpse:

Captain Vladimir Martus is a qualified Naval Architect with deep sea sailing experience as a captain, and has Yacht Master Instructor qualifications. He has built three large wooden replica ships on his own and he has considerable experience of the  most European traditional sailing ships projects (Batavia, De Delft, Tenacious, Lord Nelson, HMS Trincomalee, Gotheborg and Hermione).

Have you carried out research; will Cutty Sark 2 be popular for sailing?

There is a definite demand for ecological awareness and returning to our historical roots.

Cutty Sark 2 is going to create an information flow to keep people aware of good alternatives regarding the reducion of pollution and CO2 emissions. She will regenerate the skills and knowledge of past generation of sailors. 

The detailed research on how much interest she will attract is still on-going, but when we see the figures of people attending maritime festivals, when we see queues of people waiting to visit traditional ships, we think it is a definite sign that Cutty Sark 2 will have no difficulty in attracting an audience and supporters.

Where will the new Cutty Sark be built?

We have considered several possible places, and are now preparing a detailed survey to finalise on the best location. Priorities for defining the best place to settle our museum shipyard are: 

1. We expect the local community to “adopt” the Cutty Sark 2Sail project as their own, with friendly support on all levels: local authorities, construction and planning, tourism departments etc;  

2. Ideal place should have a potential for bringing in a lot of visitors; 

3. Preferably, it should be a nice and interesting place for volunteers to come and spend 4-8 weeks helping to the project.  

4. Above all, it must be technical possibilities to build the ship, launch her and take her to out to sea. 

The decision had not been made yet. We are in process of collecting further information from many possible locations.

Where is Shtandart now? Is she sailing?
Yes, the exact replica of the 18th century wooden frigate is still in active use. She has been sailing almost all year round, for the last 16 years. Our team is actually using the experience and lessons received from their experience with Shtandart to put into Cutty Sark 2 project.

The Cutty Sark 2Sail project is making news! Read the news about us: 







  





 



Welcome on board!Let’s work together to design, build and sail a magnificent replica of this most beautiful
19th century clipper ship - the Cutty Sark.


We would like to invite you to join our project to design, to build and (!)– to sail a replica of one of the most famous sailing ships the world has known - the tea clipper “Cutty Sark”
The CuttySark2Sail is about more than just building a ship; we intend to rediscover and save traditional skills and knowledge for future generations; to promote sail training and tall ships as environmentally friendly transport on the seas; to generate International friendship and trade.

THE CHALLENGE:
TO BUILD A HUGE WOODEN SAILING SHIP - working together with friends, with your own hands: isn't that a challenge to the modern world of computers and gadgets? We believe people should not forget about the good old ways of doing things. We are going for really hard work, in real world. We will bring back the Great Age of Sail. We'll make it real.
THE TASK:
We’ll
start with one ship at first: an authentic sailing cargo vessel, a new Cutty Sark. Our
dedicated and committed team are currently raising funds, to produce the ship's plans, and for the construction of this amazing ship. You are welcome to join the team.

At this very first stage, we will employ the most skilful naval architects: we
have to integrate a safety
equipment into the historically accurate shape of the original ship. In modern world, it’s critically
important to have professionally made drawings, calculations and receive approvals before moving further with the construction. To produce this we are asking for your financial support, and your involvement
