hard if you divide it into small jobs."  ~Henry Ford. 

2. By experience we know that if we do
the job properly, money will come when we need it: "When one
serves for the sake of service--for the satisfaction of doing that which
one believes to be right – then money abundantly takes care of
itself. Money comes naturally as the result of service." ~Henry Ford












Clean.
Green. A wonder to be seen!  



The new ship will be as ecologically clean as
possible. A stunningly magnificent vessel carrying out her work in a good,
clean, traditional way, powered only by wind and sails.
Nowadays, the exhaust from cargo ships contributes
enormously to the pollution of our Oceans. We want to stop the ongoing
destruction of our Planet. Together we can make a difference!
Cutty Sark 2 will serve as an ambassador for the
ecologically sound future which we envisage.
Sailing around the globe,
transporting
cargo, she will attract great attention and will serve as a reminder
that we should consider sustainable energy alternatives for travel, trade and
transportation. 
She will serve as a shining example to all that sail
power is a viable means of sea transport. With your help, we will make her a
success! We will make a difference!





Does the original ship still exist?
Yes. The original ship has been preserved.  She is
now used as a museum,
docked in Greenwich, London.  She is motionless now, although she seems to float upon air and glass ... she can no longer sail the seven seas.  That is why we want to build an exact copy - of the same size, of the same materials and, almost, with the same technology.

The Cutty Sark 2 will once again carry her spirit around the world. 



 




       














To mark your support, we want to express our gratitude and give you some special souvenirs we have created:

PRINTED FIRST SUPPORTER CERTIFICATE + 5 POSTCARDS

The original Cutty Sark was built in Dumbarton, in 1869 for the China tea trade.
Cutty Sark‍’s well known race against
Thermopylae took place in 1872, the two ships leaving Shanghai together on 18th June. Two weeks later Cutty Sark had built up a lead of some 400 nautical
miles, when she lost her rudder in a severe gale. The ship's carpenter took six
days to construct a new rudder, working in gales and heavy seas. This happened
twice during the same voyage. The ship arrived in London on 18th October a week
after Thermopylae, and was awarded the prize for first ship home, in spite of
being a week behind Thermopylae.
In 1885, the ship’s owner, Jock Willis
(white hat Willis), hired an excellent and eccentric captain named Richard
Woodget to sail the ship in the Australian wool trade.
In this arena the Cutty Sark once again
excelled, setting speed records between London and  Australia. For a decade she established herself
 through record breaking voyages, but in
1895 Willis sold her to the Portuguese. Renamed Ferreira, she served under the
Portuguese Flag until 1923 when she was purchased by Wilfred Dowman, for use as a
sail training ship.
The old ship has now been
restored and looks beautiful, but will never go to sea again. She rests in her
own dry dock in Greenwich, London.
It’s now time to build a
replica to sail the seven seas once more, as an ambassador to The Great Age of
Sail and as a working memorial to the men who sailed in these fantastic ships.





CUTTY SARK 2SAIL FOUNDATION is a charity and it has been entered onto the UK Register of Charities with the Registered Charity Number 1163446.



To recreate the clipper ship 'Cutty Sark' as a seagoing vessel which will be sailed in a traditional way, as a living memorial to the Great Age of Sailing Ships;
To encourage self-development and provide innovative training in seamanship and life skills for young people of all nations;To promote sail-powered shipping as an environmentally friendly alternative.










David T Morgan, Esq, MBE, TD video
CUTTY SARK 2SAIL Foundation Chairman
David is Chairman of the Maritime Heritage Trust and previously of Heritage Afloat, and Vice Chairman of the Cutty Sark Trust. He is Deputy President of the Transport Trust and a Committee Member of Europa Nostra Industrial and Engineering Heritage Committee. 
David is also Founder President of the European Federation of Museum and Tourist Railways and the World Association of Tourist Trams and Trains.  He served as Chairman of Heritage Railway Association  until 1st June 2014, and is also Chairman of Great Central Railway Plc and Vice President of the West Somerset Railway and President of the North Norfolk Railway. His initial involvement with preserved railways was as legal advisor, since he is a solicitor. 
David retired from practice at the end of Ferbuary 2013.  He served for 32 years in the Territorial Army, ending up with the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel. He was decorated with the MBE by the Queen in 2003 for his services "to transport preservation in the UK and Europe".

Mr John Robinson video
His 24-year career as a maritime curator was combined with extensive practical seafaring experience, including 32 years service with the Royal Naval Reserve and many thousands of miles under sail (He holds the RYA Yachtmaster Offshore qualification and an MCA Boatmaster's Licence). 
Since retiring as Senior Curator of Water Transport at the Science Museum, he worked voluntarily for the European Maritime Heritage Organisation and serves as a Trustee of the Maritime Heritage Trust. His clients for consultancy studies have included the Heritage Lottery Fund, Trinity House Lighthouse Service and various maritime museums.A former member of the National Historic Ships Committee, he has a detailed knowledge of the UK's heritage of historic ships and boats, and of ship preservation in European counties. John Robinson is an expert on all aspects of historic ship preservation and operation.

Captain Chris Blake OBE video
Captain Blake joined the Merchant Navy in 1962 and 13 years later moved to sail training. He has been captain of the Sir Winston Churchill and Malcolm Miller (Great Britain), STS Ji Fung (Hong Kong), STS Leeuwin (Western Australia), STS Kaisei (Japan) and delivery master of STS Young Endeavour, Britain's bicentennial gift to Australia.
In 1993 Captain Blake took command of the replica vessel Endeavour and sailed her around the world twice, rounding both Cape Horn and the Cape of Good Hope during her travels to Europe and the Americas from Australia.
He holds the International Master Class I certificates with a square rig endorsement.
Captain Blake has been awarded the Freeman of the City of London, and Freeman of the City of Newark, USA. In 1996 he was awarded the Cutty Sark Medal for outstanding seamanship and leadership, and in 2001 received the OBE for services to Sail Training and Youth Development.


Mr Thomas HoppeThomas Hoppe is Vice-chairman of Gemeinsame Kommission für Historische Wasserfahrzeuge (GSHW). 
Thomas is a qualified lawyer and runs his own Legal Consultancy Firm. He is also a keen sailor.





Vladimir Martus, RU/DE

Sports record holder, and the
master of minds, Vladimir is used to making his dreams become reality. He is
the project's leader and inspiration. It was Vladimir’s idea to build a new
Cutty Sark and if anybody can make this happen – Vladimir can.

Born and raised in a naval officers
family, Vladimir started his sailing career when he was just 14 and has now
been sailing the seas for more than 35 years. He graduated from the St Petersburg
University of shipbuilding as a naval architect and has worked as an officer on large sailing ships and replicas from 1989.
In 1991
Vladimir built his first sailing schooner called St Peter (she can be seen in
“Pirates of the Carribean” as the Black Pearl). From
1994-1999 he built and launched a 100ft sailing frigate, an exact replica of
Tsar Peter the Great’s 28-gun warship, Shtandart. 
Vladimir has directed several
city festivals and maritime events in St Petersburg.
He is President of the non-profit and charitable organisation ‘Shtandart
Project’, through which, over the past 17 years,more
than 3000 youngsters have received practical training in seamanship, personal
skills and leadership abilities.


Roman Abykhatov, UK/RUBeing an IT
engineer at Microsoft UK, Roman is responsible for establishing the IT
infrastructure to help coordinate the team work and volunteer activities online
for the Cutty Sark 2Sail Project. 
Whenever there is an emergency or
something needs doing quickly you can rely on Roman.

Kseniya Aksenovskikh, RU

In love with color and line,
Kseniya delivers visual sensation. Her beautiful images and drawings help pull
the project together. 
She is working incredibly hard to create and maintain a
corporate identity which is giving the project a beautiful profile across the
media.

Istvan Bordacs, HUAn IT engineer and
entrepreneur dedicated to both the Cutty Sark and the Cutty Sark 2Sail Project. Istvan makes
our technological ideas come true. 
He is fascinated with tall ships and other
related subjects and his knowledge and expertise makes him an invaluable member
of the team.

Bo Forsström, FI videoLiaison officer for the Tall
Ship Races and former business development manager, Bo gets great satisfaction from
how sail training challenges young people and makes them grow. 
He likes to go with them and gets inspiration from them.


Dmitry Ryabchikov video
Started to sail on board of Shtandart at the age of 12. Then he became a professional seafarer and spent 14 years on sailing ships of all types and sizes. He now works on Shtandart as a sail trainer and first officer.He is looking for ways to integrate classic sailing ships with modern
reality. He holds the RYA Yachtmaster Offshore qualification.




PM von Kaenel (Michele Stephens), UK video
Michele von Kaenel is a veteran broadcaster and media consultant who helps our team stay active and move forward. Tall ships have always been a fascination of hers, so when this project surfaced she immediately applied to join the Team.


Maria Savelieva, RUAttracted by the project’s
challenge, Maria adds a corporate element to the team and tries to make sure we
work efficiently. 
Drive, competency and high targets are the cards she plays. She
is enthralled by the beauty of tall ships.



Pete Sedgwick, UK videoA designer and boat builder with marketing
experience, Pete offers us his
wisdom and broad knowledge in marketing and strategy. For the last 15 years he
has been building replica
traditional wooden boats. Now he is moving on to ships! He is up to his neck in
this BIG dream – helping to create the next famous British tea clipper.



Alina Radova, RUA natural sales executive,
Lina is happy to help with searching for construction sites and generating creative
crowdfunding ideas. She is the engine that keeps us going and she never stops
thinking out of the box. She speaks fluent Spanish, Portuguese, and links the project
with many countries.  


   






A brass plaques with the winners' names will be installed on the deck of the Cutty Sark 2.  And, if you wish, we will publish an interview with you on all Cutty Sark 2Sail resources.









At this first stage, we need to find the best way to build the sailing clipper – preserving all the historic details, and satisfying modern safety and ecological requirements. It is not an easy task – most sailing ships experience difficulties nowadays, dealing with more and more complicated regulations, invented for large steel motor vessels.  We will employ the most experienced naval architects to produce top quality, detailed calculations and to prove that classical sailing ships have rights to exist today – without compromising safety.


It is also important to note that this work is necessary and will be extremely useful for all working sailing ships, developing the level of understanding between sail training ships and international maritime authorities.















If the new ship is a replica, why do we need to produce a new design?

The world has changed. Safety standards are different. What was normal sailing practice 150 years ago is not acceptable today.
To achieve the latest safety standards, it will be necessary to rearrange some internal details in the ship. For example: some machinery space is required for generators to provide power – for safety equipment that we are obliged to include, and things like a fridge and a freezer; domestic fresh, grey and black water purification systems will also be required; lifesaving equipment, including life rafts and specially designed small tug-boats which regulations demand be carried on board … and don’t forget the requisite launching equipment or the advanced anchor system - with extra anchors at the stern – which must all be designed and placed in a “concealed” fashion so they don't detract from the aesthetic integrity of a 19th century vessel.
The main hull, masts, spars, rigging and all operating aspects will be unchanged from those of the original ship. The new Cutty Sark will have modern equipment on board, everything to provide her with the highest levels of safety. And she has to be built as a pure sailing ship which is environmentally friendly and sound. 
These modern additions will be carefully placed so that they will not disrupt the historical integrity of the original clipper.
Where does the money go if this crowdfunding campaign is not
successful?
The
Cutty Sark2Sail Foundation retains the collected funds.Even if we do not
succeed in collecting sufficient money for the completion of the first project stage through this crowdfunding campaign, the donated money will still be used to start the
project.
The Cutty Sark2Sail Foundation retains this funding and will continue
raising funds from other sources until enough money has been raised to complete the first stage (design) and go on the following stages (construction, launching and putting out to sea). 
Where does the estimated figure come from?Is
it a draft figure or an exact calculation?
The cost for the design work is 105,000 Euros (110,500$). That is the definite figure received as a firm quotation from
a company of professional naval
architects.  
What is total cost of building such ship and how is it made
up?

The total cost of the project of 19-26M Euros is an estimate, based on analysis of similar projects in Europe and other countries throughout the world. A full detailed budget will be available after the
detailed design of the ship is complete.
The estimate consists of the following:

120K €: Ship design and approvals
4M €: Site preparation and building viewing/accommodation facilities
880K €: Timber: Teak (130m3) + Rock Elm  (200m3) etc.
13M €: Labour
4M €: Equipment and tooling
4M €: Overheads and contingency
Total: 26M €


How will you raise this money? 

After completion of the design we
will be able to detail schedules and budgets. We will go to large companies
(like tea importing companies, wool producers, etc.) with proposals for
cooperation in the field of marketing their products using ecologically clean
transportation.

We will also approach large TV companies, with proposals to create video productions of constructing and sailing Cutty Sark 2.  Additionally, we will be
approaching potential sponsors and donors, with a request to help in supporting the preservation of maritime
heritage and traditional skills.
What will happen if we don't collect the required amount? 
 We will simply try and try again, until we succeed. 
To what extent will the ship be modified,
modernized?Will it still be historically accurate after the modification?
The plan will preserve ALL
visible parts of the ship in their true historical appearance. The way the ship is to be used will adhere to
traditional methods as much as possible. However, in the hold we will
hide a modern power
unit to produce electricity for state of the art navigation systems, and communication. All water & sewage purification systems, as well as up
to date safety systems will also be included on board. We will make these modifications in such a way that people’s impression of Cutty Sark 2
as the original vessel will not be compromised. We have successful achieved this previously when
designing the frigate Shtandart.
Are there professionals
in the Cutty Sark 2Sail Team who have relevant knowledge/experience?
We have people with considerable experience in building and
sailing traditional sailing ships. We also have team
members with marketing and project management expertise. We will enlist other professionals for the areas where
the team experience is lacking. Just to give you a glimpse:
Captain Vladimir Martus is a qualified
Naval Architect with deep sea sailing experience as a captain, and has Yacht Master
Instructor qualifications. He has built three large wooden replica
ships on his own and he has considerable
experience of the  most European
traditional sailing ships projects (Batavia, De Delft, Tenacious, Lord Nelson, HMS Trincomalee,
Gotheborg and Hermione).
Have you
carried out research; will Cutty Sark 2 be popular for sailing?
There is a definite demand for
ecological awareness and returning to our historical roots.
Cutty Sark 2 is going to create an information flow to keep people aware of good alternatives regarding the reducion of pollution and CO2 emissions. She will regenerate the skills and knowledge of past generation of
sailors. 
The detailed research on how much interest she will
attract is still on-going, but when we see the figures
of people attending maritime festivals, when we see queues of people waiting to visit traditional ships,
we think it is a definite sign that Cutty Sark 2 will have no difficulty in
attracting an audience and supporters.

Where will the new Cutty Sark be built?

We have
considered several possible places, and are now preparing a detailed survey to finalise on the best location.
Priorities for defining the best place to settle our museum shipyard are: 
1. We expect
the local
community to “adopt” the Cutty Sark 2Sail project as their own, with
friendly support on all levels: local authorities, construction and planning, tourism departments etc;  
2. Ideal place should have a potential for bringing in a lot
of visitors; 
3. Preferably, it should be a nice and interesting place for volunteers to come and
spend 4-8 weeks helping to the project.  
4. Above all, it must be
technical possibilities to build the ship, launch her and take her to out to
sea.  

The decision had not been made yet. We are in process of collecting
further information from many possible locations.



Where is Shtandart now? Is she sailing?


Yes, the exact replica of the 18th century wooden
frigate is still in active use. She has been sailing almost all year round, for
the last 16 years. Our team is actually using the experience and lessons
received from their experience with Shtandart to put into Cutty Sark 2 project.

story:
The Honey Bee Portal 

(San Antonio, Texas)

Fact: The number of bees is decreasing all over the world.

The use of pesticides, habitat destruction, nutrition deficit, drought, air pollution and global warming, among some other factors, are killing our bees. Why is this important?  Because without bees, life as we know it would no longer be possible. That simple.

According to Greenpeace, bees perform about 80 percent of all pollination worldwide. Without them, fruit, trees, plants, flowers or vegetables -90% of the key sources of food for humans- might not be available for an indeterminate amount of time. And although some few pollinators out there might feel compelled to take over for the disappearing bees' jobs, there are no guarantees that they would successfully perform all the duties of these amazing insects. 

Imagine for a moment, what would happen if bees would disappear completely?  

     

Pretty scary, uh?

We can stop this. We HAVE to stop this. Not only for us but for all the future generations.

INTRODUCING: THE HONEY BEE PORTAL

We are a group of bee-conscious people whose main mission is to educate the public about the plight of the honeybee and energize efforts to help bees make a comeback. 

Since June of 2012, we have been working on a tracking system that would allow us to put this project into motion.  As you may know, the decline in numbers of the bees is a very serious issue for humanity and it's time we take action to protect them. Part of this effort involves the development of

A very user-friendly app and a honeybee health database.

The core objective of The Honey Bee Portal  is to develop a honeybee health database which will contain data collected by Beekeepers, students, organizations, and scientists, as well as data from other honeybee health monitoring projects. Once the database has been developed, web-based tools and phone apps will be created to provide beekeepers convenient access to the system so that they can generate personalized management reports. These reports will utilize survey data to compare the success and failure of different management plans to suggest which plan is best suited to the needs of an individual beekeeper. In this way, the project uses beekeepers’ real world experience to solve beekeepers’ real world problems.  

The portal will help link the public to bee hives by allowing users to adopt a hive or to manage an existing one. Through this portal, you will be able to view your hive, collect information about it, and share useful information with other owners, scientists, and universities engaged in bee studies. 

This vital network will not only help raise awareness about bees and provide a platform for action to help bees make a comeback, it intends to become a wholesome community with no borders and accurate real-time information to make timely decisions to help bees grow strong as they  perform their own mission in this world. 

With this portal, you will: 

1. Track and access a wealth of information that no other app is able to provide.

2. Become part of a worldwide community that has your same interests and a common goal.

3. Participate actively in a worth-full mission to save not only the bees but also the world.

4. Become an urban beekeeper yourself!

        You can keep tabs on your hive's activity with the touch of one button. 

Here it is how it works:

When you first register with the Honey Bee Portal, you will fill out a form that will allow us to collect data that we will use to create and provide accurate stats. Some of the information we will need includes, but not limited to: 

  1. Name
  2. Address
  3. Postcode
  4. County
  5. Country
  6. Role (Beekeeper, Student, Scientist, Supporter, etc.)
  7. List of diseases, pest and parasites, if any.
  8. Treatments used
  9. Time and dates with issues on hive or hives.

All the collected information will be displayed in an easy-to-read format.

Taking notes while making an inspection of your hives will be like taking snapshots which can help track the progress of your hives.

Not only will you be able to record data, but take photos and store them in the cloud for later reference. 

By using the Honey Bee Portal you will be able to log information to help foresee any potential problems before they occur, and troubleshoot when they do. Just imagine how by connecting your information with thousands of other beekeepers will aid you to develop a better defense against pest and diseases!

Think of this. With this portal, you could know in real-time when a nearby hive has just become infected with the Varroa mite (or worse!)  

Knowing in advance can help you take the necessary steps to prevent the spread of pathogens and parasites. You would be connected to people who are studying fungus that kills the varroa mite without any chemicals, or the best place to set a bee hive in a wet area. 

The options are endless when it comes to all the ways this portal can help you protect your bees and learn more about them! 

With the Honey Bee Portal, you will have access to all types of data in real-time, no matter where you are! From migrations to the increasing or decreasing of honeybees' presence. No beekeeper is alike and that’s what makes this tool so valuable. Just select an area that you would like to monitor and see how yours or your friends' bee hives are doing. The more powerful thing of this community portal is that the more you use it, the more relevant and efficient it will become!

It's like being part of a hive that is connected throughout the world where all members strive to do things better, easier, safer and smarter. 

With this technology, together, we will change how we manage the honeybees to ensure its survival as well as our own. 

  1. Track your hives or any other hive. If you choose to monitor your own hives, The Honey Bee Portal will feed you with any collected data that The Honey Bee Portal members have added.
  2. Create your own group of beekeeper friends. When choosing to create your own group you can pick as many as you like. Everyone will be able to share information.
  3. Connect with paleontologist or mix it up. It's your Honey Bee Hotel Portal!

Let's talk about Network Security!

As you know, having a network portal makes everyone a little "shaky". The major concern is to know if "my information is safe." Rest assure that we are taking every precaution there is to ensure that your information is completely safe. The Honey Bee Hotel Portal will not require Social Security Numbers or birthday info. Remember, it's all about the HoneyBees! The system is set up to take in information and produce helpful data about the honey bee. 

And just should you were wondering, we are neither a government funded agency nor have any ties to a government organization and we certainly don't plan on becoming part of one. We are true believers in this cause and will keep any information private, confidential, and protected.

Your support will have long legs! 

The money that we need will be used to fund the researchers, database system, coding, advisors and field agents. We will collaborate with both domestic and international initiatives to make the greatest impact and to work with beekeepers across the globe. 

We calculate that once in the market, The Honey Bee Portal will have a monthly cost of $19.99 for a one-year subscription. So, imagine how much you will be saving if you become part of our earlier supporters.

Consider Becoming an Urban Beekeeper!

Along with the Portal, we will be able to promote the development of urban beekeepers! Once we have finished with our design and testing, we will offer it to anyone that would like to start their own Bee Hive. This stage of the project will be known as The Honey Bee Hotel. 

The Honey Bee Hotel will have step by step instructions, contact information and much more to get you started! 

Can you see yourself? We can!

Support Levels

We have a variety of support and sponsor levels to get you involved!

Not just for you, but also for all those you care for!

Dollar Bee $1

One dollar can go so far! You can help improve, transform, and make a difference with just $1 dollar. Many people don't think a dollar is worth all that much these days, but that doesn't mean that it's worthless. That one dollar that you donate will be used to protect the honeybee. So, consider donating at least $1! 

$5 Dollar Sticker Supporter Bee

For every $5 dollar you donate, you will get a sticker for your car or your bike... or even your hive to show you are a HoneyBee supporter. Get one for you or for your friend and help us set this portal in motion!

$20 Bee Early Bird Special

As part of the Early Bird Special, you will receive a 1-year subscription with updates to the HoneyBee Hotel Portal.  This is a great money-savings opportunity. The Portal will connect you to a database of professional beekeepers or friends who keep bees.  You will have the opportunity to ask questions and receive suggestions on what works and what does not.

$35 Bee Suporter

At the Bee Supporter level, you will receive a 1 year subscription with updates which will connect you to a database of beekeepers who can help you if needed, and you will receive a sticker with our logo that will officially make you part of the HoneyBee Portal! 

$60 Drone Bee Supporter

At the Drone-Bee level, you will receive our chassis T-Shirt with our logo that will get your friend to stop and ask, "what is that?" giving you the perfect chance to tell them how you're helping to save the honeybees. Also, you'll get a 1-year subscription to The Honey Bee Portal and its updates while being connected to a database of professional and amateur beekeepers, who can aid you with any information you may want to get.

$80 Bee Hive Adopter

As a Bee Hive Adopter, you'll get a 1-year subscription with updates and a Honey Bee Portal patch. You will also be able to see the hive you have adopted and you will be asked to join the beta testing team when the portal is ready. As a beta tester, you will be able to conduct tests at your location with our hives.

$150 Worker Bee 

At the Worker Bee level, you will receive a 1-year subscription and updates, which will connect you to our wonderful database of professional and amateur beekeepers. Receive one of our unique The Honey Bee Portal patch to show your support along with one(1)  100 ml jar of honey from one of our participant Honey Bee Hotel hives. Your name will also be displayed on our website as a Worker Bee Supporter!

$2000 Honey Bee Hive Builder

At this level, your donation will allow us to purchase one FlowHIve for the 10 location and the material needed to build the fence for protection, a camera, and a solar system. Your name will be on the Honey Bee Hotel, with the option to join the beta testing for The Honey Bee Portal. You will receive a 2-year subscription and five (5) jars of 100 ml of honey when beta testing is completed. Also, receive 2 Honey Bee Supporter patches and have your name displayed on our website as a Honey Bee Builder.

$3000 Queen Bee Sponsor

At this level, your donation will allow us to purchase one FlowHive for the 10 location and the material needed to build the fence for protection, a camera, and a solar system. Your name will be on the Honey Bee Hotel, with the option to join the beta testing for The Honey Bee Portal. You will receive a 3-year subscription and five (5) jars of 100 ml of honey when beta testing is completed. Also, we will alter the design of the hive to mimic your store or home. Receive three (3) Honey Bee Supporter patches and have your name displayed on our website as a Queen Bee Sponsor.

Thank you so much for taking a look at our project and hope you will consider becoming part of our great group of supporters!!!

The Honey Bee Portal (San Antonio, Texas)Fact: The number of bees is decreasing all over the world.The use of pesticides, habitat destruction, nutrition deficit, drought, air pollution and global warming, among some other factors, are killing our bees. Why is this important?  Because without bees, life as we know it would no longer be possible. That simple.According to Greenpeace, bees perform about 80 percent of all pollination worldwide. Without them, fruit, trees, plants, flowers or vegetables -90% of the key sources of food for humans- might not be available for an indeterminate amount of time. And although some few pollinators out there might feel compelled to take over for the disappearing bees' jobs, there are no guarantees that they would successfully perform all the duties of these amazing insects. Imagine for a moment, what would happen if bees would disappear completely?       Pretty scary, uh?We can stop this. We HAVE to stop this. Not only for us but for all the future generations.INTRODUCING: THE HONEY BEE PORTALWe are a group of bee-conscious people whose main mission is to educate the public about the plight of the honeybee and energize efforts to help bees make a comeback. Since June of 2012, we have been working on a tracking system that would allow us to put this project into motion.  As you may know, the decline in numbers of the bees is a very serious issue for humanity and it's time we take action to protect them. Part of this effort involves the development ofA very user-friendly app and a honeybee health database.

The core objective of The Honey Bee Portal  is to develop a honeybee health database which will contain data collected by Beekeepers, students, organizations, and scientists, as well as data from other honeybee health monitoring projects. Once the database has been developed, web-based tools and phone apps will be created to provide beekeepers convenient access to the system so that they can generate personalized management reports. These reports will utilize survey data to compare the success and failure of different management plans to suggest which plan is best suited to the needs of an individual beekeeper. In this way, the project uses beekeepers’ real world experience to solve beekeepers’ real world problems.  
The portal will help link the public to bee hives by allowing users to adopt a hive or to manage an existing one. Through this portal, you will be able to view your hive, collect information about it, and share useful information with other owners, scientists, and universities engaged in bee studies. 
This vital network will not only help raise awareness about bees and provide a platform for action to help bees make a comeback, it intends to become a wholesome community with no borders and accurate real-time information to make timely decisions to help bees grow strong as they  perform their own mission in this world. 


With this portal, you will: 
1. Track and access a wealth of information that no other app is able to provide.
2. Become part of a worldwide community that has your same interests and a common goal.
3. Participate actively in a worth-full mission to save not only the bees but also the world.
4. Become an urban beekeeper yourself!
        You can keep tabs on your hive's activity with the touch of one button. Here it is how it works:When you first register with the Honey Bee Portal, you will fill out a form that will allow us to collect data that we will use to create and provide accurate stats. Some of the information we will need includes, but not limited to:  Name
Address
Postcode
County
Country
Role (Beekeeper, Student, Scientist, Supporter, etc.)
List of diseases, pest and parasites, if any.
Treatments used
Time and dates with issues on hive or hives. 




All the collected information will be displayed in an easy-to-read format.

Taking notes while making an inspection of your hives will be like taking snapshots which can help track the progress of your hives.

Not only will you be able to record data, but take photos and store them in the cloud for later reference. By using the Honey Bee Portal you will be able to log information to help foresee any potential problems before they occur, and troubleshoot when they do. Just imagine how by connecting your information with thousands of other beekeepers will aid you to develop a better defense against pest and diseases!



Think of this. With this portal, you could know in real-time when a nearby hive has just become infected with the Varroa mite (or worse!)  
Knowing in advance can help you take the necessary steps to prevent the spread of pathogens and parasites. You would be connected to people who are studying fungus that kills the varroa mite without any chemicals, or the best place to set a bee hive in a wet area. 



The options are endless when it comes to all the ways this portal can help you protect your bees and learn more about them! 
With the Honey Bee Portal, you will have access to all types of data in real-time, no matter where you are! From migrations to the increasing or decreasing of honeybees' presence. No beekeeper is alike and that’s what makes this tool so valuable. Just select an area that you would like to monitor and see how yours or your friends' bee hives are doing. The more powerful thing of this community portal is that the more you use it, the more relevant and efficient it will become!
It's like being part of a hive that is connected throughout the world where all members strive to do things better, easier, safer and smarter. 



With this technology, together, we will change how we manage the honeybees to ensure its survival as well as our own. 





Track your hives or any other hive. If you choose to monitor your own hives, The Honey Bee Portal will feed you with any collected data that The Honey Bee Portal members have added.
Create your own group of beekeeper friends. When choosing to create your own group you can pick as many as you like. Everyone will be able to share information.
Connect with paleontologist or mix it up. It's your Honey Bee Hotel Portal!




Let's talk about Network Security!
As you know, having a network portal makes everyone a little "shaky". The major concern is to know if "my information is safe." Rest assure that we are taking every precaution there is to ensure that your information is completely safe. The Honey Bee Hotel Portal will not require Social Security Numbers or birthday info. Remember, it's all about the HoneyBees! The system is set up to take in information and produce helpful data about the honey bee. 
And just should you were wondering, we are neither a government funded agency nor have any ties to a government organization and we certainly don't plan on becoming part of one. We are true believers in this cause and will keep any information private, confidential, and protected.


Your support will have long legs! 
The money that we need will be used to fund the researchers, database system, coding, advisors and field agents. We will collaborate with both domestic and international initiatives to make the greatest impact and to work with beekeepers across the globe. 
We calculate that once in the market, The Honey Bee Portal will have a monthly cost of $19.99 for a one-year subscription. So, imagine how much you will be saving if you become part of our earlier supporters.
Consider Becoming an Urban Beekeeper!
Along with the Portal, we will be able to promote the development of urban beekeepers! Once we have finished with our design and testing, we will offer it to anyone that would like to start their own Bee Hive. This stage of the project will be known as The Honey Bee Hotel. 


The Honey Bee Hotel will have step by step instructions, contact information and much more to get you started! 
Can you see yourself? We can!


Support Levels
We have a variety of support and sponsor levels to get you involved!


Not just for you, but also for all those you care for!






Dollar Bee $1
One dollar can go so far! You can help improve, transform, and make a difference with just $1 dollar. Many people don't think a dollar is worth all that much these days, but that doesn't mean that it's worthless. That one dollar that you donate will be used to protect the honeybee. So, consider donating at least $1! $5 Dollar Sticker Supporter BeeFor every $5 dollar you donate, you will get a sticker for your car or your bike... or even your hive to show you are a HoneyBee supporter. Get one for you or for your friend and help us set this portal in motion!
$20 Bee Early Bird Special
As part of the Early Bird Special, you will receive a 1-year subscription with updates to the HoneyBee Hotel Portal.  This is a great money-savings opportunity. The Portal will connect you to a database of professional beekeepers or friends who keep bees.  You will have the opportunity to ask questions and receive suggestions on what works and what does not.




$35 Bee Suporter
At the Bee Supporter level, you will receive a 1 year subscription with updates which will connect you to a database of beekeepers who can help you if needed, and you will receive a sticker with our logo that will officially make you part of the HoneyBee Portal! 








$60 Drone Bee Supporter


At the Drone-Bee level, you will receive our chassis T-Shirt with our logo that will get your friend to stop and ask, "what is that?" giving you the perfect chance to tell them how you're helping to save the honeybees. Also, you'll get a 1-year subscription to The Honey Bee Portal and its updates while being connected to a database of professional and amateur beekeepers, who can aid you with any information you may want to get.



$80 Bee Hive Adopter
As a Bee Hive Adopter, you'll get a 1-year subscription with updates and a Honey Bee Portal patch. You will also be able to see the hive you have adopted and you will be asked to join the beta testing team when the portal is ready. As a beta tester, you will be able to conduct tests at your location with our hives.



$150 Worker Bee 
At the Worker Bee level, you will receive a 1-year subscription and updates, which will connect you to our wonderful database of professional and amateur beekeepers. Receive one of our unique The Honey Bee Portal patch to show your support along with one(1)  100 ml jar of honey from one of our participant Honey Bee Hotel hives. Your name will also be displayed on our website as a Worker Bee Supporter!


$2000 Honey Bee Hive Builder
At this level, your donation will allow us to purchase one FlowHIve for the 10 location and the material needed to build the fence for protection, a camera, and a solar system. Your name will be on the Honey Bee Hotel, with the option to join the beta testing for The Honey Bee Portal. You will receive a 2-year subscription and five (5) jars of 100 ml of honey when beta testing is completed. Also, receive 2 Honey Bee Supporter patches and have your name displayed on our website as a Honey Bee Builder.


$3000 Queen Bee Sponsor


At this level, your donation will allow us to purchase one FlowHive for the 10 location and the material needed to build the fence for protection, a camera, and a solar system. Your name will be on the Honey Bee Hotel, with the option to join the beta testing for The Honey Bee Portal. You will receive a 3-year subscription and five (5) jars of 100 ml of honey when beta testing is completed. Also, we will alter the design of the hive to mimic your store or home. Receive three (3) Honey Bee Supporter patches and have your name displayed on our website as a Queen Bee Sponsor.



Thank you so much for taking a look at our project and hope you will consider becoming part of our great group of supporters!!!

story:
Organization: Sundarban Green Environment Association 

Place: Kumirmari (Gosaba)

Mission and vision:

The story of the region and its people is same throughout. Endangered traditional livelihood [caused by heavy erosion triggering loss of farm-land; forest-resources like wood, honey etc. being unavailable either for the strict enforcement of the present laws, or being scanty due to over-exploitation; crab, fish and other aquatic resources being scanty than earlier] is not peculiar to one or two blocks of the zone, but to the whole of the region. The mission of this organization is to restore the opportunity of livelihood to the local inhabitants. To fulfil this aim, it has defined the following objectives:

·  To restore the nature of the region, deteriorated by over-exploitation through decades-

o  Through mangrove afforestation: As per government records, here in the Sundarban area, about 60 species of mangrove thrive. Our endeavour is to increase their number in balanced proportion throughout the region as observed in nature so that the afforestation drive remains sustainable, and men may bear the fruit of the forest resources from their very villages.

o  By protecting the natural embankments of the estuaries, thus, actually protecting the farmlands, one of the most important provisions of livelihood in the region that lie next to the banks: This is to be done in a manner that is sustainable and eco-friendly. Hence, no artificial embankments are to be erected, rather careful plantation of mangrove is to be adopted to hold the banks strong against the water and wind, and to make their slope gradients gently gradual.

o  By restoring the aquatic environment at the estuaries: Polluting factors like oil-spill from boats and trawlers or industrial waste being carried by the river Hooghly are right now beyond our scope of control. But apart from that, again, calculated mangrove plantation on the banks of the rivers and estuaries of the region can restore the population of the crabs and fish back by providing them their food to grow and shelter to thrive. At the same time, control of plastic waste into the water from the locality is to be achieved to accelerate the rate of restoration.

o  By exploring newer ways of eco-friendly sustainability in terms of livelihood: Developing local handicrafts utilizing natural objects like fiber etc. locally procured, commercial utilization of the inland water bodies which otherwise are used only for domestic purpose, initiating responsible tourism, promoting apiary, enhancing the scope of the cultivable land by promoting and reviving the cultivation of the long-abandoned indigenous saline water resistant variety of paddy etc. is to be planned methodically so that the scope of livelihood generation increases at the same place without affecting the nature.

·  To restore the nature of the population, turned dull by lack of proper education-

o  By awareness campaigns: Regular campaigns are to be organized throughout the region, ensuring the participation of the maximum of the younger generation, so that they grow up with a concern for the ecology of the largest mangrove region of the world, and they live with a cause to protect this richness of nature they are gifted with for providing them with the opportunity of livelihood.

o  By participatory programmes: Regular programmes should be planned and executed to ensure the participation of the local population as volunteers in the various projects undertaken, mostly the younger generation, for only awareness does not generate compassion, rather involvement does the trick. Nature cannot be restored and pro-nature livelihood cannot be generated as well as maintained without a sympathetic and compassionate population thriving in it.

The vision is the great fusion which we dream- here, the population will live and grow with its rich natural environment, not exploiting it, rather exploring it to find newer means to develop the region,  thereby grow themselves. Men here will live as a part of nature, without asking the question of being superior or taming the wild forces without understanding them. The region will exist as a true ‘biosphere’, as is meant actually by the term. We also love to dream that one day the people here will lead the world by their example of living and leading a life that co-exists with and along nature, by hinting at ways to combat each and every human endeavour to manipulate the nature to its ultimate destruction.

Action area:

Current:

Kumirmari Gram Panchayet, Gosaba Block, Canning Sub-division, South 24 Parganas, West Bengal, India.

Location: The villages of Kumirmari Gram Panchayat are surrounded by River Raymangal and River Sarsa, Korankhali.

Population: The island is the home place for about [ ] people, out of which, more than 80% is SC/ST community. Most of them are typical poverty-stricken rural folk living in mud huts with thatched roofs.

Occupation and economy: Farming and fishing along with crab-hunting are the bread earning provision for most of the population residing in the place. Most of the farmers are marginal farmers, depending upon less than three bighas [I acre] of land for his family yielding once annually. If the labour cost is excluded, a year with a generous yield of paddy will let them earn a maximum of twelve-fifteen thousand INR annually per acre. For the small fishermen and crab hunter of the island, the situation is poorer. With the advancement of technology, the able fishermen hunt the mouth of the rivers and adjoining bay such that a very little fish can make their way to the estuaries hunted by these small fishermen. Moreover, most of them are without any land to cultivate. Hence, the population here is mostly below poverty level, striving hard to meet their both ends, and finally, opting for migration, either seasonal or permanent.

Infrastructure: The GP [Gram Panchayat] is without any electricity till date, the roads are mostly kaccha, and three are brick-layed. Solar electricity are used as alternative source of energy, though the supercyclone ‘Aila’ has reached an immense injury to the solar panels installed.

Education: Two high schools, six primary schools and some ICDS centre cater to the educational need of the people.

Health: The people are to depend on three health sub-centres [these are centres attented by trained nurses and ASHA workers and are without any doctors] in case of any medical emergencies. The whole island is without any medical shop, or any trained doctor’s chamber. However, some quacks are here to carry the burden.

Culture: Traditionally, the people here celebrate the Bonobibi Utsab in the month of January. However, recently people are getting more enthusiastic about celebrating the Durga-Puja or Kali-Puja. In fact, Bonobibi Utsab has been able to retain its importance only among those who still frequent the nearby forest area to hunt its resources.

Proposed:

Chhoto Mollakhali Gram Panchayat and Kachukhali Gram Panchayat: two adjoining GP of Kumirmari.

Activities: 

Afforestation: volunteers approached, survey done, seeds procured, fund raised, volunteers participated, the activity, time period.

The local people were approached informally at different local hangouts, particularly the youth were targeted. The crisis of sustenance was discussed, and the ways of probable solutions were also shared. With those who shared a common view, the older generation of the island was also approached. Their guidance proved to be very useful in selecting the spots where we intended to start the plantation programme first. Local schools and clubs were also approached. The subject was shared with the local school children too in order to make them aware of the facts. The local clubs as well as the schools provided a needed thrust to the ongoing discussion of the crisis by incorporating the subject in both academic competitions like quiz, debate, essay-writing etc. and cultural activities like staging a drama or composing a poem or song.

The forest department of the region and sub-division was approached first for seeds and saplings needed for the purpose. However, as their nursery was not equipped for the purpose, it was decided to collect the seeds on our own. The elders again came forward pointing out spots where the seeds from the forest are washed ashore. As per their guidance, they were collected during the low tides with group of volunteers from the villages. Moreover, the local fishermen were approached to handover the seeds that are caught at their nets, which they mostly used as fuel to burn for cooking purpose. This approach also fulfilled the objective of promoting awareness, for many turned to share our purpose when told the reason of collecting the seeds.

The plantation programme started in the month of April and continued to September in the year 2013 amidst a mixed reaction from the public in general. Some actively volunteered; some watched passively; some threw some valuable suggestion about the planting job while passing by; and some commented to demoralize. However, mostly people said and worked positively, and the local residents tirelessly kept their cattle’s grazing under control and protected the young saplings after they germinated.

The process is still in continuation, and the rate has increased as more and more volunteers are pouring in every year, and are being inspired to turn the spots at or near their land similarly green. Many, both individually as well as institutionally [particularly the local clubs] approach us to carry on the programme at or near their premises when they are on or near the embankments.

Protection of embankment and thereby cultivable land along with dwelling houses in the villages: A stretch of 4.5 km embankment of river Sarsa has been covered with twenty thousand surviving mangrove out of more than twenty seven thousand planted, thereby protecting the stretch from both water and wind. It is being anticipated that securing this stretch of embankment, at least a population of 600 families are being protected with their cultivable land and domicile.

Restoration of the aquatic environment in the area: Afforestation in the said stretch has helped a lot to restore the aquatic environment, by providing needed habitat to the aquatic flora and fauna. As a result, the red crabs, which used to frequent the places long long ago, have returned again, as the local residents are reporting themselves; and the seedlings of tiger prawn [collection of which is a popular way of earning in the region] are being reported to pour in this zone in more numbers than the adjoining places. Kartick Barman, a local resident reported us of having caught a lot of vetki and crabs particularly in the monsoon of 2015 from this very region. He cannot remember when he had such a fishing back last and that too, at his doorsteps. This year, he had not visited elsewhere for fishing, but is hunting through the jungle that is growing at his doorsteps. Other people have also reported about the increasing number of fishes like kan, pangash, dapur etc. in the zone.

Reviving the long abandoned indigenous varieties of paddy: 12 farming families have ventured to cultivate 16 long abandoned indigenous varieties of paddy in a stretch of 30 bighas [10 acres] of land. They have returned to this long forgotten salinity resistant varieties of paddy partially at their fields again being burdened by the heavy cost of cultivating the high yielding varieties. Moreover, apart from the low cost involvement in this case, they are expecting a longer straw this time as bi-product which will in turn come very handy while thatching the roofs not only for its length, but also for its longivity.

Collaboration:  In collaboration with Rotaract Club of Heritage Engineering College, fifty poor families in this island without any proper provision of light for the dark hours are provided with solar lamps to enhance the feelings of humanity. It has also been decided that a health camp will be organized soon to promote awareness and to survey the public health condition in general empirically so that something can be planned accordingly for the villagers’ benefit.

Future plan: a) Discussions have started to make the most of the inland water bodies. About 15 families have stepped forward in order to learn the scientific techniques and ways to explore their ponds and pools to reap a better harvest. Our organization is in the process of negotiating experts for the purpose.

b) Starts practices of organic farming among 50 farmer

c) Initiatives are already undertaken to promote responsible eco-tourism in the area, with the objective of knowledge exchange mostly. Primary survey is complete for the purpose, and a number of eager host families are waiting to start their drive. Already they have gathered a first-hand experience in the job while they accommodated 9 students of sociology in two batches from Bosco Institute, Assam and Pune Institute, Maharashtra, visiting the area for academic knowledge exchange programme in the year 2014-15 for twenty and seven days respectively. Department of Environmental Science, University of Calcutta also frequents the area for similar academic purpose, and thus provides a boost to the initiative.

d) 200000 mangrove plantation throughout the river embankment of Kumirmari gram panchayat area. This will protect our land from the river erosion.   

Why me?

After completing a 2 year Create to Inspire Fellowship last year, creating artistic products with more than 200 young people of Kolkata that would make the environment a trending subject, I have decided that one of my missions being an artist and arts manager would be to continuously support those who have dedicated their lives to the environment and its safekeeping ! 

Pranabesh is no outsider to Sunderbans, but a son of the soil. he has been a victim of the issues himself discussed above like any other youth of the time in his locality. Hence,he has realized the concerns himself with his own life and experiences, instead of learning about them from others’ experiences.

He himself, along with his other mates have tried to combat the situation as per their own understanding of the issues, and I must say that they are already being rewarded in the process by nature itself. It proves that their experiences were explored properly, and their initiatives to combat the situation were not mistaken.

But they need support, and a lot of it. You my friend can join hands by initially contributing Rs 2 to buy a mangrove sapling for his afforestation drive. Then visit him in Sunderban and come forward with expertise, skills, people, funds and whatever other support you can offer. Support The Mangrove Man to do what he is doing ! Lets do our part !


Some links that have documented Pranabesh's work !

http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/Green-crusader-on-mangrove-mission/articleshow/46788663.cms

https://grin.news/can-this-man-save-the-sundarbans-2940ea1bc407#.x8r9r1knw

http://www.theoptimistcitizen.com/man-for-mangr...

Activities:  
Afforestation: volunteers approached,
survey done, seeds procured, fund raised, volunteers participated, the
activity, time period.
The local people were
approached informally at different local hangouts, particularly the youth were
targeted. The crisis of sustenance was discussed, and the ways of probable
solutions were also shared. With those who shared a common view, the older generation
of the island was also approached. Their guidance proved to be very useful in
selecting the spots where we intended to start the plantation programme first.
Local schools and clubs were also approached. The subject was shared with the
local school children too in order to make them aware of the facts. The local
clubs as well as the schools provided a needed thrust to the ongoing discussion
of the crisis by incorporating the subject in both academic competitions like
quiz, debate, essay-writing etc. and cultural activities like staging a drama
or composing a poem or song. 
The forest department of
the region and sub-division was approached first for seeds and saplings needed
for the purpose. However, as their nursery was not equipped for the purpose, it
was decided to collect the seeds on our own. The elders again came forward
pointing out spots where the seeds from the forest are washed ashore. As per
their guidance, they were collected during the low tides with group of
volunteers from the villages. Moreover, the local fishermen were approached to
handover the seeds that are caught at their nets, which they mostly used as
fuel to burn for cooking purpose. This approach also fulfilled the objective of
promoting awareness, for many turned to share our purpose when told the reason
of collecting the seeds.
The plantation programme
started in the month of April and continued to September in the year 2013
amidst a mixed reaction from the public in general. Some actively volunteered;
some watched passively; some threw some valuable suggestion about the planting
job while passing by; and some commented to demoralize. However, mostly people
said and worked positively, and the local residents tirelessly kept their
cattle’s grazing under control and protected the young saplings after they
germinated.
The process is still in
continuation, and the rate has increased as more and more volunteers are
pouring in every year, and are being inspired to turn the spots at or near
their land similarly green. Many, both individually as well as institutionally
[particularly the local clubs] approach us to carry on the programme at or near
their premises when they are on or near the embankments.
Protection of embankment
and thereby cultivable land along with dwelling houses in the villages: A
stretch of 4.5 km embankment of river Sarsa has been covered with twenty
thousand surviving mangrove out of more than twenty seven thousand planted,
thereby protecting the stretch from both water and wind. It is being
anticipated that securing this stretch of embankment, at least a population of
600 families are being protected with their cultivable land and domicile.
Restoration of the aquatic
environment in the area:
Afforestation in the said stretch has helped a lot to restore the aquatic environment,
by providing needed habitat to the aquatic flora and fauna. As a result, the
red crabs, which used to frequent the places long long ago, have returned
again, as the local residents are reporting themselves; and the seedlings of
tiger prawn [collection of which is a popular way of earning in the region] are
being reported to pour in this zone in more numbers than the adjoining places.
Kartick Barman, a local resident reported us of having caught a lot of vetki
and crabs particularly in the monsoon of 2015 from this very region. He cannot
remember when he had such a fishing back last and that too, at his doorsteps.
This year, he had not visited elsewhere for fishing, but is hunting through the
jungle that is growing at his doorsteps. Other people have also reported about
the increasing number of fishes like kan, pangash, dapur etc. in the zone.
Reviving the long abandoned
indigenous varieties of paddy: 12 farming families have ventured to cultivate 16 long
abandoned indigenous varieties of paddy in a stretch of 30 bighas [10 acres] of
land. They have returned to this long forgotten salinity resistant varieties of
paddy partially at their fields again being burdened by the heavy cost of
cultivating the high yielding varieties. Moreover, apart from the low cost
involvement in this case, they are expecting a longer straw this time as
bi-product which will in turn come very handy while thatching the roofs not
only for its length, but also for its longivity.
Collaboration:  In collaboration with Rotaract Club of
Heritage Engineering College, fifty poor families in this island without any
proper provision of light for the dark hours are provided with solar lamps to
enhance the feelings of humanity. It has also been decided that a health camp
will be organized soon to promote awareness and to survey the public health
condition in general empirically so that something can be planned accordingly
for the villagers’ benefit.
Future plan: a) Discussions have
started to make the most of the inland water bodies. About 15 families have
stepped forward in order to learn the scientific techniques and ways to explore
their ponds and pools to reap a better harvest. Our organization is in the
process of negotiating experts for the purpose.
b) Starts practices of
organic farming among 50 farmer
c) Initiatives are already
undertaken to promote responsible eco-tourism in the area, with the objective
of knowledge exchange mostly. Primary survey is complete for the purpose, and a
number of eager host families are waiting to start their drive. Already they
have gathered a first-hand experience in the job while they accommodated 9
students of sociology in two batches from Bosco Institute, Assam and Pune
Institute, Maharashtra, visiting the area for academic knowledge exchange
programme in the year 2014-15 for twenty and seven days respectively.
Department of Environmental Science, University of Calcutta also frequents the
area for similar academic purpose, and thus provides a boost to the initiative.
d) 200000 mangrove
plantation throughout the river embankment of Kumirmari gram panchayat area.
This will protect our land from the river erosion.   
Why me?
After completing a 2 year Create to Inspire Fellowship last year, creating artistic products with more than 200 young people of Kolkata that would make the environment a trending subject, I have decided that one of my missions being an artist and arts manager would be to continuously support those who have dedicated their lives to the environment and its safekeeping ! Pranabesh is no outsider to Sunderbans, but
a son of the soil. he has been a victim of the issues himself discussed above
like any other youth of the time in his locality. Hence,he has realized the
concerns himself with his own life and experiences, instead of learning about
them from others’ experiences.
He himself, along with his other mates have tried to combat the situation as per their own understanding of
the issues, and I must say that they are already being rewarded in the process by
nature itself. It proves that their experiences were explored properly, and their initiatives to combat the situation were not mistaken. 
But they need support, and a lot of it. You my friend can join hands by initially contributing Rs 2 to buy a mangrove sapling for his afforestation drive. Then visit him in Sunderban and come forward with expertise, skills, people, funds and whatever other support you can offer. Support The Mangrove Man to do what he is doing ! Lets do our part !Some links that have documented Pranabesh's work !http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/Green-crusader-on-mangrove-mission/articleshow/46788663.cmshttps://grin.news/can-this-man-save-the-sundarbans-2940ea1bc407#.x8r9r1knwhttp://www.theoptimistcitizen.com/man-for-mangr...

story:
Getting carbon out of the atmosphere and into the soil  (carbon farming) mitigates climate change and reverses desertification (drought).  We have a program  that incorporates a huge amount of carbon in the soil in the first year. This program costs less money for the farmer to begin and makes the farmer more money per acre while regenerating the soil and providing nutritious food.   Without the microbe (microscopic soil life) inoculations that we do it often takes 3-5 years even using the other techniques involved with this system to get results.    The quickly increased carbon holding capacity which holds the moisture is the reason we can farm in the desert without irrigation.

Where many of us are overwhelmed by impending drought, starvation, desertification and climate change, this approach can solve these problems without government intervention or huge amounts of public funds.  These practices are actually less expensive to apply than the current industrial agriculture as it takes less equipment, less water, less labor and less external inputs to maintain these farms.  The start up costs are less than starting a vineyard.  We believe once farmers see how this approach works for them via our demonstration farm, they will be excited to learn and apply it on their own farms. 

Why this farm.

I (Charlotte Anthony) started Terra Lingua Farms after  2 years in India, where 70% of the farming is done without irrigation often with less than  20 inches of rain a year.  I learned in India quick ways to turn poor soils into carbon-rich fertile soil without adding any kind of fertilizer.   In India there are places where, each year, for hundreds of years,  the ground has becomes more fertile, in spite of harvesting a lot of produce.  

In India with the sheer numbers of people and most of the farmers describing  to me how they lacked the water they needed and how their neighbors had already given up farming, i lived among the symptoms underlying starvation, climate change, drought, desertification.  Soon after my return, I had an ah hah moment, recognizing that these are all related to what i now understand to be the industrial farming system.

Being a life time farmer, I decided to find a place in the desert, with little water and show how this farming system could solve all these problems.  Rather than looking for prime soil,  as most farmers  do, I looked for soil which needed regenerating and where there was little rain fall.   I found a place in Eastern Oregon with a couple that have 500 acres.  I leased 20 acres of land and drastically shifted my life to move here.  I  gathered  my personal resources,  and with the help of several people who have been impressed over the years with my work started this farm.  It is not easy.  It is isolated here with the closest supermarket or place to buy tools  1.5 hours away.   My friends are 5 hours away in Eugene. Most every day, especially when it is hot,  I reaffirm to myself how blessed I am to be able to demonstrate a way to alleviate some of the major ills on this planet at this time.

Experience:

 I worked in  orchards,  mentoring with one of New England's foremost orchardists, Bill Darrow.    I have  a 20 year history working with  permaculture and natural farming systems.  I started a  Community Supported Agriculture project in Paonia, Co.  I coordinated the permaculture demonstration gardens in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina.   With my team, I started  more than 650 gardens for people in Eugene, Oregon with a pay it forward system. I helped create 7 food forests in Oregon and California. Through all of this I have been using microbial inoculations effectively in all types of soils.

I helped many farmers in India set up swales, ponds, etc. to hold water in their soils and revitalize their wells.   Once  I understood traditional Indian farming, I helped land owners who had lost this knowledge establish these systems on their farms.

What is different about our system?

The difference between what we are doing and industrial agriculture is huge.   Industrial agriculture treats the soil as a blank slate to which they add what science and commercial fertilizer companies indicate the plants need to grow. They take out all the trees and habitat for insects (90% of which are beneficial). The chemicals used cause the plants to take up as much as 5 times the water. Since the plants have only a part of what they really need, they attract insects and viruses.  Weeds are nature's way to begin to balance the soil.

In our system, we rely on the living organisms  in the soil which partner with the plants giving them the fertilizer, the air and the water that they need even in low rainfall situations.   We do not desroy these organisms by tilling.

What do we actually do? 

We are creating an edible food forest.  This means we are mimicking forest conditions and growing food with trees as the primary focus.  A forest is a living system where  the soil gets more fertile every year.

We have a whole-systems approach, many things working together including: inoculating the soil with microbes, holding rainwater in the soil, dry land farming  (no irrigation), hedge rows, mulch beds, and planting many types of crops that nourish each other in a no till system.  This system creates fertile soil easily and quickly.  The microbes in the soil sequester carbon and this carbon feeds the crops.  There is little money spent on external inputs, no pesticides, no herbicides etc., leaving the farmer with a living wage.  Maybe more importantly, if enough acres around the world were to use this system, desertification would be reversed and climate change would be seriously mitigated.

If this system works so well, why aren’t all farmers doing it.

Farmers do not know about this system.  We are doing this demonstration farm to show farmers how they can  make good money (at least $5,000 an acre net) by the third year) at the same time that they regenerate their soil, allowing the land to supply food far into the future.   

Current industrial farming practices are decimating the soil, as well as initiating 35% of the carbon in the atmosphere.  Side effects to  humans and animals from chemicals including fertilizers, pesticides and herbicides are causing increasing medical and veterinary bills as well as reducing quality of life.

Right now this whole system approach to agriculture is not understood by most farmers.  Terra Lingua is a demonstration farm showing actual costs, yields and soil samples so farmers can understand how this works.  We are also a hands-on teaching facility for the finer points of the system.

Are there any existing farms using biologically based systems making incomes that would satisfy farmers.  

There are now farmers in the United States and around the world applying these principles effectively using animals.  It is a mob grazing system and is practiced by  farmers such as  Gabe Brown, Joel Salatin, Alan Savory and many others.  Our approach works with microfauna (microscopic animals and plants) rather than macrofauna (animals).  Not all farmers want to work with animals. Also we need to eat food other than just meat.  One farmer who did not use animals for meat or dairy in India was Narsanna Koppula.  We are demonstrating a system where fruit and nut trees, forest trees, herbs, vegetables, grains, legumes, and oil seeds nurture the earth and provide food and lumbar.

Carbon farming:  How do you reverse desertification (stop drought) and mitigate climate change with farming? 

Plants working with their microbial partners take C02 from the air and store carbon in the soil.  This is how the plants get their food (fertilizer).  One of the microbes, the mycorhizzals increase the length of the plant roots by as much as 10 times.  They also bring water and minerals from the surrounding plants.  This is how all plants were watered and fertilized before chemicals, including trees hundreds of feet tall.   

Unfarmed or not overgrazed soils, whether forest or prairie, have huge amounts of carbon stored in them. Once the soils are farmed with current tilling, fertilizing and irrigating methods, or degraded into desert through overgrazing, or removing all the trees, the carbon stores in the soil are released into the air as CO2.  A resource, the carbon in the soil, which has been a solution for millions of years, becomes a big part of the problem. With our system, the carbon in the soil is exponentially increased.  This means that the water-holding capacity as well as fertility of the soil is also exponentially increased. 

We have selected Terra Lingua Farm as our proving ground, with 8-15 inches of rain a year and degraded soils.  The place where the rubber meets the road for our system is to get the microbial content high enough to retain the water so that seeds can start and grow.  Many desert farmers are using irrigation.  We are not.  This means spraying with the microbes many times. The microbes need water and organic matter to multiply and we need to keep priming the pump so to speak, until the microbes take off.  Most importantly,  without the quickly increased carbon holding capacity the desert areas may not be able to be farmed.  With good microbial content the organic matter in the soil can go from 1% (often the case with industrial agriculture to 11%). 

The key to fertility in the soil is the microbes that are in that soil.  With the help of the microbes, any soil has all the available minerals needed to feed the plants.  The soil tests usually done measure what the soil has available without microbes.   Please see soil scientist, Elaine Ingham’s, ‘The Roots of Your Profits’ on YouTube if you’re curious about exactly how this works.

What We Need

We are leasing 20 acres of a 500-acre farm in Kimberly, Oregon.  We came here because we wanted to show how these methods would work in desert conditions.  Imagine how much more food could be grown around the world if we could grow food in the deserts.  We came to this particular land, as the land owners would like their land to be productive, and they would love to see their local community become prosperous.  The farming in these parts is mainly cattle for beef but, sadly, the farmers and/or spouses must take an extra paid job as their farms do not support them.

The land owner is allowing us to use some of his farm equipment and, when time permits, he is helping us with various projects such as chisel plowing of the fields (a first year practice which is used to hold water in the soil and does not involve turning the soil),  He is also digging water trenches for our camping area, and making outdoor kitchen and bathing facilities.  He does this in return for a share of the produce and profit. 

There are still a lot of purchases that we need to make.  We need seeds for herbs, vegetables, trees and berries. We also need to purchase berry bushes and trees.   We need several trailers for living quarters for our students and a paid assistant manager.  We need to pay labor costs including an assistant manager who can operate and maintain the tractors we are being allowed to use.  The camp is totally off-grid so we need solar panels for electricity.  We also need fencing.

The other major expense is for samples of both soil and the food we are growing.  We want to document our rapid increase of carbon in the soil along with rapid increase of soil biology.   We also want to document the nutrition in the food that we grow.

In total, we want to raise $13,000 to continue the farm.  We anticipate needing additional funds and as this is a profit endeavor, we will look for loans.  It is easier to get loans once we can show the farm.  Also after the first year we will have income from our crops.

Other Ways You Can Help Mitigate Climate Change and Reverse Desertification and Starvation:

Besides money contributions, we also need help getting the word out.  If you are on any social media, please share there and with any friends on and off social media and in any groups you are involved in that are appropriate for this. 

This campaign is meant to be help people understand what what  carbon farming is, what putting carbon in the soil can do for climate change.   Even if people cannot contribute financially it is a good education tool.   Please look at the Indiegogo share tools!

To Wrap  Up:

Many people doing this type of system (permaculture, edible food forestry, agoforestry, agroecology) are not using microbial inoculations.  Without these innoculations it will take  more time to build up the carbon holding capacity of the soil which we at Terra Lingua will do in 1 year.  This translates to soil fertility, water holding capacity and therefore production.  It also means that we can farm without irrigation in the desert, making as much as 50% more land available world wide for agriculture.

“You never change things by fighting the existing reality.  To change something, build a new model that makes the existing model obsolete.”  Buckminster Fuller

We believe with our approach and your help funding and sharing it, we can truly change the way farming is done around the world, thus alleviating starvation, desertification, and mitigating climate change.  And we include in starvation the empty calories, nutritional deficiencies and high medical and veterinary bills that come from our current growing systems.  We will show the farmers that our system makes them a good income.
