and mitigating climate change.  And we include in starvation the empty
calories, nutritional deficiencies and high medical and veterinary bills that
come from our current growing systems.  We will show the farmers that our
system makes them a good income.

story:
Masai Mara Conservation - save the wildlife and the culture


Since one year we run a wildlife conservancy bordering the great Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya. This area is one of the most genuine and unspoiled pieces of nature on earth. It is one of the most game-rich areas in Africa. There are several threats to the area in the form of increased population and cultivation but also poaching.  The way to save this land and all the wildlife for the future is to form Conservancies where the wildlife and the Maasai population can co-exist in a balanced manner. By leasing the land from the Maasai they also get a direct benefit from conservation and tourism.

My name is Karl von Heland and I have a passion for this area. I am from Sweden but my Kenyan history goes back to my grandfather Eric who came to Kenya in 1919 working as Manager of the farm owned by the famous Karen and Bror von Blixen-Finecke (also known from the movie Out of Africa). 

I built a small safari camp, Entumoto Safari Camp, in 2007 together with my "adopted" maasai son Rimoine Ole Kararei, just outside the actual park in the Sekenani Valley.  This is a place of stunning beauty with rolling hills and views over the Rift Valley. 

The Mara region used to be total wilderness but has seen a sharp increase in population in the last 20 years as the Maasai have been forced away from their nomadic life, to settle down so the kids can go to school. As maasai love cattle the numbers has been increasing sharply, also with increased wealth, so the situation has grewn un-sustainable in many areas.  Most of the land in the wider Mara region has been privatized in the last few years and each family has got a piece of private land. This means they will have to totally change their lifestyle.

The Entumoto conservancy was established in march 2014 and became an immediate success. As all cows were removed from the area wildlife poured back in and we now have all the big five and an abundance of game in the area. Cattle can still graze occasionally and in separate zones, under strict control.

We have however been working for long to expand the area from 2600 acres of land leased from 400 families to about 35.000 acres of land leased from all 3.500 landowners in the area (a small part of each landowners land). We have involved several other small camps to join this development and the starting date shall be in july 2015. This fantastic development is now in jeopardy.

Due to the crisis in tourism in Africa some of these  partners will not be able to fund the conservancy as planned and the whole project risk being delayed or even fail. Western tourists stopped traveling to Africa last year as Ebola stroke in Western Africa, some 5300 kilometers away! Also, islamic groups have been terrorizing  the Somali border and occasionally parts of the coast and Nairobi. Even though life is very much normal in most parts of Kenya tourism has been very hard hit. 

We thus need additional funding to make this grand project succeed. We have been granted about 600.000 USD from a UK sponsor through WWF. This will help in the initial funding of the management company to  hire rangers, buy patrol cars but also on education and community projects.  

But we still need to cover up for those tourism partners who can not find the financing. All these funds will go into leasing the land. There are 3500 maasai families that shall get an initial fixed lease of 6.500 Ksh (70 USD) per year and then increasing. We also need to fund part of the salaries and running cost for the rangers who will secure the area from poaching. We have lots of elephants and also rhinos in the area and the poaching has increased as demand from China and Vietnam has pushed prices for ivory and rhino horn to the level of gold.

We have two different operations in this area, the bush camp Entumoto www.entumoto.com and our trust, the Peder von Heland Trust, (see Facebook peder von heland trust entumoto). The trust runs different community projects such as the funding of a Rescue Center for Maasai girls in need of protection from circumsition and early marriage and a vocational training center. Please visit the Facebook or web-sites to see more pictures and information.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to secure the funding of the leases and wages to rangers etc for at least one year until we can secure the local funding as tourism comes back and more camps and lodges can join the project. 

We have been working on this project for many years together with the local maasai community. We have joined forces with two good tourism partners, Mara Bushtops and Leleshwa camp and several NGO's who are focusing on conservation. As the land in this area, Siana, was mapped and equally distributed to the maasai last year this project could come true. Meetings has been held in all villages surrounding the area and the local leaders has worked hard to convince the community to vote for the formation of the conservancy.

There is now two formal companies formed for the conservancy. One Landowners Company and one Management Company. The Landowners company is owned and managed by the local maasai and they will deal with all issues related to the land. The management company has a board of directors consisting of three maasai elected by the Landowners Company and three tourism partners from Entumoto, Mara Bushtops and Leleshwa. 

The Management Company has set all rules for the conservancy such as grazing rights, trespassing rights, limitations on tourism, payments etc etc. We will also hire rangers and manage the conservancy.

By sponsring this project you will actively help us preserve a very important part of Africa to wildlife but also help the Maasai benefit from conservation. As all land is now privatized in the area there will be no land for the maasai to walk and graze their cattle. By introducing strict grazing rules and conditions in the conservancy (Zone grazing in different times of the year) we will make it possible for the landowners to maintain some of their old nomadic grazing culture and the community is actually quite enthusiastic about it. There are many examples of successful conservancies around in Kenya and best practices are being developed.

The funds we collect from you will go 100 % into financing the conservancy and linked community projects. We need all the help we can get, even if we do not reach our entire goal.

The Impact

We know how important it is to get this conservancy up and running as we can see how well it has worked in our initial site, the Entumoto Conservancy.

One year ago we managed to gather 300 maasai under a tree in the Sekenani Valley. Many of the local politicians and leaders also came to give long speeches and describe how important it would be for them all to secure more land for wildlife and tourism. 

My maasai partner Rimoine had a big bag with cash and we had also asked a local bank from Narok to send some staff to open bank accounts for these who wanted to join. We had also managed to get the list of all owners of specific plots and as they signed a lease agreement for their plot they got some cash and could open a bank account (the cooperative bank clercs had portable pc.s with mobile modems so it was down right there, under the tree).

When this was done in march 2014 the whole area was filled with cattle. Some from the neighborhood walking in grazing in the days and some from far which means there were temporary bomas all over the place (a boma is built by thorny bushes to keep lions and hyenas out and the cattle and the herders stay there during the night). 

As this area is right next to the park and the whole Serengeti eco-system (no fences) there were quite a lot of game but the number of cows often kept them away.

The day after the big meeting all herders were told to leave the area and after some weeks of debating and organizing they were all gone. Just days later  the first tower of giraff came in, followed by elephants, buffalo and even wild dogs.  Nature revived and during the great wildebeest migration in july the whole area was filled with zebra, wildebeest and all types of antelopes. 

Today, one year later, we have a resident pride of lions who just had cubs. We have had rhinos scouting the area and last week we had a first ostrich coming in. It is just amazing how quick this land has been taken back by the game and how beautiful it has become.  

We can now do this to such a big tract of land which will soon become the jewel of african wildlife and small scale, sustainable, safaris. But if it fails now I fear it is high risk this land will instead be turned into wheat and corn farming fighting battles with wildlife and cattle, often overgrazing and degrading the land into destruction.

Those who help us with contributions will get special rates on accommodation. We want to show you this beautiful land and its fantastic wildlife and its fascinating  maasai culture. Think, if you sponsor just 70 USD it will go straight to one maasai family and it will help securing this land and its wildlife for the future!

Please also help us spread the word about this project - tell your friends! share the information on social media! 

Thanks in advance.

Karl

story:
Help me save a delicate link in a critical migratory route:  The Pacific Flyway.

LAS RAÍCES DEL MAR is a timely documentary about the vibrant mangrove forests of the coast of Colima, their contribution to marine and terrestrial life, and their precarious future.  Focusing on the mangrove estuaries around the port city of Manzanillo, we learn of the incredible variety of life that mangrove supports, from simple shellfish, to birds and mammals, to the fish caught offshore on which we survive.  Under threat by development, we learn about creative alternatives to mangrove destruction in which mangrove lagoons are transformed into bioreserves.

All of these lagoons are in a state of peril.  much is agressive destruction for commercial development. We focus in particular on the Port expansion project in Manzanillo and the Laguna de Juluapan, cut in half by a 1980's real estate development project that failed.  We document how mangrove destruction affects local fishermen, who are now netting a fraction of their original catch.

But there is hope.  There are programs to revitalize lagoons, such as La Laguna del Valle de Las Garzas.  Caught between urban runoff and the encroaching Port of Manzanillo, there are programs in place to keep it dredged and open it as a municipal park.  We visit the manglars of Palo Verde, a protected reserve open for tourists to visit a mangrove community.

We have much material filmed.   Now begins the editing process and the all-important Premier, after which we will screen the film at national and international festivals.  But it is here where your support is so critical.  THE MESSAGE, THE MISSION, IS THERE.  The country has just been through the tragedy of Tajamar in Quintana Roo, where developers, backed by police forces, cynically flattened over 50 hectares of healthy mangrove.  But an informed population is fighting back, and there is an injunction against development in Tajamar.  I need help putting this project on the road…  to save mangrove, we need to get the international community, particularly where they appreciate the presence of migratory animals, aware of how important this thin coastal forest is.


THIS HAS BEEN ENTIRELY SELF-FUNDED BY ME, JAMES KURTZ.  In 2007, I began to trench abandoned roadway in order to flood the Laguna de Juluapan.  To date, I have helped restore ten acres of ruined lagoon while risking arrest.  But if you see the story of mangrove, you will see why such unauthorized actions are critical. Killing mangrove kills fisheries.

Please help me help mangrove by supporting my film.  We are at an historic moment, and we can win this.

Please support LAS RAICES DEL MAR by clicking on a giving level in the right hand column.  We will return your recognition by giving you an honorary title recognizing your friendship with the natural world, and a premium (recompensa) to thank you for helping our project.

story:
Somos cuatro estudiantes de Bolivia, Ecuador y El Salvador de la carrera de Ingeniería en Ambiente y Desarrollo en la Universidad Agrícola Panamericana, Zamorano en Honduras. Hemos sido seleccionados para presentar en Columbia University, New York, nuestro proyecto sobre medidas de mitigación y adaptación al cambio climático para pequeños productores de Honduras.

Juntos hemos recaudado 1/4 del total necesario para asistir al evento y la fecha es cada vez más próxima. Estamos ansiosos por demostrar cómo siendo estudiantes logramos cambios evidentes en las comunidades cercanas a la Universidad y en el mundo también. Una vez cumplida nuestra meta de recaudación, los fondos adicionales serán utilizados como capital semilla para dar sostenibilidad al proyecto que presentaremos y así continuar ayudando a las familias rurales de Honduras.

Compartiendo el proyecto en la conferencia, queremos difundir esta iniciativa para que esté disponible a otros, se inspiren y puedan replicar nuestro proyecto en sus propias comunidades alrededor del mundo.

¡Se parte de esta iniciativa! Con tu ayuda podremos realizar este sueño y tendremos la oportunidad de contribuir hacia un desarrollo sostenible juntos!

Nuestro proyecto. Nuestras comunidades.

Nuestra presentación se titula "Llevando alternativas de adaptación al cambio climático a agricultores de pequeña escala: reduciendo la brecha entre la academia y la sociedad; desde la perspectiva de los estudiantes" (Bringing adaptation alternatives to climate change to small scale farmers: narrowing the gap between Academy and Society from the students' perspective). Zamorano estableció en 2012 un módulo de trabajo de Aprender Haciendo denominado Manejo Integrado de Cultivos y Cambio Climático. En él aprendemos a desarrollar sistemas resilientes de producción agrícola mediante estrategias asequibles, de forma que los servicios ecosistémicos y los medios de vida puedan ser protegidos. Con este conocimiento, más de 500 estudiantes de 18 países de Latinoamérica han contribuido al establecimiento del programa en comunidades rurales de Honduras y más de 50 familias han sido capacitadas en la aplicación de tecnologías de conservación que incrementan la resiliencia de sus sistemas de producción agrícola ante el Cambio Climático.

Zamorano, also known as the Escuela Agrícola Panamericana, is registered as a 501(c)(3) organization with the U.S. IRS under ID #04-2104172.  Donations made by persons paying taxes in the U.S. or Honduras may be eligible for tax deductions.

story:
Please Join Nepal Earthquake Disaster Relief

Dear Precious Loving Ones,

As you know, on April 25th Nepal was struck by a devastating 7.8 earthquake, and again on April 12th by a 7.3 magnitude aftershock. We, the Dzogchen Shri Singha Foundation USA, are now helping through Buddhist Master Geydak Rinpoche in Nepal.

Now, many organizations and individuals are helping the earthquake relief efforts in Nepal, but there is still a great shortage of aid because more than eight million people are affected. More than three million people are suffering from a shortage of food, medicine, clothes, and accommodations. More than 14,000 have been seriously injured and there are not enough medical facilities to help them. 7,200 people have died and this number may increase still. Our temple in Godawari and the monks’ living quarters have also been damaged, and some of our monks have been injured.

A lot of Nepali villages were struck so severely that not even a single house remains standing. Many of these villages are not accessible by vehicles. Rescue or aid has not reached a lot of these remote areas. Now the weather is very bad, and there will be a lot of rain or snow in the coming weeks and months. Many people are suffering and crying for help.

In order to ease the pains of the Nepali people, Geydak Rinpoche and our Sangha, already in Nepal, have been compassionately helping these affected people every day since the initial quake. We have already helped more than 40,000 people with basic disaster relief, traveling to more than 64 villages in remote areas. We so rejoice in what they are doing. 

A Renewed Effort

At this time, the Dzogchen Shri Singha Foundation wants to raise money to support this aid project in Nepal. Everyone, please support this loving compassionate act. As a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, every dollar you donate is eligible for tax deduction according to the full extent of the law. 

100% of your donations will go directly to the people of Nepal for relief effort with no intermediaries. 

Right now we are trying to provide over 1,000 families with basic shelters for the summer rainy season and the harsh weather of winter to come. 

Of course we cannot support everyone in Nepal, but we must do our part. 

It makes a big difference. 

So far, we have distributed critical supplies and tools such as:

1.) 1,300 tents 
2.) 10,000 shovels
3.) 1,000 hammers
4.) 2,500 pounds of nails
5.) 130,000 pounds of rice 

And other essential medicines and various necessities such as shoes and clothes to those areas in greatest need. We have also provided hundreds of hot meals everyday to those who were injured. 

What Help We Need Now

Since the initial earthquake, Geydak Rinpoche, his monks, and volunteers have been tirelessly working every day to bring much needed supplies. We are renting two trucks to carry the tons of rice and other supplies to the remote areas of Nepal where help is rarely received. 

The hospitals in Nepal are nowhere near set up to receive such a vast number of people. Many of the wounded are left in the lobbies and in hallways. Their facilities have no ability to supply the needs of these suffering individuals. We have been feeding hundreds of hot meals to people in the hospitals every day. One thing we are greatly in need of is a dish sanitizer as there is no way to properly clean the utensils and dishes needed for this amount of people. 

Every day our compassionate volunteers are also in the streets bringing disinfectant spray to help reduce the risk of disease, which is a very serious impending threat with the oncoming of the monsoons.

Later we also plan to help repair some historical holy sites that have been damaged or destroyed. If anyone would like to compassionately help this aid project, it is greatly appreciated. We will use 100% of whatever donations we receive to directly support this project and nothing else. 

Geydak Rinpoche has ordered many supplies such as rice and tents from India to make sure that our donations go directly to the mouths, over the heads, and upon the feet of those who are in most need. 

Facing Weather Challenges

Now that the monsoon season has begun, the worst case scenario is setting in, and the race to ensure shelter and lasting recovery is deepening. The roads are becoming more and more difficult to traverse and hope to reach the remote villages with aid is a manner of swift compassionate activity. Many people need supplies, and we are on the ground every day bringing it to them. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You have the power to make a difference in the lives of others in a most desperate time. Your compassionate generosity can bring great relief to the people of Nepal! If you do not choose to donate through our Foundation, please help in any way possible.

The power of compassion in action is tremendous, and there are many things that you can do to help. Use the Indiegogo share tools to  share this campaign and spread the word. 

Remember that everybody needs help sometime in life. You have an opportunity to be a hero for someone in great need. The power of compassionate action is immeasurable.

May all beings be free from suffering and the causes of suffering!
May all beings have happiness and the causes of happiness!

— Dzogchen Shri Singha Foundation, USA

ཨོཾ་མ་ཎི་པདྨེ་ཧཱུྃ་ཧྲཱིཿ

Om Mani Padme Hung Hri
story_txt:
Please Join Nepal Earthquake Disaster Relief

Dear Precious Loving Ones,
As you know, on April 25th Nepal was struck by a devastating 7.8 earthquake, and again on April 12th by a 7.3 magnitude aftershock. We, the Dzogchen Shri Singha Foundation USA, are now helping through Buddhist Master Geydak Rinpoche in Nepal.
Now, many organizations and individuals are helping the earthquake relief efforts in Nepal, but there is still a great shortage of aid because more than eight million people are affected. More than three million people are suffering from a shortage of food, medicine, clothes, and accommodations. More than 14,000 have been seriously injured and there are not enough medical facilities to help them. 7,200 people have died and this number may increase still. Our temple in Godawari and the monks’ living quarters have also been damaged, and some of our monks have been injured.
A lot of Nepali villages were struck so severely that not even a single house remains standing. Many of these villages are not accessible by vehicles. Rescue or aid has not reached a lot of these remote areas. Now the weather is very bad, and there will be a lot of rain or snow in the coming weeks and months. Many people are suffering and crying for help.
In order to ease the pains of the Nepali people, Geydak Rinpoche and our Sangha, already in Nepal, have been compassionately helping these affected people every day since the initial quake. We have already helped more than 40,000 people with basic disaster relief, traveling to more than 64 villages in remote areas. We so rejoice in what they are doing. 

A Renewed EffortAt this time, the Dzogchen Shri Singha Foundation wants to raise money to support this aid project in Nepal. Everyone, please support this loving compassionate act. As a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, every dollar you donate is eligible for tax deduction according to the full extent of the law. 100% of your donations will go directly to the people of Nepal for relief effort with no intermediaries. 
Right now we are trying to provide over 1,000 families with basic shelters for the summer rainy season and the harsh weather of winter to come. 
Of course we cannot support everyone in Nepal, but we must do our part. 
It makes a big difference. 
So far, we have distributed critical supplies and tools such as:
1.) 1,300 tents 2.) 10,000 shovels 3.) 1,000 hammers 4.) 2,500 pounds of nails5.) 130,000 pounds of rice 
And other essential medicines and various necessities such as shoes and clothes to those areas in greatest need. We have also provided hundreds of hot meals everyday to those who were injured.    What Help We Need Now Since the initial earthquake, Geydak Rinpoche, his monks, and volunteers have been tirelessly working every day to bring much needed supplies. We are renting two trucks to carry the tons of rice and other supplies to the remote areas of Nepal where help is rarely received. 
The hospitals in Nepal are nowhere near set up to receive such a vast number of people. Many of the wounded are left in the lobbies and in hallways. Their facilities have no ability to supply the needs of these suffering individuals. We have been feeding hundreds of hot meals to people in the hospitals every day. One thing we are greatly in need of is a dish sanitizer as there is no way to properly clean the utensils and dishes needed for this amount of people. 
Every day our compassionate volunteers are also in the streets bringing disinfectant spray to help reduce the risk of disease, which is a very serious impending threat with the oncoming of the monsoons.
Later we also plan to help repair some historical holy sites that have been damaged or destroyed. If anyone would like to compassionately help this aid project, it is greatly appreciated. We will use 100% of whatever donations we receive to directly support this project and nothing else. 

Geydak Rinpoche has ordered many supplies such as rice and tents from India to make sure that our donations go directly to the mouths, over the heads, and upon the feet of those who are in most need. 
Facing Weather Challenges
 Now that the monsoon season has begun, the worst case scenario is setting in, and the race to ensure shelter and lasting recovery is deepening. The roads are becoming more and more difficult to traverse and hope to reach the remote villages with aid is a manner of swift compassionate activity. Many people need supplies, and we are on the ground every day bringing it to them. 
Other Ways You Can Help
 You have the power to make a difference in the lives of others in a most desperate time. Your compassionate generosity can bring great relief to the people of Nepal! If you do not choose to donate through our Foundation, please help in any way possible.
The power of compassion in action is tremendous, and there are many things that you can do to help. Use the Indiegogo share tools to  share this campaign and spread the word. 
Remember that everybody needs help sometime in life. You have an opportunity to be a hero for someone in great need. The power of compassionate action is immeasurable.

story:
ZERO WASTE

A  documentary about having too much stuff and throwing it away.

We are pumping carbon dioxide into the atmosphere at a rate that could lead to our extinction. Most of  the Co2 is generated by industry and manufacturing, supported by over-production and over-consumption. Garbage is another byproduct of our economic system.

Vancouver, British Columbia, like most urban areas in Canada and the U.S., is struggling to cope with solid waste. It is an affluent metropolitan region, where the average person throws away almost 1.4 tonnes of garbage every year.

Metro Vancouver aspires to achieve "zero waste" at some point in the future, but right now, it is recycling and composting about two thirds of its garbage. The rest goes to landfills and incineration.

An extremely controversial aspect of Metro's solid waste plan is the proposal to build more incineration facilities, despite objections from many who are concerned about pollution and health risks.

Many critics doubt that zero waste can ever be reached. Zero waste advocates say even the definition of the term is misleading, since some so-called recyclable waste ends up in a landfill or incinerator.

In order to recycle a product, it must be broken down and then re-manufactured into something new. This process requires a lot of Co2-generating energy. The material must be transported to a recycling facility, sorted, sent on to the  manufacturer, then re-manufactured and sent back to the market.

Although we hear a lot about the three R's - reduce, reuse, recycle - most of the emphasis is on  recycling. Recycling may be better than landfills or incineration, but it treats the symptoms of the problem not the root cause: over-production and over-consumption.

Zero waste advocates around the world are pushing for change, but will it be too little, too late?

Our documentary addresses all of these issues and looks at efforts to move toward a more sustainable system that wastes fewer resources. We have conducted more than a dozen interviews and shot footage at numerous locations to illustrate the problem and some of the solutions.

Your financial support will allow us to cover editing and other post-production costs. Even it you aren't able to donate, you can still help by getting word out to everyone you know - facebook, email, etc. Remember to use Indiegogo's share tools.

story:
Our rug

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Our rug is a blend of Banana, Jute and Cotton fibers. All these fibers will be part of our Agroforestry, together with other species (see below). The rug was designed by Flavia Vanelli and her team at RatoRói. They will be all hand-made by the artisan team at Tati&Art and use only natural colors. We have created three different sizes for you to choose.

As we are using 100% natural fibers, the rug is biodegradable. However, long lasting products are also important. So, especially if you pretend to use it outdoors, we recommend applying a simple waterproof Rug & Carpet Spray.

 

Our Agroforestry

The profit of this campaign will be invested in what we are calling a 'Textile Agroforestry', using species with long and strong fibers. Resources will be allocated to four main costs: 1) soil evaluation, 2) seeds, 3) plantation and 4) maintenance. Below you can find a design plan for our prototype with 1 hectare:

More about Agroforestry:

This sustainable way of farming has been implemented in Brazil but remains mostly unknown worldwide. However, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) from United Nations (UN) is finally supporting more of these farming systems.

It restores landscapes and helps to increase soil fertility, biodiversity, water quality and community development. To know more, check out the video below of Ernst Gotsch, our inspiration, and mentor: 

The future

Our vision is to develop a 'Textile Agroforestry' framework to be used by different farmers and scalable throughout the whole supply-chain, integrating cooperatives, people that work and use the forest as a resource, and designers that are looking for new sustainable materials.

If you are interested to collaborate with us, or recommend partners, don't hesitate to reach out: beto@farfarm.co

story:
Short Summary

I am seeking your support to help "Free Mama Earth" from the abuse caused by destructive human behavior like ozone layer depletion (climate change), nuclear proliferation and deforestation.  As a mother and singer/songwriter, the environment, peace and social justice are causes dear to my heart. One morning I awoke with the melody for "Free Mama Earth" and the lyrics flowed through my fingers onto a composition book.  Grammy award winner Mamadou Diabate is playing on "Free Mama Earth." Once we receive funding and release "Free Mama Earth,"  100% of sales from downloads and  streams of "Free Mama Earth" will be donated to ENVIRONMENTAL DEFENSE FUND www.edf.org and NUCLEAR AGE PEACE FOUNDATION www.wagingpeace.org.   

Environmental problems like climate change can seem overwhelming and impossible to solve, but doing nothing guarantees failure. "It always seems impossible until it's done." President Nelson Mandela.

The kind of world our children and future generations will inherit depends on actions we take now. "Free Mama Earth" is about saving Mama Earth from abuse like humans cutting down all the trees in the forest, polluting the drinking water, oceans, air, atmosphere... Plus, the music is beautiful.  

No one can do everything, but everyone can do something.  United we are rich in ideas. Together we can make an impact. WILL YOU PLEASE JOIN ME BY MAKING A DONATION?

What We Need & What You Get

Our budget of $5,000 for production of "Free Mama Earth" is detailed in the "pie" chart: (Producer, recording studios, engineers, side musicians, background vocalist...) Funds received in excess of $5,000 will be used to produce an epic environmental video for Aria Elan's new song: "Free Mama Earth". 100% of sales from downloads and streams of "Free Mama Earth" will be donated to ENVIRONMENTAL DEFENSE FUND www.edf.org and NUCLEAR AGE PEACE FOUNDATION www.wagingpeace.org to help support the important work they do to STOP  climate change, rain forest destruction and nuclear proliferation.

We are rewarding donors with cool gifts. "Free Mama Earth" bumper stickers, pens, organic 100% cotton t-shirts, CD autographed by Aria Elan, skype concert - Aria Elan singing "Free Mama Earth" and songs from "Smile" album.

The Impact

The old ocean front power plant in the opening of my video spews waste into the air & ocean causing pollution and erosion.  Normally I would be running as far away from the power plant as possible, but I'm running towards it to show you the surreal juxtaposition between the majestic Pacific Ocean and the ugly, dangerous 20th century power plant located only a few yards from the ocean.  We need more 21st century clean energy solutions like solar and wind, not nuclear or fossil fuel monstrosities. 

Mama Earth is the only home we have.  I want our children & future generations to inherit a garden of eden, not a nuked out polluted planet. No more Hiroshima or Fukushima.

I am doing this "Free Mama Earth" campaign for children all over the world. They are coming.  I am going.  When my eyes close, "Free Mama Earth" will continue to inspire and raise money for our cause.  THANK YOU.

One Planet, One Blood, One Love...

Risks & Challenges

Like Kermit the Frog said: "It's not easy being green."  I understand that the middle class is dwindling all around the world, people are suffering and do not have a lot of money, but we all find time and money for the things that are important to us. Saving our environment is important to millions of people around the world. Your donations will make all the difference in assuring the success of "Free Mama Earth" campaign, so please join me and vote with your dollars. 

I have personal knowledge about overcoming adversity. Born African American on a small farm in South Carolina, I overcame racism and sexism to achieve my goals. We can do this!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this "Free Mama Earth" campaign with your family and friends through email and social media. Use the indiegogo share tools! Thanks and One Love! Aria

story:
Pimp the Shark Lab

The South African Shark Conservancy (SASC) is a small NGO based in the Old Harbour Museum situated on the shores of Hermanus, South Africa.  We are a passionate group of scientists & conservationists who have dedicated our lives to promoting understanding of - and stewardship for - Earth's oceans & the very special animals who call them home.

Using sharks as iconic animals, we engage with communities, academic institutes & children - using our small research lab & shark tanks - to help change perceptions about some of the planet's most maligned creatures.


More than 3000 people visit our lab, interact with our captive sharks & meet our scientists every year.  With so many people wanting to get up close & personal with sharks in our lab, we want to be able to give them the very best experience possible - whilst maintaining a happy & healthy living environment for our beautiful sharks.

We receive limited grant-based funding for our research projects.  However, with no permanent financial support, our small conservation NGO cannot afford to upgrade the aquarium & education center that has proved to be an invaluable experiential education experience for more than 20 000 people from around the world.

Meet the sharks

EDUCATION & OUTREACH

For many children & adults who visit our Shark Lab, this is the first time they will meet sharks face-to-face.  Having been exposed to endless negative media about these animals, a surprising number of visitors are terrified of sharks - even the small and relatively inactive sharks housed in our aquarium.  In a country where wildlife poaching (even in the ocean) is rampant we endeavor to create a lasting positive experience that changes perceptions and attitudes.  Using a hands-on, experiential approach our goals are to inspire passion and respect for ocean ecosystems and animals.

RESEARCH

Research in the Shark Lab is focused on the behaviour & ecology of small sharks found nowhere else in the world.  We provide more than 70 interns & students each year with the opportunity to conduct hands-on shark research, building critical skills for future careers as marine scientists.  Sharks housed in the Shark Lab tanks are kept for a maximum of 3 months & then released back into the ocean.

AMBASSADORS FOR SHARKS

Local & international celebrities, such as Nickelback (pictured here), have visited the Shark Lab & enjoyed some special one-on-one time with our sharks.  Celebrities have an unparalleled audience & can, through the power of their actions, help sway public opinion about sharks.

What people have to say about the Shark Lab

Great presentation, extensive knowledge, very relaxed environment, genuine passion for shark conservation.  Very inspired to further my own knowledge & take action in some way. (Sarah, 2011).

You have really opened my eyes.  I am a fisherman & never respected these animals.  Thank you for a great effort.  You definitely have my vote!  (Mohammed, 2012).

Thanks for the awesome tour & learning experience!  Good luck making the world more aware!  (Monique & Tiaan, 2013).

Wonderful organization & you guys do amazing work!  Truly thanks to you guys I have fallen in love with sharks more than ever before!!  Thank you!! (Rebecca, 2014).

The plan

Pimp our Shark Lab is a campaign designed to help SASC raise much-needed funds for upgrading and redesigning our aquarium & education center.  Our goal is to raise US$25 000 in order to improve the education & outreach we deliver, as well as improve the lives of our sharks.

$25 000 will enable us to install custom-built acrylic tanks which will include:

  •   a floor-to-ceiling kelp tank highlighting local ocean biodiversity, including our endemic sharks;
  •   a small experimental tank for students and interns to conduct research &   develop critical skills;
  •   a touch tank for experiential education purposes;
  •   filters, fittings, spare parts, etc to keep the aquarium running.

Funds will also be used to help revamp the Shark Lab, installing storage facilities required for samples collected during research & for our field equipment.  We will also improve the interactive displays and facilities in our education center.  

The Impact

With a contribution of your choosing, you will:

  • help our dedicated team improve living conditions for the sharks in our Shark Lab;
  • create an incredible hands-on learning tool for thousands of children & adults;
  • support the growth & development of a shark research facility, thereby contributing to the long-term health of shark populations & ocean ecosystems;
  • invest in the oceans, protect charismatic species under threat & leave a lasting legacy for future generations.

Can't contribute financially?

Even if you can't make a donation, you can help by making some noise about our Pimp the Shark Lab campaign & sharing it with all your friends & family.

Remember, as a small NGO with limited finances, each & every cent counts.  Even the smallest donation will benefit our operation, ultimately helping us achieve our funding goals.

ultimately helping us achieve our funding goals.

story:
#SolarCamp aims to provide refugee camp residents in Lebanon with Solar Panel Systems to reduce their monthly electricity costs by up to 80%, while reducing deadly electrical wiring interwoven through the camp and improving the environment. 

#SolarCamp is a start-up, and this first-stage pilot program will be installed at a kindergarten in Bourj El Barajneh refugee camp in south Beirut. The kindergarten is an ideal site for the installation of the first off-grid Solar Panel System because we'll be able to directly reduce some of the dangerous wiring around the school building, while also reducing the cost of electricity so that school programs can run longer. It will also as a great showcase and demonstration to the rest of the camp residents about the benefits of solar panel systems. 

After the success of the pilot program, we plan to work with our partners to scale up the project to include more and more locations around the camp. The secondary effects of such a project are manifold. Residents’ monthly disposable income will rise significantly, which will improve quality of life for each household. As the camp pulls itself farther away from dependence on the grid, addressing open-air wiring will be more manageable. In the long run safety will improve for the camp, where currently children are injured or die every year because of this highly hazardous and underdeveloped infrastructure scheme. 

We are also developing an educational component for the kindergarten kids so they can learn about their camp, the dangers of the wires, the environment in general and how to take care of their communities. 

The Partners

#SolarCamp is partnering with the American Near East Refugee Aid (ANERA), a reputed organization with 48 years of experience working with Palestinian refugees. In 2015 ANERA had access to $58 million that was spent on their award-winning education, economic development and health work. Their funding comes from foundations, corporations, governments, and thousands of individual donors.

ANERA will partner with #SolarCamp and implement the project in Bourj El Barajneh as they have relationships and the trust of the camp residents as well as the staff to manage the project.

#SolarCamp is also partnering with a Lebanese Solar Energy company, SolarLeb. The company has seven years of experience in the Solar PV installation sector. As one of the first movers in the industry in Lebanon, the company is the currently one of the market leaders in the country. The company has deep experience in challenging environments, installing solar lamps and panels in the Bekaa Valley for the Syrian refugee settlements there. SolarLeb also has large contracts to provide renewable electricity in Nigeria. 

Bourj El Barajneh

The camp is located in the south of Beirut. 20,000 Palestinian refugees live on one square kilometer of land. Life is very crowded for these communities that have been there since 1948. Camps like this have depended on UNRWA, NGOs and relief work for decades. 

In Bourj El Barajneh, camp residents currently pay up to $70 to $150 a month for electricity, a heavy cost for families that earn on average $400 a month. Furthermore they only receive electricity from the Lebanese government for 10 to 12 hours a day, and the rest of the 12 to 14 hours they live on expensive diesel-powered generators. While the electricity coming from the government is very reasonably priced, the real cost is generator power. These generators are often owned and operated by cartels that are able to charge high fees as monopolies. 

The Gifts, Palestinian Embroidery, and Women's Program Association  

The tradition of handmade Palestinian embroidery dates back to the late nineteenth century, a signifier of regional identity and a marker of age and status. Originally used in the making of intricate, colorful and striking wedding dresses the practice is being used to create general accessories and furniture items like handbags and pillows. 

#SolarCamp and ANERA are working with the Women's Program Associations and NISCVT (National Institute for Social Care and Vocational Training) that operate in the Palestinian Camps. ANERA organizes Skilled based training sessions for young people to reintegrate the job market or just to acquire a new skills including traditional Palestinian Embroidery, and sometimes for our events we do buy their products to support them financially. Traditional Palestinian embroidery has been transmitted from generation to generation throughout the Palestinian diaspora to keep the culture and tradition alive. All works are hand made by women living in the refugee camps, therefore all proceeds directly support these women.

The Founder

#SolarCamp's founder has a long track record of social activism, community organizing and international development having worked on both Obama campaigns, at Al Jazeera English and as a USAID contractor. 

He is a Master’s Candidate in International Affairs from Johns Hopkins University with a focus on Energy Economics and Renewable Energy. He's also attending an MBA program at INSEAD to complete his education and utilize disruptive business models to spread environmentally-friendly technology globally. 

Born to a Palestinian Father and a Lebanese mother, and raised in the USA, Waleed has raised $500,000 for in Scholarship funding for Palestinian students to study in top American universities. He's also worked in the refugee camps in Lebanon in the past.

story:
Short Summary

We're an NGO based in Bethlehem, Palestine (West Bank.) We are the first and only shelter in this region (mostly for dogs and some cats) and we need your support.

With the help of some volunteers, we were able to use a house that is under construction to save sick, abused, neglected, and on the brink of death stray dogs. Unfortunately, we are over capacity now (with 50+) dogs and have found another solution.


We have built a shelter to house almost double the amount which has running water, electricity, and space for a clinic.


We have spent already $25,000 to construct the foundation of the shelter and need to pay off our debt in order for the workers to finish this shelter before winter comes full force.


We are building this new shelter for strays to receive a warm home, medical care, food, and a safe haven. We want to bring them back to health and nourish them so in the future they can be adoptable.


The Who and The What?

We are a group of local and international volunteers created The Animal and Environment Association based in Bethlehem. Our director started the process of legally creating and signing up this shelter in the Ministry in 2011. It is almost 6 years later that we have managed to start working.


There is no law in Palestine to protect stray animals or to save the ones already suffering. There is no shelter for them, no specialized clinics or veterinarians (only for large cattle,) and no support from the government or people.So, we have branched out to the international community.


There are millions of people living here and tens of thousands of stray animals...and our little association trying to save them all.

Our current shelter has many problems;


-It is completely under construction, all the floors and walls are concrete so the animals are getting cold now.

-There are no windows, electricity, or a method to bring those in. We are simply not allowed by the owner.

-Running water is not always available.

-The shelter is in a very secluded, out of the way valley and hard to come to.


The Plan

Once we have full support, we plan to use the clinic for more than sickness, pain, and disease. We plan to neuter and spay the strays slowly, transport some to Israeli shelters as their law only allows fully vaccinated, sterilized, and micro chipped animals to enter their shelters and get adopted.

Eventually we want to integrate this idea and project into the local society. We want to have a sanctuary, a petting section, volunteer options, events, education, and a pet shop for existing and future pet owners.



The Impact

We have saved over 200 dogs, and currently care for more than 40 of them. They have all been either poisoned, hit by a car, abused, or left to starve. They are all happy, playful, and never hungry again! We have also made connections with other shelters who are willing to help us and have built another brand new shelter.



Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and that's ok of course. But what you can do is SHARE OUR STORY, SHARE OUR CAMPAIGN, SHARE OUR INFORMATION.

Please visit our website;www.Basau.org to see pictures and videos of some of the animals we have saved and to read about more information on us. (Warning; graphic and unpleasant videos and photos are on there of hurt animals and how animals are disposed of in this region.) ***If you'd like to volunteer, please contact as - we are always in need of more hands!***

And please share our Facebook page to spread the word about us!

story:
On Wings of Waste is a pioneering flight from San Francisco to Alaska powered solely by a revolutionary recycled plastic fuel.

50 percent of the plastic we use is only used once before being thrown away. This is a massive problem because plastic can take hundreds of years to degrade. Which means that almost every piece of plastic ever made, still exists.

The world is currently being choked by end of life plastic that seemingly has no use, One Wings of Waste is a journey designed to change that perception. We believe that by putting a value on plastic rather than treating it in a disposable fashion, we can help rid our planet of this plastics plague. 

Plastic to oil technology is one these solutions. Rather than pilling plastic into landfill we can now turn it into a fuel, recycling the carbon and thereby reducing our reliance on fossil fuels. The fuel itself is more efficient and cleaner than other fuels and can reduce green house gas emissions by up to 70%.

Sir David Attenborough has endorsed the flight saying, “It is a sign of hope in a very depressing world. At last a mechanism has been found by turning plastic waste into something that can be used and be valuable. The On Wings of Waste flight I hope will bring attention to the world to this great solution that is there waiting to be taken if only we can get the support of people to do so”.

Please join us on this groundbreaking journey that will change the way we use plastic and fuel forever. 

The Impact

This journey is designed to inspire humanity to realise it's capability to solve some of the planets most pressing issues.

 By flying a plane on a recycled plastic fuel for the first time, we hope to show people that we can make the switch to more sustainable and clean forms of consumption. On Wings of Waste will:

  • help solve the world's plastic problem
  • help solve climate change 
  • highlight the hard work that innovators are doing to make the world a better place 

What your funding supports!

- The plastic waste to fuel RV9 plane

- Crate / delivery / insurance and rebuild

- Design - body stocking of names on the plane

- The support plane and pilots

- Project management 

- Logistics 

- Security 

- Public relations 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to our funding campaign help broaden the scope of the cause by:

  • Tell your friends
  • Share our campaign 
#youcareyoushare

story:
---CLIQUEZ ICI POUR LA VERSION FRANÇAISE---


‘There is still time to save our forests. By buying our album you will contribute to protecting our forests, to supporting our farmers, and to leaving something for our children. I call on everyone to join the movement Sing 4 Comoros Forests!’

Campaign Ambassador Maalesh (winner of the 1995 RFI World Music prize and 2007 Indian Ocean prize).


The Comoro Islands suffered the highest rate of deforestation in the world between 2000 and 2010, causing huge problems for the population. Imagine that you can help to reforest the Comoros just by listening to music. Because by buying a new album that brings together many of the best-known Comorian musicians, you can! The proceeds from the campaign will go to supporting the NGO Dahari’s work to save water resources, improve the livelihoods of rural communities, and conserve the Critically Endangered Livingstone’s fruit bat.  If we raise 60,000 dollars through this campaign we will be able to support communities to plant 150,000 trees in 2016.


On the island of Anjouan the environmental problems are clearly visible: only about 10 of 50 previously permanent rivers remain and agricultural yields are in sharp decline. A vicious circle has set in with poverty leading to increased deforestation and vice-versa. The situation is so desperate that hundreds of people die each year trying to make the crossing to the French-administered island of Mayotte in the hope of a better future. 


The NGO Dahari (meaning ‘Sustainable’) has developed a package of tools that empower communities to halt deforestation while securing better livelihoods and wellbeing. Created at the beginning of 2013, Dahari has already:

  • Supported over 3500 of the poorest Comorians to increase their income from farming;
  • Developed the first ever forest management initiatives for the country to protect key water resources and biodiversity hotspots;
  • Garnered unprecedented international support, with technical and financial partnerships with over 30 institutions from Madagascar, France, the UK, Australia, the Netherlands, and the US.



We need your help to reforest the Comoros. You can help Dahari plant 150,000 trees with local communities in 2016:

  • fruit trees and trees grown for timber and fuel to boost farmers’ income,
  • fast-growing tree species to form erosion breaks and provide fodder for cattle,
  • indigenous trees to protect water sources and provide feeding resources for endemic biodiversity.

This is a unique opportunity to help save the forests of the Comoros whilst enjoying some fantastic local music. Please give generously!



  • Donate by buying a reward (contact us if you would like to make an offline donation)
  • Retweet our updates with hashtag #Sing4ComorosForests
  • Take a photo or make a video with a panel saying #Sing4ComorosForests
  •  Distribute the campaign on Facebook and Twitter and through your networks (contact us if you would like to receive a supporter package of suggested social media messages)
  • Launch your own "Sing 4 Comoros Forests" fundraiser concert or event (contact us if you would like a kit)


This charity album is an initiative from Dahari and Ouvoimoja, a Comorian band that brings together the most talented musicians on the island of Anjouan. Ouvoimoja’s music, a fusion of reggae, folk and Comorian mgodro, focuses on both the beauty and harsh reality of life in the islands.


Many of the most famous Comorian musicians are joining forces to support the campaign and will feature on the album, which will include the 3 songs from Ouvoimoja : Walozi (the fishermen), Rilemewa (we are tired) and Ulanga (the nature).

Already signed up: Maalesh, Eliasse, Cheikh MC, Mounawar, DadiPoslim, Costy, Goulam, Nawal.


  • 80% of the money will go directly to support Dahari’s core field programmes to reforest the Comoros in order to conserve water resources, boost farmer incomes, and conserve the Livingstone’s fruit bat.
  • 10% will go towards creating the album and ensuring it is heard in every village in the Comoros through a communications campaign involving concerts and the distribution of CDs.
  • The final 10% will go towards the admin costs, including site fees at 8% and delivery of rewards. 






*****************************************

Version Française

*****************************************


"Il est encore temps de sauver nos forêts. Acheter l'album, c'est contribuer à protéger nos forêts, soutenir nos agriculteurs, mais aussi à laisser quelque chose à nos enfants. J'appelle tout le monde à rejoindre le mouvement Sing 4 Comoros Forests."

Maalesh, parrain de la campagne (lauréat du prix RFI Musiques du Monde 1995 et du prix Musiques de l'Océan Indien 2007)



Les Comores ont souffert du taux de déforestation le plus élevé du monde de 2000 à 2010, ce qui a causé beaucoup de problèmes pour les populations. Imaginez que vous puissiez reboiser les Comores simplement en écoutant de la musique. Parce qu’en achetant un nouvel album qui réunit des musiciens comoriens reconnus, vous pouvez ! Les recettes de cette campagne seront utilisées pour soutenir le travail de l'ONG Dahari pour sauver les ressources en eau, augmenter les revenus des communautés rurales, et conserver la Roussette de Livingstone, en danger critique d'extinction. Si nous récoltons 60 000 dollars avec cette campagne, nous pourrons soutenir les communautés à planter 150 000 arbres en 2016.



Sur l’île d’Anjouan, le déclin environnemental est clairement visible : sur les 50 rivières qui coulaient autrefois, on ne compte plus qu’une dizaine de rivières permanentes, et les rendements agricoles diminuent. Un cercle vicieux s’est installé : la pauvreté mène à la déforestation et vice versa. La situation est tellement désespérée que chaque année des centaines de personnes trouvent la mort en tentant de traverser le bras de mer qui les sépare de l’île de Mayotte, sous administration française.


L’ONG Dahari (qui signifie « durable ») a développé une série d’outils qui donnent du pouvoir aux communautés pour stopper la déforestation tout en assurant des conditions de vie et des revenus meilleurs. Créée début 2013, l’ONG a déjà :

  • aidé plus de 3500 comoriens parmi les plus défavorisés à augmenter leurs revenus par l’agriculture
  • développé les premières initiatives de gestion forestières aux Comores, pour protéger les ressources en eau prioritaires et les hotspots de biodiversité
  • développé un réseau de soutien international, avec des partenariats techniques et financiers avec plus de 30 institutions aux Comores, à Madagascar, en France, au Royaume-Uni, en Australie, aux Pays-Bas et aux Etats-Unis.




Nous avons besoin de votre aide pour reboiser les Comores. Vous pouvez aider Dahari à planter 150 000 arbres avec les communautés locales en 2016 :

  • des arbres fruitiers et des arbres cultivés pour leur bois, pour augmenter les revenus des agriculteurs
  • des arbres à croissance rapide pour former des haies anti-érosion et fournir du fourrage pour le bétail
  • des arbres indigènes pour protéger les sources d’eau et nourrir la faune endémique.

C’est une opportunité unique de sauver les Comores de l’effondrement environnemental, tout en appréciant de la bonne musique comorienne. Faites appel à votre générosité, donnez !



  • Faites un don en commandant une contrepartie (contactez-nous si vous voulez faire un don hors-ligne)
  • Partagez nos publications avec le hashtag #Sing4ComorosForests
  • Prenez une photo ou faites une vidéo avec un panneau #Sing4ComorosForests
  • Faites tourner la campagne sur Facebook et Twitter et dans vos réseaux (contactez-nous si vous voulez un kit de supporter avec des exemples de publications)
  • Organisez un concert ou un événement "Sing 4 Comoros Forests" (contactez-nous si vous voulez de l'aide)


Cette compilation est une initiative de l’ONG Dahari et d’Ouvoimoja, un groupe comorien qui réunit les musiciens les plus talentueux de l’île d’Anjouan. La musique d’Ouvoimoja, une fusion de reggae, de folk et de mgodro comorien, parle de la beauté des Comores et de la dure réalité de la vie dans nos îles.


Une dizaine de musiciens connus des Comores se sont unis pour rejoindre la campagne et ont accepté de participer sur l’album, qui comptera les notamment les trois chansons d'Ouvoimoja : Walozi (les pêcheurs), Rilemewa (nous sommes fatigués) et Ulanga (la nature).

Ils ont rejoint le projet : Maalesh, Eliasse, Cheikh MC, Mounawar, Dadiposlim, Costy, Goulam, Nawal.


  • 80% de l’argent reviendra directement pour soutenir les programmes de Dahari pour reboiser les Comores pour conserver les ressources en eau, augmenter les revenus des agriculteurs, et conserver la roussette de Livingstone.
  • 10% seront utilisés pour créer l’album et assurer qu’il soit écouté dans chaque village des Comores, par une campagne de communication incluant des concerts et des distributions de CDs
  • Les derniers 10% seront utilisés pour les coûts administratifs, notamment la commission d’Indiegogo de 8% et les frais de livraison des contreparties.

indigenous trees to protect water sources and

This is a unique opportunity to help save the forests
of the Comoros whilst
enjoying some fantastic local music. Please
give generously!










Donate by buying a reward (contact us if you would like to make an offline donation)


Retweet our updates with hashtag
#Sing4ComorosForests


Take a photo or
make a video with a panel saying #Sing4ComorosForests


 Distribute the
campaign on Facebook and Twitter and through your networks (contact us if you would like to receive a supporter package of suggested social media messages)


Launch your own "Sing 4 Comoros Forests" fundraiser concert or event (contact us if you would like a kit)








This charity album
is an initiative from Dahari and Ouvoimoja, a Comorian band
that brings together the most talented musicians on the island of Anjouan.
Ouvoimoja’s music, a fusion of reggae, folk and Comorian mgodro, focuses on both the beauty and harsh reality of life in the
islands.

Many of the most
famous Comorian musicians are joining forces to support the campaign and will
feature on the album, which will include the 3 songs from Ouvoimoja : Walozi (the fishermen), Rilemewa (we are tired) and Ulanga (the nature).
Already signed up: Maalesh, Eliasse, Cheikh MC, Mounawar, DadiPoslim, Costy, Goulam, Nawal.









80% of the money will go directly to support
Dahari’s core field programmes to reforest the Comoros in order to conserve
water resources, boost farmer incomes, and conserve the Livingstone’s fruit
bat.


10% will go towards creating the album and ensuring
it is heard in every village in the Comoros through a communications campaign
involving concerts and the distribution of CDs.


The final 10% will go towards the admin costs,
including site fees at 8% and delivery of rewards. 













*****************************************


Version Française

*****************************************

"Il est encore temps de sauver nos
forêts. Acheter l'album, c'est contribuer à protéger nos forêts, soutenir nos
agriculteurs, mais aussi à laisser quelque chose à nos enfants. J'appelle tout
le monde à rejoindre le mouvement Sing 4 Comoros Forests."
Maalesh,
parrain de la campagne (lauréat
du prix RFI Musiques du Monde 1995 et du prix Musiques de l'Océan Indien 2007)




Les Comores ont souffert du taux de déforestation le plus élevé du monde de 2000 à 2010, ce qui a causé beaucoup de problèmes pour les populations.
Imaginez que vous puissiez reboiser les Comores simplement en écoutant de la
musique. Parce qu’en achetant un nouvel album qui réunit des musiciens
comoriens reconnus, vous pouvez ! Les recettes de cette campagne seront
utilisées pour soutenir le travail de l'ONG
Dahari pour sauver les ressources en eau, augmenter les
revenus des communautés rurales, et conserver la Roussette de Livingstone,
en danger critique d'extinction. Si nous récoltons 60 000 dollars avec cette
campagne, nous pourrons soutenir les communautés à planter 150 000 arbres en
2016. 




Sur l’île d’Anjouan,
le déclin environnemental est clairement visible : sur les 50 rivières qui
coulaient autrefois, on ne compte plus qu’une dizaine de rivières permanentes,
et les rendements agricoles diminuent. Un cercle vicieux s’est installé :
la pauvreté mène à la déforestation et vice versa. La situation est tellement
désespérée que chaque année des centaines de personnes trouvent la mort en
tentant de traverser le bras de mer qui les sépare de l’île de
Mayotte, sous administration française. 








L’ONG Dahari (qui
signifie « durable ») a développé une série d’outils qui donnent du
pouvoir aux communautés pour stopper la déforestation tout en assurant des
conditions de vie et des revenus meilleurs. Créée début 2013, l’ONG a
déjà :



aidé plus de 3500
comoriens parmi les plus défavorisés à augmenter leurs revenus par l’agriculture


développé les
premières initiatives de gestion forestières aux Comores, pour protéger les ressources en eau
prioritaires et les hotspots de biodiversité


développé un
réseau de soutien international, avec des partenariats techniques et financiers avec
plus de 30 institutions aux Comores, à Madagascar, en France, au Royaume-Uni,
en Australie, aux Pays-Bas et aux Etats-Unis.






Nous avons besoin de votre aide pour reboiser
les Comores. Vous pouvez aider Dahari à planter 150 000 arbres avec les
communautés locales en 2016 : 



des arbres fruitiers et des arbres cultivés pour leur bois, pour augmenter
les revenus des agriculteurs


des arbres à croissance rapide pour former des haies anti-érosion et
fournir du fourrage pour le bétail


des arbres indigènes pour protéger les sources d’eau et nourrir la faune
endémique.


C’est une
opportunité unique de sauver les Comores de l’effondrement environnemental,
tout en appréciant de la bonne musique comorienne. Faites appel à votre générosité, donnez ! 







Faites un don en commandant une contrepartie (contactez-nous si vous voulez faire un don hors-ligne)


Partagez nos publications avec le hashtag
#Sing4ComorosForests


Prenez
une photo ou faites une vidéo avec un panneau #Sing4ComorosForests


Faites
tourner la campagne sur Facebook et Twitter et dans vos réseaux (contactez-nous si vous voulez un kit de supporter avec des exemples de publications)

Organisez un concert ou un événement "Sing 4 Comoros Forests" (contactez-nous si vous voulez de l'aide)








Cette compilation
est une initiative de l’ONG Dahari et d’Ouvoimoja, un groupe
comorien qui réunit les musiciens les plus talentueux de l’île d’Anjouan. La
musique d’Ouvoimoja, une fusion de reggae, de folk et de mgodro comorien, parle de la beauté des Comores et de la dure
réalité de la vie dans nos îles.

Une dizaine de
musiciens connus des Comores se sont unis pour rejoindre la campagne et ont
accepté de participer sur l’album, qui comptera les notamment les trois chansons d'Ouvoimoja : Walozi (les pêcheurs), Rilemewa (nous sommes fatigués) et Ulanga (la nature).
Ils ont rejoint le projet : Maalesh, Eliasse, Cheikh MC, Mounawar, Dadiposlim, Costy, Goulam, Nawal.







80% de l’argent reviendra directement pour soutenir
les programmes de Dahari pour reboiser les Comores pour conserver les
ressources en eau, augmenter les revenus des agriculteurs, et conserver la
roussette de Livingstone.


10% seront utilisés pour créer l’album et
assurer qu’il soit écouté dans chaque village des Comores, par une campagne de
communication incluant des concerts et des distributions de CDs


Les derniers 10% seront utilisés pour les coûts
administratifs, notamment la commission d’Indiegogo de 8% et les frais de
livraison des contreparties.

story:
We deserve a world in which we can all thrive!  That’s why hundreds of community leaders of all ages and backgrounds are coming together at the NC Climate Justice Summit on Nov. 20-22nd.  We’re facing severe threats—droughts, floods, hurricanes, sea level rise—and worsening pollution and economic inequality.  So, we need to skill up, get creative and take strategic action.  We’re coming together at the Summit to become the solutionaries needed in the fight for climate justice. 

The people who are hit first and worst by climate change are leading the way forward, but we need your support to build our movement.  Your contribution will provide scholarships for the youth leaders who are attending this groundbreaking Summit.  Plus, your contribution will help us receive a matching challenge grant from the Fund for Democratic Communities!

Please give generously today!

story:
Short Summary

ANIMALIA IN NATURE is a sustainability project that aims to inspire a greater connection with nature in urban Sydney.

Our events feature outdoor film screenings of family friendly documentaries of the natural world.

Guests are invited to participate in a multi-sensory experience by dressing as their favourite animal in line with the each event’s theme. The theme will be based on the film subject, which we will select. For example, “Animalia in the Forests” or “Animalia Under the Sea”.

Each event will be free and will feature roving flora and fauna characters, smoking and growing ceremonies and behaviour change motivational giveaways, allowing guests to be fully immersed within the natural word.

Our first event will be take place in January.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $3000 to get our project on the ground and running

The breakdown is:

The venue (Coal Loader Sustainability Building - Waverton) – $350

The Screen (Big screen hire) - $1200

Insurance - $200

Graphic design - $250

Accessories for the event – guest speakers, actors, lights, chair hire, possible eco-food and beverage van –$1000

Any amount we raise over our goal will be put towards the next event in April

The Impact

We all know that time is a precious resource and lacking amongst Sydney’s working population. Outdoor film screenings in serene locations are a great way to captivate our imaginations, infuse us with nature and provide a fun and educational experience.

Thoughtfully selected guest speakers will deliver empowering messages of how we can protect and advocate for our natural spaces.

We want this experience to offer more than just a film, we want to inspire people to be aware and reconnect (and have fun!). 

Risks & Challenges

We cannot afford the rights for screening films. The only way to screen these publicly is if we do not price or ticket our event. 

We do however have to make a booking page - as we can only host 150 people at the venue for venue regulation reasons. 

This is our main hurdle as pricing tickets would have been the easiest way to fund this project.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are really keen to hear form anyone who would like to donate giveaway products in line with our messaging to distribute at our events.

Meet Our Team:

Steve Williams

Caitlin Scullin

Stacey Cournoyer

Andrew Burford

story:
Cloud Forest Conservation Team

For three years, board members of the Cloud Forest Conservation Initiative (CFCI) have been traveling to the Guatemalan highlands to work with the K'iche speaking Maya to help preserve over 40,000 acres of old growth cloud forest.  We continue our mission to help preserve this ecological gem through conservation biology work and to incentivize the Maya via eco-tourism and community service. This is who we are:

  • CFCI is a non-profit based in North America and Guatemala. www.forestprimeval.org
  • Inchanted Journeys teams with CFCI to help bring amazing people from all over the world to this gorgeous ancient forest for conservation biology, eco-tourism, and community service. www.inchantedjourneys.com
  • We are a team of scientists, social advocates, and wilderness adventurers working to conserve the largest unprotected old growth cloud forest in Central America.   
  • We are working with the Maya to establish conservation strategies, set aside programs, and economic incentives with the goal of establishing a large conservation area or preserve.

We have had many successes. Right now, the key is getting more brilliant people into the cloud forest to fall in love with the forest and her people.  Many Guatemalans are now asking if they can join us and need some financial support to cover their costs of travel, food, lodging, and conservation efforts.  Ask yourself: can you help CFCI make this happen?

What We Need & What You Get

CFCI's campaign for the 2016 year is simple:

  • We need to raise $1,500.00 to help underwrite the cost of several native Guatemalans to participate in the eco-trek and to continue these conservation efforts. Any extra money will be funneled into sustainable community development projects, conservation research into threatened and endangered species, and more. 
  • We are excited to offer multiple perks such as CFCI conservation coffee mugs, reusable CFCI shopping bags, Mayan weaves, and for large donations: a seat on the eco-trek (or a gift seat for a friend or family).
  • If we do not reach our goal, all money raised will be dedicated toward the scholarship fund for native Guatemalans.

Projects we have completed in the past with money donated include biological inventories, trail construction/maintenance, greywater installations, native tree nurseries, tools/computers for Guatemalan staff, and direct conservation via land acquisition.

The Impact

Extending this opportunity to native Guatemalans will help bring local attention to this critically important project:

  • Everyone who come to Cerro el Amay and its old growth cloud forest falls in love with it.
  • CFCI has been successfully working with the Maya communities in the region since 2009 and we have fostered strong, collaborative relations with community leaders and members.
  • Inchanted Journeys staff have led successful, life-changing eco-treks all over the world that help bring global awareness and perspective to critical social and environmental hot spots.
  • Your donation will help real people make a real and direct impact.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge with conservation work in the highlands of Guatemala is the poverty of the Maya.  Here is what we are doing about it:

  • Providing a source of viable income to the Maya involved in leading us into the forest, conducting conservation studies, protecting their lands, providing us with meals and housing, and more.
  • Working with Mayan communities to develop sustainable economic development through conservation and alternative agriculture/permaculture.
  • Bringing people into their communities who are sincerely interested in the Mayan way of life and supporting their growth and heritage.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out to everyone you know who may be interested in supporting this campaign.
  • Come on one of our eco-treks: www.inchantedjourneys.com
  • Help us with other support work.
  • Visit the Cloud Forest Conservation Initiative: www.forestprimeval.org
  • Bring us your ideas!

Thank you for your help!

story:
Project Drawdown

This initiative is inspired by Project Drawdown, an organization that identifies solutions for global warming by deploying climate solutions as quickly, safely and equitably as possible. 

Main takeaways are:

  • The #1 way of lowering greenhouse gas emissions is to improve Refrigerant Management.
  • Substitutes are already on the market, including natural refrigerants such as carbon dioxide.
  • Phasing out HFCs could avoid additional emissions equivalent to 25 to 78 GIGATONS of carbon dioxide.

What We Need & What You Get

The George Street Co-op needs:

  • $10,000.00 to launch the Energy Efficiency Initiative.
    • This includes working with an experienced refrigeration management consultant, applying for grants, and properly disposing of the current refrigeration system. Funds will also be allocated to replacing the current refrigeration system with an environmentally-friendly one, powered by natural refrigerants.

What you get:

  • Your impact will improve the quality of life at the Co-op and improve the energy efficiency of the Co-op's refrigeration system.
  • Energy savings will be used to fund more energy efficiency projects, creating a positive feedback loop.
  • You will receive sincere gratitude from a loving community of dedicated individuals.


 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to make a donation, please consider helping in other ways:

  • Tell your friends
  • Post on social media
  • Join the Co-op Outreach Committee
  • Join the Co-op Finance Committee
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools

 

 THANK YOU!!! See the FAQ section below for more details.

story: Every handful of compost contains millions of microbes. Sure, they are not much individually, but together? They're a force of nature. Become that force. Help us grow this grassroots movement to break up with waste and build the most sustainable organics program ever.
