story:
EXPEDITION SACRED SEA (in a nutshell):

Inadequate waste management and increased human activities due to tourism even remote, pristine and vast areas are negatively impacted. Lake Baikal (Russia) is an example and in summer 2016 we are planning to investigate the presence of plastic contamination in the world's deepest, largest and oldest lake. We will sail and dive around the entire circumference of the lake to document the current ecological crisis which is threatening its ecosystem. 


Expedition Sacred Sea (the full story):

Lake Baikal - also called the Sacred Sea of Siberia is the largest reservoir of freshwater in the world, containing approximately 20% of the total unfrozen freshwater. It is also known as the clearest of all lakes and is a symbol of  unspoiled and unique nature with very rich biodiversity. It hosts more than 1,000 species of plants and 2,500 species of animals of which more than 80% of are endemic. These are all reasons it has been listed as a UNESCO natural world heritage site in 1996. 

source: http://petr.juracka.eu

The new Baikal? 

Since 2008 dramatic changes of the ecosystem have been reported. This deterioration of the environmental health is caused by eutrophication, a process in which the water is saturated by phosphates and nitrates of human origin causing abnormal proliferation of some algae, cyanobacteria and phytoplankton. Last year it has been reported that this bloom covered almost entirely the water surface in shallow areas and in some places reached depths up to 40m. 


The source of pollution is increasing human activities and improper waste management. All changes have been very rapid and reported over a short period of time: the last 3-5 years.  Scientists call this dramatic situation a crisis that could affect the ecosystem irreversibly. The lake is turning into a swamp and many endemic species could be lost solely within this generation as the algea bloom interferes with spawning of the fish and by producing resilient toxins that can be dangerous also to human health.  Moreover 90% of Baikal sponges that can take over 200 years to grow to a size of over a meter are affected by an unknown disease and are now dying within one season.

Algal bloom in Baikal 

     Healthy Baikal sponges (left) and affected by necrosis (right)                                  source: Igor Khanaev 


The Plastic Problem 

Plastic is one of the most widely used materials in the world and its production is growing immensely. However, it is estimated that approximately 10% of produced plastic ends up in the oceans. Plastic pollution is an environmental problem spiraling out of control posing a threat to marine systems where it is now spreading globally to even the most remote habitats and to fresh water reservoirs. 

Plastic waste on a beach in the remote Commander Islands, Russia 

Microplastics, particles less than 5mm in size, can be formed by fragmentation of larger plastic pieces, industrial ‘scrubbers’, micro-beads in cosmetics, and plastic nanoparticles used in industry.

The hazardous consequences of microplastic pollution in the marine environment are starting to be a cause of great concern. Microplastics are ingested across the entire food web from marine invertebrates to mammals, with severe effects on the health of the organisms. Furthermore, pollutants can adhere to microplastic particles and leaching of toxins can occur.

             Microplastic particles from 1L of sediment.                                                                    source: Baztan et al. Marine Pollution Bulletin (2014)

Microplastic pollution poses a serious threat to the environment leading to social, economic and health repercussions. Extensive research is being done mapping the distribution of microplastic in marine environments but their distribution in fresh water reservoirs still remains relatively unknown.

Our Aim: 

In order to address the problem of microplastic contamination we wish to: 

  • analyze for the first time plastic pollution in the lake Baikal 

  • compare distribution of plastics within the water column at sites with varying population densities

  • contribute to public available databases describing the distribution of plastics on a global scale

  • publish scientific papers

  • raise awareness on plastic pollution by presenting our findings in talks, articles and a short film 

    Who we are: 

    We are two SCUBA divers with extensive experience in adventurous and challenging conditions. During our surface intervals we are both lab based biologists interested in gene regulation and stem cells. This gives us the scientific skills to carry out this project. On our dives we have noticed an increase in plastic pollution also in remote areas, which greatly concerns us. We became interested in this problem and as scientists want to contribute to the research and to raise awareness of this global issue.

    Plan of the Expedition & What We Need 

    We will spend about 6 weeks in Lake Baikal travelling in a catamaran alongside a Russian sailing team around the entire circumference of the lake. 

    On the way we will SCUBA dive and collect water samples from the surface and underwater to establish the levels of plastic contamination. We will also sample shore sediments, survey the shoreline and analyse fish stomach contents for the presence of plastic debris. 

    We will also be taking lot of pictures & footage on land and underwater for a short movie documenting the current ecological situation in Baikal. 

    We have covered our flights to Russia, diving and camping gear. We have also recently obtained dSLR camera and underwater housing, to be able to take high quality images and videos. Moreover, we obtained a generous support from a dive centre in Baikal that will kindly provide us with tanks, a portable compressor and a first aid oxygen kit to take on the catamaran. This will allow us to safely dive even in the most remote areas. 

    We are asking for your help to cover our additional expenses including logistics (sailing, accommodation & food) and reagents and materials needed for the analysis of collected samples. 

    Details of our Budget: 

                                         Expenditure GBP
                                      Transport:
                                         Flights London - Irkutsk-London   1292
                                                        Contribution to sailing    1381
                                          Visa & Insurance:
                                              Russian Visas   136
                                                Diving & Travel Insurance   178.84
                                        Living Costs:
                                             Accommodation & Food    300
                                           Bank fees   80
                                        Equipment:
                                                  Equipment service   454.82
                                         Reagents   80
                                      TOTAL:   3902.66


    Other ways to help

    If you are interested in our project please follow us on our website and social media and help us spread the word! 

    THANK YOU!
story_txt:
EXPEDITION SACRED SEA (in a nutshell):

Inadequate waste management and increased human activities due to tourism even remote, pristine and vast areas are negatively impacted. Lake Baikal (Russia) is an example and in summer 2016 we are planning to investigate the presence of plastic contamination in the world's deepest, largest and oldest lake. We will sail and dive around the entire circumference of the lake to document the current ecological crisis which is threatening its ecosystem. 


Expedition Sacred Sea (the full story):

Lake Baikal - also called the Sacred Sea of Siberia is the largest reservoir of freshwater in the world, containing approximately 20% of the total unfrozen freshwater. It is also known as the clearest of all lakes and is a symbol of  unspoiled and unique nature with very rich biodiversity. It hosts more than 1,000 species of plants and 2,500 species of animals of which more than 80% of are endemic. These are all reasons it has been listed as a UNESCO natural world heritage site in 1996.
